And by the way, in the time period of opening our models, we have got construction superintendents and construction managers out there, who are opening these  communities in 15 days from the time that we sign the contracts and pour the slab. We have a model open and operational.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Bill, I just have a question for you back on that margin this quarter and the 110 basis points from warranty and litigation accruals. I think I understand what this is, but can you give me a little more detail on that specifically? I'm assuming
componenttext: And then, Bill, I just have a question for you back on that margin this quarter and the 110 basis points from warranty and litigation accruals. I think I understand what this is, but can you give me a little more detail on that specifically? I'm assuming this is closings in which you didn't need to book the contingent warranty and then it ran off. But the litigation side and what you're thinking about how that will impact the next couple of quarters, do you have visibility there?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, on both litigation and warranty, really, they are estimates and largely estimates of expectations of future claims based on the history of our claims, based on our tail of closings that we have closed in the past. And so each quarter, as we close hom
componenttext: Yes, on both litigation and warranty, really, they are estimates and largely estimates of expectations of future claims based on the history of our claims, based on our tail of closings that we have closed in the past. And so each quarter, as we close homes, we book an estimate of what we expect those future claims would be, and then we adjust any of our estimates based on our claims history. If you recall last quarter, the impact in the current quarter on as a percentage of revenues was actually hurt our margin by around 50 basis points, if I recall. This quarter, the adjustment there relative to last quarter was an improvement of 110 basis points. And so really, what we look at is our experience in terms of both the warranty and litigation. We look at our tail and typically, we are adding to those accruals each quarter as we close additional homes. It's just a matter of how much we add relative to the revenue that we had in the quarter. This quarter we had much higher closings volume. And so the relative change in the overall accrual had a less impact.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Reheart (sic) [Michael Rehaut] from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Reheart (sic) [Michael Rehaut] from JPMorgan.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: First question, I just wanted to circle back to earlier talk about the tax credit but also the change in the FHA, growing from 6% to 3% in terms of help on the closing. In that type of world, which we might enter, we'd be entering later this year, can you
componenttext: First question, I just wanted to circle back to earlier talk about the tax credit but also the change in the FHA, growing from 6% to 3% in terms of help on the closing. In that type of world, which we might enter, we'd be entering later this year, can you just give me a sense of the flexibility you have in your plans? Because you've talked about anticipating perhaps making tweaks and changes, flexibility in terms of your average selling price and also incremental incentives?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: First all, I think we're better positioned than anyone in the industry with our current product, as well as what our average sales price is. The way I look at the changes and all, whether it be FICO scores, whether it be the 6% -- 3% to 6% or 6% to 3%, we
componenttext: First all, I think we're better positioned than anyone in the industry with our current product, as well as what our average sales price is. The way I look at the changes and all, whether it be FICO scores, whether it be the 6% -- 3% to 6% or 6% to 3%, we're all going to have to deal with it as the buyers come in our door. And I think that we're properly positioned to do that. I think to take the noise away from the industry, it would be good to get whatever is going to be enacted, enacted and whatever is going to be terminated, terminated so that we get back to a more normalized homebuilding environment and get the tax credits and that sort of thing out of our business so that we can fully compete with one another out there. And we believe we're better positioned to compete in the industry than anyone else. So we're hoping that we get back to no tax credit, where ever the FHA percentage is. And let's move on and find out who's standing when it's all said and done.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: But I guess what I'm getting at is the 200 ASP that we saw in orders in the quarter, I mean could that, just within the mix that you offer, go to 180 without a real drop in gross margins? Do you have that flexibility in terms of your product offering with
componenttext: But I guess what I'm getting at is the 200 ASP that we saw in orders in the quarter, I mean could that, just within the mix that you offer, go to 180 without a real drop in gross margins? Do you have that flexibility in terms of your product offering with similar margins to make an adjustment? Or would you have to give some back on incentives and discounts?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's going to be a combination of both. But let me say, clearly, as Don Horton and I have been in the field for three weeks a month for the last two years, one of the things that we've done very well in this company, we'd invite anyone who's liste
componenttext: I think it's going to be a combination of both. But let me say, clearly, as Don Horton and I have been in the field for three weeks a month for the last two years, one of the things that we've done very well in this company, we'd invite anyone who's listening or any of the analyst community to come out. We've really repositioned our products, such that we are building an Albuquerque homes from 800 square feet and larger. In California, we're building homes that are selling from 160, down 50%, 60% off the peak. So notwithstanding whatever changes, I think we're positioned with our product to the extent and with a good margin in it because we don't have lost leaders in this company. We frac [ph], as we've said for years, every house is a profit center for us, and we don't have lost leaders in any one community. So our low-end product, our lowest-priced product in the company should make the same gross margin as the remaining product in that particular subdivision. So we believe we're well positioned to handle whatever comes at us.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: And just a couple of housekeeping, the impact from prior impairments, Bill, if you could give that for the quarter. You had mentioned that, as well as can you give us a sense of the average incentive that you're offering today as a percent of home price a
componenttext: And just a couple of housekeeping, the impact from prior impairments, Bill, if you could give that for the quarter. You had mentioned that, as well as can you give us a sense of the average incentive that you're offering today as a percent of home price and where that was relative to the peak and what normal is?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the impairment release this quarter, on homes gross margin, that was $117 million release that had an impact of 10.5% on margin. That's actually a lower impact than last quarter, where we had a $134 million run through and a 13.3% impact last
componenttext: In terms of the impairment release this quarter, on homes gross margin, that was $117 million release that had an impact of 10.5% on margin. That's actually a lower impact than last quarter, where we had a $134 million run through and a 13.3% impact last quarter. And in terms of overall incentive percentages compared to history, we don't report those in terms of specific numbers because a lot of things go into that. But where we are today with our adjusted product, with our adjusted cost, with our current -- with our pricing that we have set based on that cost in the marketplace today, clearly, we are offering fewer incentives than we were a year or two ago. If you go into a subdivision and we have our standard price and you have your standard incentive package that's there. But that's less than we were offering a year or two ago.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, along those lines, to  follow-up on your question earlier, there are a lot of our competitors trying to figure out what they really are. They're analyzing their subdivisions and their product lines and all these sorts of things to try to create t
componenttext: Michael, along those lines, to  follow-up on your question earlier, there are a lot of our competitors trying to figure out what they really are. They're analyzing their subdivisions and their product lines and all these sorts of things to try to create these niches. There's one thing about Horton. Truly, the heart of the market today is entry level. We know what we are. We're the king of entry level, and no one understands it like we do. So we're well positioned to continue to capitalize on the heart of the market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: And Bill, just want last thing, you had given us some directional guidance in terms of the incentives. Is it also safe to say though that you still have a bit to go to get back to a normal level?
componenttext: And Bill, just want last thing, you had given us some directional guidance in terms of the incentives. Is it also safe to say though that you still have a bit to go to get back to a normal level?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, in a more healthy housing environment, where there's job growth and there's the demand that we've seen at healthier times in the past, clearly, yes. There could be a time when we will see fewer incentives than we see today. But as Don has s
componenttext: Well, clearly, in a more healthy housing environment, where there's job growth and there's the demand that we've seen at healthier times in the past, clearly, yes. There could be a time when we will see fewer incentives than we see today. But as Don has shared, we still are very realistic about what the future may hold in the overall health of the economy and the housing market, so we could be a ways away from that sort of environment again.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Alex Barron from Housing Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alex Barron from Housing Research.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Don, I was wondering if you could share your thoughts on the shadow inventory concerns like some people have?
componenttext: Don, I was wondering if you could share your thoughts on the shadow inventory concerns like some people have?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's no question that there is shadow inventory out there. I was reading on a bunch of reports last night before this conference call, and it's astounding to me, one, that still the high level of people who are underwater on their mortgages in som
componenttext: Yes, there's no question that there is shadow inventory out there. I was reading on a bunch of reports last night before this conference call, and it's astounding to me, one, that still the high level of people who are underwater on their mortgages in some of the key markets for the whole industry, as well as the number of people who are delinquent and in foreclosure, coupled with the fact that the bank inventory foreclosed units. So I think we're going to be continually dealing with that over the course of the next couple of years, that's why we think the next couple of years in the industry will be challenging. The thing that can help the industry the most is for us to begin to have some. As we've had stabilization on values, I was looking on a list of  our ASPs, and it's pretty interesting to me, out of 33 of the markets that we track, we really only, in our humble opinion, have weakness in our pricing in about four or five of those markets, and the rest of our markets have stabilized pretty well. But to get back to a point where we have some appreciation in housing values, I think it's the only thing that's going to make our industry better going forward. We're going to be fighting the shadow foreclosure, the delinquencies, all of these people underwater on their mortgages. We have to get housing values back somewhere closer to where they were, which is a long-term process.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I was also wondering, you guys mentioned you had, I believe it was 22,000, maybe I didn't get those number right, 22,000 finished lots that you own. And then, you also have some other finished lots that you optioned. So my question is, what happens if you
componenttext: I was also wondering, you guys mentioned you had, I believe it was 22,000, maybe I didn't get those number right, 22,000 finished lots that you own. And then, you also have some other finished lots that you optioned. So my question is, what happens if you couldn't find additional option lots? Are you guys going to start developing those other lots that you have? Or are you just -- and how much money would it take to continue to develop those? Or are you going to go further, keep on looking for distressed finished lots?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the answer to both questions is yes. Currently, we still see an adequate supply of lots in most of our markets of what we call finished lots owned by others, who we can buy on an option basis. We do have land that is mothballed. We pull some
componenttext: Well, I think the answer to both questions is yes. Currently, we still see an adequate supply of lots in most of our markets of what we call finished lots owned by others, who we can buy on an option basis. We do have land that is mothballed. We pull some of the land out every quarter and begin to develop it when it makes economic sense for us to develop it. So as a result, I think most of our lot inventory will be -- or houses will continue to be built on the 22,000 lots that we own. That's our goal, to work our way through our existing lot inventory, as well as to work our way through our 24,000 option lots and continue to add to those. We have some partially finished lots. Once we get finished with the vast majority of our 22,000 finished lots, then we'll start focusing on how we work our way through the partially finished lots. I somewhat am disappointed, as people continue to focus on our owned lot inventory. And I would say to you that we've done a wonderful job of continuing to work our way through our owned lot inventory as it makes economic sense and supplementing that with option deals. The fact that we have $1.9 billion in cash, we're one of the few builders starting specs in most of our markets, makes us the pre-eminent buyer for these option deals. So I look at our owned lot inventory and say, "It's slowly but surely being merged in with our closings on option lots, and we're having a wonderful merged gross margin on both product lines."

So you're exactly right. He is smiling. And he doesn't smile much.

componenttext: Yes, 3,100 under construction. Okay, but we talked about we need to achieve, like, greater than 100% backlog conversion.

componenttextpreview: Well, Tim, the good news is...
componenttext: Well, Tim, the good news is...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Let me first of all say Jones, you were with Horton one time when he was asleep at the wheel. I assure you that we're not asleep at the wheel on specs. Okay?
componenttext: Let me first of all say Jones, you were with Horton one time when he was asleep at the wheel. I assure you that we're not asleep at the wheel on specs. Okay?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I think what your analysis is missing is that we're going to continue to sell homes this quarter. So not every home that is a spec today is going be a spec when we report again at March 31.
componenttext: I think what your analysis is missing is that we're going to continue to sell homes this quarter. So not every home that is a spec today is going be a spec when we report again at March 31.

componenttextpreview: It will be in backlog. If it has not closed, it will be in backlog at March 31, and we have one more quarter to then close that backlog.
componenttext: It will be in backlog. If it has not closed, it will be in backlog at March 31, and we have one more quarter to then close that backlog.

componenttextpreview: Don't worry about our specs. We will control those better than anyone else.
componenttext: Don't worry about our specs. We will control those better than anyone else.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Wilson at JMP Security (sic) [JMP Securities].
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jim Wilson at JMP Security (sic) [JMP Securities].

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I guess my first question, you mentioned that there were only a few markets left where you were seeing any weakness on pricing. Could you just give maybe, I don't know, your top three in terms of strength of pricing, and weakness in pricing in terms of ge
componenttext: I guess my first question, you mentioned that there were only a few markets left where you were seeing any weakness on pricing. Could you just give maybe, I don't know, your top three in terms of strength of pricing, and weakness in pricing in terms of geographic location?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Firmly, one, I'll combine all of Texas, and hopefully that will suffice. But I look at Houston, it had an extraordinary quarter, and is having an extraordinary second quarter. I say the same thing about San Antonio, and both of our Dallas-Forth Worth mark
componenttext: Firmly, one, I'll combine all of Texas, and hopefully that will suffice. But I look at Houston, it had an extraordinary quarter, and is having an extraordinary second quarter. I say the same thing about San Antonio, and both of our Dallas-Forth Worth markets, and even in a tough market like Austin is right now, we're doing very well on Austin. So I think Texas because of the fact that we didn't have any big peak, we didn't have much of a valley. And we have good job growth in Texas. I was reading the other day that we're expected to generate 100,000 new jobs in Texas in calendar year 2010. So I look at Texas as certainly a strong market. Now the weak markets continue to be Las Vegas and certainly Phoenix. There are a lot of people underwater on their mortgages on both of those markets, and there are foreclosures and delinquencies. The good thing about both of those markets is that the listings are declining in each one of those markets. And that's a function of a couple of things. I think people are taking their homes off the market because they can't sell them. And secondly, I think the banks are doing a good job of metering out the foreclosed homes ahead. So that's my read on the strong and the weak.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: And then my other question is on the land acquisition environment. So obviously did a, I guess, pretty good job in at least spending a couple of hundred million dollars, and you suggested obviously higher margins. Could you describe, as you look at it, ki
componenttext: And then my other question is on the land acquisition environment. So obviously did a, I guess, pretty good job in at least spending a couple of hundred million dollars, and you suggested obviously higher margins. Could you describe, as you look at it, kind of incrementally and the deals you're looking at now, is pricing on lots stable or is it getting more competitive and thus higher? Or how would you kind of characterize it?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I think it's becoming a more competitive environment, both of the number of potential buyers, as well as the pricing. Certainly, I think that the investors who entered the market three years ago, entered tad early. I think the investors who are entering t
componenttext: I think it's becoming a more competitive environment, both of the number of potential buyers, as well as the pricing. Certainly, I think that the investors who entered the market three years ago, entered tad early. I think the investors who are entering today think that the homebuilding environment is going to continue to improve. And we'll have to see what that holds. As we said earlier, we can see our way to July 1, and then thereafter, we'll have to see what the homebuilding market affords us. We're well positioned to meet whatever the challenges are. But I think, in general, I think there could be a temporary market condition, where we've got more buyers at higher prices than what we've encountered over the course of the past 12 months.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Buck Horne from Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Buck Horne from Raymond James.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Would you be willing to quantify or just kind of give us a ballpark idea what you think the right number of specs you'd like to enter the fourth quarter with would be, given where you think the demand would drop off to?
componenttext: Would you be willing to quantify or just kind of give us a ballpark idea what you think the right number of specs you'd like to enter the fourth quarter with would be, given where you think the demand would drop off to?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say right now, we're waiting to see the answer to that question as well. And it's going to be driven by the sales volume that we see, primarily after the tax credit, it should expire on the sales front at April 30.
componenttext: I'd say right now, we're waiting to see the answer to that question as well. And it's going to be driven by the sales volume that we see, primarily after the tax credit, it should expire on the sales front at April 30.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: The way we'll be managing through that through the spring is as we work into the heart of the selling season, we will slow down our starts during the selling season once we get to the point where we can no longer sell and close a home and still take advan
componenttext: The way we'll be managing through that through the spring is as we work into the heart of the selling season, we will slow down our starts during the selling season once we get to the point where we can no longer sell and close a home and still take advantage of the tax credit. So we will be working down our spec levels during this time the tax credit is still outstanding. And hopefully, we land it where we expect the demand will be, but we'll start monitoring that as the expiration nears and after it passes.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: But I want to bring up something that I haven't brought up before, and as one of our Regional Presidents says, the homes that we're building today, obviously with our 17.1% gross margin at Q1, to the extent that we end up with a few additional specs that
componenttext: But I want to bring up something that I haven't brought up before, and as one of our Regional Presidents says, the homes that we're building today, obviously with our 17.1% gross margin at Q1, to the extent that we end up with a few additional specs that we need to move in that fourth quarter. Clearly, we believe that we'll be moving those with a profitable margin in them, albeit it may not be 17.1%. But our cost are, we believe, the best in the industry, combined with our option lot purchases that we're making. So therefore, notwithstanding the fact we may have a few extra specs, I think those still move at a good margin.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of cycle times, can you give us a little bit of color on how fast you can start and guarantee a delivery, given the pace that you're working at today? And how fast can we put houses in the ground and deliver them before the tax credit deadlin
componenttext: And in terms of cycle times, can you give us a little bit of color on how fast you can start and guarantee a delivery, given the pace that you're working at today? And how fast can we put houses in the ground and deliver them before the tax credit deadline?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, that's going to vary by, really, subdivision and division, depending upon the size of the product and how complicated it is but also depends upon the division. But marginally speaking, it ranges from about we can deliver product in some of our marke
componenttext: Well, that's going to vary by, really, subdivision and division, depending upon the size of the product and how complicated it is but also depends upon the division. But marginally speaking, it ranges from about we can deliver product in some of our markets within 60 days. And in some markets, it's going to take us four months. So each one of our divisions and each one of our subdivisions in terms of supplementing our existing specs, we are looking at whether or not we have time to construct those and meet the 6/30 (sic) [4/30] deadline.

componenttextpreview: Thank you. And thank you for joining our conference call. Once again, I give all of our teammates out there our heartfelt congratulations and appreciation because you absolutely outperformed the industry this quarter. As I said on my e-mail this morning,
componenttext: Thank you. And thank you for joining our conference call. Once again, I give all of our teammates out there our heartfelt congratulations and appreciation because you absolutely outperformed the industry this quarter. As I said on my e-mail this morning, now we have to go do it quarter-by-quarter-by-quarter. And we have a challenging second quarter ahead of us. But fully, we expect us, all of you to do as good a job as you did in the first quarter. Our goal is to make money, net profit in each of one of the four quarters this year and for the fiscal year. So let's do it again. You're only as good as your last deal. Thank you, and goodbye.

At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the DR Horton America's Builder First Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010

componenttext: Thank you, Courtney. Thank you, and good morning. Joining me this morning are Bill Wheat, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Stacey Dwyer, Executive Vice President and Treasurer. Before we get started, Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010

Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: First, we want to thank all of our DHI team members for generating our first profit since Q1 fiscal year '08. Congratulations to each of you. We have all pursued a long and arduous road characterized by downsizing, impairing and consolidating to adjust to
componenttext: First, we want to thank all of our DHI team members for generating our first profit since Q1 fiscal year '08. Congratulations to each of you. We have all pursued a long and arduous road characterized by downsizing, impairing and consolidating to adjust to an ever-changing national, regional and local economic and housing environment. We have successfully negotiated the road together. This, coupled with your superior effort to secure new lot positions at attractive prices over the last year, places DHI in a preeminent position in our industry with a great opportunity to build on what we have started. It prides us the privilege of telling the public about your accomplishments in this conference call. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: On a pretax basis, including impairments, we are excited to report a pretax profit of $42.8 million. Both our Homebuilding and Financial Services segment were profitable. Our net income for the quarter was $192 million or $0.56 per diluted share compared
componenttext: On a pretax basis, including impairments, we are excited to report a pretax profit of $42.8 million. Both our Homebuilding and Financial Services segment were profitable. Our net income for the quarter was $192 million or $0.56 per diluted share compared to a net loss of $62.6 million or $0.20 per share in the prior year quarter. Net income for the current quarter includes an income tax benefit of $149.2 million related to the recent change in the tax law for NOL carrybacks. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Let's be clear. Our goal this year is profitability in each and every quarter and for the entire fiscal year. Profitability in the second quarter will be challenging as we will not close as many homes in the second quarter as we did in the first quarter.
componenttext: Let's be clear. Our goal this year is profitability in each and every quarter and for the entire fiscal year. Profitability in the second quarter will be challenging as we will not close as many homes in the second quarter as we did in the first quarter. We are entering the quarter with 4,136 homes in backlog, and we will need to realize a backlog conversion ratio of greater than 100% to reach profitability. With the extension and expansion of the homebuyer tax credit and with our available housing inventory, a high backlog conversion rate is entirely achievable, but we do not expect to be as profitable as we were this quarter. In the third quarter, we expect strong closing since homes must close since June 30 for the extended tax credit. The third quarter will probably be our strongest quarter for profits this year. We expect our September quarter will be the most challenging as the tax credit support for home sales will have expired. As we move past the selling season, we will be able to get a better read on core demand and we will adjust our business accordingly. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Net sales orders for the first quarter were 4,037 homes, up 45% from the same quarter in the prior year. Our average sales price on net sales orders in the quarter increased approximately 3% both sequentially and from the year-ago quarter to $210,600. Our
componenttext: Net sales orders for the first quarter were 4,037 homes, up 45% from the same quarter in the prior year. Our average sales price on net sales orders in the quarter increased approximately 3% both sequentially and from the year-ago quarter to $210,600. Our cancellation rate was 26% in the quarter.Our sales backlog increased 3% from the prior year to 4,136 homes or $884 million. Our first quarter home sales revenues increased to $1.1 billion or 5,529 homes from $886 million or 4068 homes in the year-ago quarter. Closings were unusually strong for our December quarter, driven by the original November 30 expiration date of the homebuyer tax credit. Our average closing price for the quarter decreased approximately 8% from the year-ago quarter to $200,400. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the first quarter was 17.1%, up 160 basis points from our home sales margin in the year ago period and up 460 basis points sequentially from our September quarter.  Approximately 300 basis points of the seq
componenttext: Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the first quarter was 17.1%, up 160 basis points from our home sales margin in the year ago period and up 460 basis points sequentially from our September quarter.  Approximately 300 basis points of the sequential increase was due to the average costs of our homes declining by more than our average selling prices, partially due to our success constructing enclosing homes on recently-acquired finished lots in new community. 15% of the first quarter closings were from new deals that were contracted for in fiscal 2009. Margins on closings in our new projects are approximately 350 basis points higher than on the remainder of our closings. Approximately 110 basis points of the sequential increase in gross margin was due to the current quarter change in our warranty and litigation accruals as a percentage of home sales revenue. The final 50 basis points was due to a decrease in the amortization of capitalized interest and property taxes. The decreased amortization resulted from reductions in our interest and property taxes incurred and capitalized over the past year and we have a greater mix of homes closed on acquired finished lots this quarter. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: As we had indicated on our year-end call, we expect lower impairments in 2010, primarily based on a reduction in our watch list at September 30, 2009. In addition, this quarter, we saw an increase in our home sales gross margin to 17.1%, an increase in ou
componenttext: As we had indicated on our year-end call, we expect lower impairments in 2010, primarily based on a reduction in our watch list at September 30, 2009. In addition, this quarter, we saw an increase in our home sales gross margin to 17.1%, an increase in our average sales price on our net sales and good sales volume. These positive results were incorporated in our first quarter impairment analysis when we reviewed all projects in the company and determine the projects with a pre-impairment carrying value of $5.3 million were impaired. We recorded inventory impairments of $1.7 million as a charge to cost of sales. We refer to our projects which have indicators of potential impairment but we're not impaired as our watch list, which represents those projects deemed to be the highest risk for future impairments. Our watch list is currently $478.7 million, down from $542 million at September 30, 2009, and also down from $1.2 billion at June 30, 2009. The largest concentrations in our watch list are in California, Texas, Hawaii and Illinois. Also, during our first quarter, we had net recoveries of $500,000 of earnest money and pre-acquisition costs. If our margins and absorptions stay at current levels, we expect our impairments to remain at a relatively low level in our second quarter. As we move past April 30, and the expiration of the tax credit, we will evaluate the impact on sales demand, sales prices and expected margins for sales written after April 30. And we will incorporate these market conditions in our inventory impairment process as necessary in the June and September quarters. We still expect our impairments in fiscal 2010 to be substantially lower than those we recorded in fiscal 2009. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Our consistent focus on SG&A was a key to our return to profitability. We have leveraged our SG&A structure to focus on opportunities in our existing markets, and division operations. Home-building SG&A expense for the quarter, which includes all corporat
componenttext: Our consistent focus on SG&A was a key to our return to profitability. We have leveraged our SG&A structure to focus on opportunities in our existing markets, and division operations. Home-building SG&A expense for the quarter, which includes all corporate overhead, in other words a fully loaded number, was $128.4 million, or 11.6% of homebuilding revenues, compared to 14.1% in the year-ago quarter. SG&A increased only $1.4 million or 1% on a 36% increase in homes closed. We will continue to actively manage our SG&A levels relative to our expected number of home closings. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: We recorded $26.9 million in home-building interest expense during the quarter. We are required to expense a portion of our interest incurred as interest expense, while our home building debt level continues to exceed our active inventory. Financial Servi
componenttext: We recorded $26.9 million in home-building interest expense during the quarter. We are required to expense a portion of our interest incurred as interest expense, while our home building debt level continues to exceed our active inventory. Financial Services pretax income for the quarter was $6.7 million, compared to a pretax loss of $2.9 million in the year-ago quarter. 90% of our mortgage company's business was captive during the quarter. Our company-wide capture rate was approximately 61%, our average FICO score was 7/02 and our average combined loan-to-value was 93%. Our product mix in the quarter was essentially 100% agency-eligible, with government loans accounting for 63% of our volume. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: During our December quarter, we received a tax refund of approximately $113 million related to our taxable loss in fiscal 2008. Subsequent to September 30, new legislation was passed that extended the NOL carry back period from two years to five years. We
componenttext: During our December quarter, we received a tax refund of approximately $113 million related to our taxable loss in fiscal 2008. Subsequent to September 30, new legislation was passed that extended the NOL carry back period from two years to five years. We evaluated our options under the five-year carry back, and we elected to carry back our tax loss from fiscal 2009. As a result, we increased our income tax receivables by approximately $200 million, and have filed for a $352 million refund, which we expect to receive in the second quarter of fiscal 2010. The remaining $30 million of our $382 million income tax receivable is expected to be received from state, and federal tax refunds in future periods. Our deferred tax asset is now $915.2 million, and is fully reserved at September 31, 2009. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Our total inventory decreased by approximately $80 million during the first quarter. Our homes in inventory at the end of December totaled 11,500, of which 1,100 were models, 7,300 were speculative and 2,900 of these specs were completed. Of the first qua
componenttext: Our total inventory decreased by approximately $80 million during the first quarter. Our homes in inventory at the end of December totaled 11,500, of which 1,100 were models, 7,300 were speculative and 2,900 of these specs were completed. Of the first quarter closings captured by our mortgage company, 66% were the first-time buyers, who typically purchase spec homes. So we continue to manage both our total number of homes, and inventory, and our number of speculative homes to match expected demand. Our unsold completed homes older than six months were 600 homes at December 31, 2009, down from 800 at September 30. We are prepared for the spring selling season, and for current demand created by the federal home buyer tax credit with our current spec level. We will continue to manage our spec levels very closely as we move closer to the April 30 sales contract deadline for the home buyer tax credit. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Our land and loan acquisition investments remain controlled, and we continually reevaluate our land development plans based on current sales trends. We have been actively contracting for finished lots to supplement our existing land positions, and increas
componenttext: Our land and loan acquisition investments remain controlled, and we continually reevaluate our land development plans based on current sales trends. We have been actively contracting for finished lots to supplement our existing land positions, and increase our current average gross margins. In our first of the quarter, we invested approximately $200 million, primarily in finished lots. Our spending on finished lots will be largely dependent on our sales pace. Our spending on land and development costs will continue to be at very low levels. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Our supply of owned land and lots at December 31, 2009, was approximately 88,000 lots, of which approximately 22,000 are finished lots. We control an additional 24,000 lots through option contracts and our net earnest money deposit balance for these lots
componenttext: Our supply of owned land and lots at December 31, 2009, was approximately 88,000 lots, of which approximately 22,000 are finished lots. We control an additional 24,000 lots through option contracts and our net earnest money deposit balance for these lots is only $9.3 million. We are focused on managing our supply of owned, finished lots in line with our sales demand in a low-risk, capital-efficient manner. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: We generated approximately $220 million in operating cash flow in the quarter, which included $113 million federal income tax refund. Future cash flows, excluding federal tax refunds, will be dependent on our inventory levels, which will be dependent on s
componenttext: We generated approximately $220 million in operating cash flow in the quarter, which included $113 million federal income tax refund. Future cash flows, excluding federal tax refunds, will be dependent on our inventory levels, which will be dependent on sales levels in the spring and summer, especially after the federal tax credit expires. As we have mentioned before, we are focused on changing the source of our cash flow from inventory and balance sheet reductions to income. We ended the quarter with approximately $1.9 billion of unrestricted home building cash. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: In the December quarter, we repurchased approximately $173.2 million of our outstanding notes for $171 million plus accrued interest. The balance of our public notes outstanding at December 31, 2009, was $2.9 billion. Subsequent to quarter end, we have re
componenttext: In the December quarter, we repurchased approximately $173.2 million of our outstanding notes for $171 million plus accrued interest. The balance of our public notes outstanding at December 31, 2009, was $2.9 billion. Subsequent to quarter end, we have repurchased $7.5 million of our outstanding notes, we have redeemed $130.9 million of our 4 7/8% senior notes, which matured in January, and we have announced our intent to redeem in February the remaining $95 million of our 5 7/8% senior notes due 2013 at a price of 101.958%. Our remaining note maturities in fiscal 2010 total $84.6 million.At December 31, our homebuilding leverage ratio, net of cash, was 28%, a 730 basis-point improvement from a year ago. This improvement in leverage compared to the prior year is due primarily to the increase in our cash balances, continued reductions in outstanding debt and the positive impact to equity from both the expansion in the NOL carryback period and the change in accounting principal for debt with conversion options. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: On October 1, 2009, we adopted and applied retrospectively the FASB's new authoritative guidance which specifies that the liability and equity components of convertible debt be separated, and that our interest cost reflect our non-convertible debt borrowi
componenttext: On October 1, 2009, we adopted and applied retrospectively the FASB's new authoritative guidance which specifies that the liability and equity components of convertible debt be separated, and that our interest cost reflect our non-convertible debt borrowing rate as of the issuance date of the convertible notes. As a result, the carrying value of our convertible notes has been reduced to $373.8 million at December 31, 2009, with the primary offset to increase additional paid-in capital. While the cash coupons on these convertible notes is still 2%, the effective rate for the notes for GAAP purposes is approximately 9.7%.  September 30, 2009, and the prior periods have been adjusted for this accounting change and we will file an 8-K to reflect these adjustments to our fiscal 2009 Form 10-K in the next two weeks. Also, our first quarter 10-Q that we expect to file later today will summarize the effects of this accounting change on our previously reported September 30, 2009, financial statements. Early adoption of this authoritative guidance was not permitted. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: In summary, there were numerous pauses for the quarter, the most important of which include: We were profitable with a pretax income of $42.8 million in the quarter; we saw a 45% increase in our sales, with our ASP increasing both sequentially and year-ov
componenttext: In summary, there were numerous pauses for the quarter, the most important of which include: We were profitable with a pretax income of $42.8 million in the quarter; we saw a 45% increase in our sales, with our ASP increasing both sequentially and year-over-year; fully loaded homebuilding SG&A, which includes all corporate overhead, as a percentage of revenues, was 11.6%, up only $1.4 million or 1% on a 36% increase on homes closed; positive cash flow for the past 14 consecutive quarters, now totaling over $5.4 million. We continue to reduce our debt as reflected in our $173 million of repurchases in Q1. Our announced redemption of $95 million in senior notes due 2013 and $131 million of notes which matured in January, leaving us with only $85 million in remaining maturities in fiscal 2010.Lastly and most importantly, to answer some of our critics, it is clear we are selling homes at a profit while working our way through our own lot positions as evidenced by our 17.1% gross margin this quarter. There are still challenges in the homebuilding industry: Rising foreclosures, high inventory levels of available loans, high unemployment, tightening FHA lending standards and weak consumer confidence. However, new home inventory remains low, interest rates are favorable, housing affordability is near record highs and near-term demand should be boosted by the home buyer tax credit. We will continue our focus on providing affordable homes for the first-time buyer, controlling our cost, contracting for new communities with attractively-priced finished lots and maintaining our strong balance sheet. Again, we want to thank all of our DHI team members who continue to outperform all of our peers. We're especially proud of our sales team who significantly outsold all of our competition in the industry. DR and I have never been more proud of you. Keep up the great work. DHI is leading the industry into the housing recovery. This concludes our prepared remarks. And now, we'll host any questions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Joshua Pollard from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Joshua Pollard from Goldman Sachs.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Don, thanks for the clarity on the seasonal trends. I think it helps set investor expectations for the year and the quarters in context of your goal for profit. Could you take a moment and talk about the seasonality of gross profit margins in 2010 and pot
componenttext: Don, thanks for the clarity on the seasonal trends. I think it helps set investor expectations for the year and the quarters in context of your goal for profit. Could you take a moment and talk about the seasonality of gross profit margins in 2010 and potentially your expectations there?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, we're proud to start off the first quarter with a 17.1% gross margin. I believe as we move into second quarter, which we're currently in today, we should be able to maintain that margin into the second quarter and even into the third quarte
componenttext: Well, clearly, we're proud to start off the first quarter with a 17.1% gross margin. I believe as we move into second quarter, which we're currently in today, we should be able to maintain that margin into the second quarter and even into the third quarter. After the tax credit expires and July 1 starts, I would anticipate our gross margins to run off some in the fourth quarter, that's an unknown. As I say, come July 1, we're going to have a new housing environment. We're prepared to deal with whatever comes at us. And if the tax credit expires and there's not another one, then we'll deal with that just as we've dealt with everything else.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: When you talk the about gross profit margins, you mentioned about I think 150 basis points coming from some warranty reversals. Are your comments about second and third quarter having similar gross margins inclusive or exclusive of those factors?
componenttext: When you talk the about gross profit margins, you mentioned about I think 150 basis points coming from some warranty reversals. Are your comments about second and third quarter having similar gross margins inclusive or exclusive of those factors?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Bill. We would expect to have -- to be able to maintain our margin just inclusive of all of those factors, the change in warranty accruals, the change in capitalized interest and property taxes. Our normal occurring adjustment, sometimes there are
componenttext: This is Bill. We would expect to have -- to be able to maintain our margin just inclusive of all of those factors, the change in warranty accruals, the change in capitalized interest and property taxes. Our normal occurring adjustment, sometimes there are increases, sometimes there are decreases, but we expect to be able to maintain our margins for the next quarter or two in the range we reported this quarter.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Many of your competitors have talked about January being positive in particular on traffic and order levels. Are you seeing similar strength and could you maybe give as much detail as possible?
componenttext: Many of your competitors have talked about January being positive in particular on traffic and order levels. Are you seeing similar strength and could you maybe give as much detail as possible?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: We don't have final numbers yet. We do expect to show a positive year-over-year comparison in January, and part of it's seasonal, part of it is driven by the tax credit. We would typically expect to see stronger traffic beginning about now. We always look
componenttext: We don't have final numbers yet. We do expect to show a positive year-over-year comparison in January, and part of it's seasonal, part of it is driven by the tax credit. We would typically expect to see stronger traffic beginning about now. We always look at Super Bowl Sunday and the week before that, but we certainly would expect to see the stronger traffic, and we are seeing that in some of the reports that are coming in.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: And, Josh, we're not big believers in tracking traffic. What Don Horton and I are really focused on are tracking sales and notwithstanding the fact that our traffic counts maybe down or less. What we're really focused on is our conversion rate. And clearl
componenttext: And, Josh, we're not big believers in tracking traffic. What Don Horton and I are really focused on are tracking sales and notwithstanding the fact that our traffic counts maybe down or less. What we're really focused on is our conversion rate. And clearly, as the traffic has declined over the years, giving different months in the fiscal year, our goal is how do we convert the largest amount of traffic coming through our models at any one point in time.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Where is that conversion rate today?
componenttext: Where is that conversion rate today?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, what we track at the corporate office is net sales. I couldn't tell you the conversion rate. But we are seeing positive trends in our net sales in January.
componenttext: Actually, what we track at the corporate office is net sales. I couldn't tell you the conversion rate. But we are seeing positive trends in our net sales in January.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Megan McGrath from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Megan McGrath from Barclays Capital.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up actually on Josh's question around seasonality. When you talk about fourth quarter being potentially your most difficult quarter, and you just talked about that on margin, is that the expectation that you might have to start lowering
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up actually on Josh's question around seasonality. When you talk about fourth quarter being potentially your most difficult quarter, and you just talked about that on margin, is that the expectation that you might have to start lowering prices after the expiration of the tax credit? Or do you actually think that 4Q volumes could be lower than let's say 2Q, which would be pretty rare?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, we do believe that fourth quarter volumes will be less than the second quarter and the third quarter volumes just simply because we believe a number of sales, we don't know exactly how many, but we believe that the number of the sales are being
componenttext: Actually, we do believe that fourth quarter volumes will be less than the second quarter and the third quarter volumes just simply because we believe a number of sales, we don't know exactly how many, but we believe that the number of the sales are being driven by the tax credit. So to the extent that, that tax credit expires, clearly, I think that will adversely affect our sales in the fourth quarter. And relative to inventory, we're focusing on reducing our inventory post-March to comply with the expiration of the tax credit to the extent that there's more volume than we anticipate in the fourth quarter, we can ramp our inventory back up again.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: And then to get a little bit more color on your comments around impairment, given what you said around the potential -- that 2Q's going to be a little bit more difficult, 2Q's profitability and especially 4Q. Is that taking into account impairment should
componenttext: And then to get a little bit more color on your comments around impairment, given what you said around the potential -- that 2Q's going to be a little bit more difficult, 2Q's profitability and especially 4Q. Is that taking into account impairment should be automatically -- expect impairments to go up next quarter, given your comments around profitability? Or is that already taking that into the account?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: It's already taken into account. We expect, as long as volumes and margins stay at reasonable levels in Q2, we expect our impairments in Q2 to remain at a relatively low level. We will start getting a better read on where core demand is, where core margin
componenttext: It's already taken into account. We expect, as long as volumes and margins stay at reasonable levels in Q2, we expect our impairments in Q2 to remain at a relatively low level. We will start getting a better read on where core demand is, where core margins are post the tax credit at the end of April and then we will factor that into our impairment evaluations.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's reflective. That's one of the reasons why we choose to share with you our watch list. Because certainly, as our watch list continues to decline, we anticipate our impairments to continue to decline.
componenttext: I think that's reflective. That's one of the reasons why we choose to share with you our watch list. Because certainly, as our watch list continues to decline, we anticipate our impairments to continue to decline.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Oppenheim from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Oppenheim from Crédit Suisse.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can talk about the plans in terms of building specs and inventory. You guys have done a lot better in terms of the orders within fiscal 4Q and 1Q based on the specs that you had. How aggressive do you plan to be with specs in buildi
componenttext: I was wondering if you can talk about the plans in terms of building specs and inventory. You guys have done a lot better in terms of the orders within fiscal 4Q and 1Q based on the specs that you had. How aggressive do you plan to be with specs in building on 2Q and what does that mean as you think about cash flow for the second quarter given the likelihood of lower closing volume?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll take the first half and Stacey or Bill can take the second half. We believe we're properly positioned today with our inventory to meet the demand, i.e. the spec inventory to meet the demand that's going to be associated with the tax credit. Clearly,
componenttext: I'll take the first half and Stacey or Bill can take the second half. We believe we're properly positioned today with our inventory to meet the demand, i.e. the spec inventory to meet the demand that's going to be associated with the tax credit. Clearly, what we are doing currently is to the extent that we need to start additional specs to replace spec sales and those new spec units can turn and close by the expiration period, which is June 30, then we'll start additional specs. But basically, we're properly spec-ed today and it's only a replacement of specs as we need them to meet the 6/30 closing dates.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Cash flow for Q2, it will be positive. We are expecting a $350,000 to $2 million income tax receivable. So that's going to drive the cash flow from operations. In terms of whether it would be cash flow positive without that purely from an operational basi
componenttext: Cash flow for Q2, it will be positive. We are expecting a $350,000 to $2 million income tax receivable. So that's going to drive the cash flow from operations. In terms of whether it would be cash flow positive without that purely from an operational basis, part of that will depend on what we do choose to do with our inventory of homes under construction and that's going to be driven by the sales that we see over the next two months.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: And clearly, a driver of our cash flow is our closings volume. And as we've stated, we do expect to close fewer homes in our second quarter so that we will not have that driver of cash flow in the second quarter, then we expect it to increase again in the
componenttext: And clearly, a driver of our cash flow is our closings volume. And as we've stated, we do expect to close fewer homes in our second quarter so that we will not have that driver of cash flow in the second quarter, then we expect it to increase again in the third.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess I'm wondering, you talked about buying land. And with the cash position that you have, are you setting any goals in terms of what you'd like to acquire in fiscal 2010 in terms of the number of lots or dollars to invest?
componenttext: And I guess I'm wondering, you talked about buying land. And with the cash position that you have, are you setting any goals in terms of what you'd like to acquire in fiscal 2010 in terms of the number of lots or dollars to invest?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're focused really on contracting for lots on an option basis with as little earnest money as possible. We are in a position where we really don't want to buy very many lots all cash unless it's at a significantly reduced price. The bottom line is
componenttext: Well, we're focused really on contracting for lots on an option basis with as little earnest money as possible. We are in a position where we really don't want to buy very many lots all cash unless it's at a significantly reduced price. The bottom line is we're not anticipating, as I mentioned to you and earlier on the conference call, to spend very much on land development or land acquisition or even land development. What we're really focused on is contracting for option lots, as well as purchasing some finished lots on an all-cash basis if the yield is there.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: And the way we're managing our overall lot inventory is we are focused on our position of owned finished lots. Today, we own about 22,000 finished lots. That's a little more than a year supply. That's pretty good. We have 24,000 optioned lots, which the v
componenttext: And the way we're managing our overall lot inventory is we are focused on our position of owned finished lots. Today, we own about 22,000 finished lots. That's a little more than a year supply. That's pretty good. We have 24,000 optioned lots, which the vast majority of those are finished lots as well. So we have those in position in a flexible, low-risk position that we'll be able to bring into our own supply as need be. So we are focused really on our own finished lots position.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Josh Levin from Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Josh Levin from Citi.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: When you purchase lots during the quarter, what kind of assumptions were you making about absorption rate and home prices? Were you using absorption rates and home prices from the quarter?
componenttext: When you purchase lots during the quarter, what kind of assumptions were you making about absorption rate and home prices? Were you using absorption rates and home prices from the quarter?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Say your question one more time now.
componenttext: Say your question one more time now.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: So during the first quarter, when you purchased finished lots, obviously, when you were trying to calculate the price you're willing to pay, you had to make assumptions about absorption rates and home prices, going forward. Were you using absorption rates
componenttext: So during the first quarter, when you purchased finished lots, obviously, when you were trying to calculate the price you're willing to pay, you had to make assumptions about absorption rates and home prices, going forward. Were you using absorption rates and home prices from the first quarter when you made your decision about what price to pay for finished lots?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, especially on an all-cash basis. As again, most of our purchases were under option contracts, where were doing takedowns on a monthly or quarterly basis, most of them are quarterly basis. So yes, we're basing those purchases of those lots based upon
componenttext: Yes, especially on an all-cash basis. As again, most of our purchases were under option contracts, where were doing takedowns on a monthly or quarterly basis, most of them are quarterly basis. So yes, we're basing those purchases of those lots based upon the pricing and absorptions of Q1, to the extent that the pricing erodes into Q2 or Q3 or whenever our next takedown is. Obviously, the beautiful thing about the option contracts is it affords us the opportunity to go back and rework the price of those lots based upon what the absorption as well as of the sales price of the homes is.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: You got tremendous operating leverage on your SG&A during the quarter. I mean, your SG&A barely moved despite the uptick in orders. How much more operating leverage do you think there is? Will it be this significant going forward?
componenttext: You got tremendous operating leverage on your SG&A during the quarter. I mean, your SG&A barely moved despite the uptick in orders. How much more operating leverage do you think there is? Will it be this significant going forward?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I put this in the category of no good deeds will go unpunished. To answer your question, in this company, everyday, from the corporate level to the regional level, to the division level, SG&A is a constant focus in this company and it has been for the 26
componenttext: I put this in the category of no good deeds will go unpunished. To answer your question, in this company, everyday, from the corporate level to the regional level, to the division level, SG&A is a constant focus in this company and it has been for the 26 and a half years I've been here and has been ever since Don Horton came from Arkansas to Texas. And it probably it was when he was in Arkansas he started focusing on SG&A. So I don't know how much more leverage we have, but clearly, we are focused on trying to keep our SG&A at the current level or better. To the extent that we have fewer closings in Q2 that percentage could go up, but we have proven beyond any reasonable doubt over the last three years that we have been the most efficient operator in the industry with the lowest, all in, fully-loaded SG&A and we will continue to be so.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Goldberg at UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Goldberg at UBS.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: First question is actually about the change with the FHA that happened recently in terms of several funded concessions and how that's affecting the business, going from 6% to the 3% allowable concessions?
componenttext: First question is actually about the change with the FHA that happened recently in terms of several funded concessions and how that's affecting the business, going from 6% to the 3% allowable concessions?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Those rules are not in effect yet, David. They are proposed and I believe the timing for implementation is going to be sometime this summer. So it's hard to answer. If the incremental 3% closing cost is the deciding factor between when someone can buy a h
componenttext: Those rules are not in effect yet, David. They are proposed and I believe the timing for implementation is going to be sometime this summer. So it's hard to answer. If the incremental 3% closing cost is the deciding factor between when someone can buy a home, then they may have to save a little longer. I mean, it kind of comes back to the same thing that we were saying, when some of the loan products went away, you just have to plan a little longer, save a little longer to be able to get into a home.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: And as we said in our conference call, one of the things that we're looking at are all the different catalysts to our current sales. And to the extent that one or two of those catalysts expire or have been canceled, then its incumbent upon us as we have d
componenttext: And as we said in our conference call, one of the things that we're looking at are all the different catalysts to our current sales. And to the extent that one or two of those catalysts expire or have been canceled, then its incumbent upon us as we have done over the last three arduous years as I've said, to adjust our business model to deal with whatever the facts are at the time.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Follow-up question is on the competitive environment. When we look at the expiration of the credit that's coming, obviously, it seems to me that a lot of public and private builders that we're talking to are building more spec inventory at this time and t
componenttext: Follow-up question is on the competitive environment. When we look at the expiration of the credit that's coming, obviously, it seems to me that a lot of public and private builders that we're talking to are building more spec inventory at this time and trying to be a little bit more prepared in terms of having units that can close on time. And I'm wondering if you can talk about the competitive landscape, if you feel like that's the trend you're seeing from your competitors, and if you're worried about pricing in that kind of an environment.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Well it's always interesting when they come to the dance late, which it seems like that our competitors are coming to the dance late, and that's one of the reasons we think that our Q4 will be a tougher quarter for us than any other quarter, because clear
componenttext: Well it's always interesting when they come to the dance late, which it seems like that our competitors are coming to the dance late, and that's one of the reasons we think that our Q4 will be a tougher quarter for us than any other quarter, because clearly, we have the spec inventory today. I think some of our competitors are just beginning to increase their spec levels. And as a result, we could have additional excess new home capacity, our inventory in the fourth quarter and we'll have to deal with that as we see. Clearly, we're positioned and have been positioned during this entire downturn to meet the demand as generated by the tax credit. I believe we're in a preeminent position. We've got to finish inventory in a number of our communities. We have spec inventory that's coming on at various stages of construction. So again, I think that by virtue of the fact that the home has to be sold by April 30 and closed by June 30, some people better increase their inventory turns to meet the deadlines that are in place. So we feel very good and there will be competition bringing on additional inventory, but it's not nearly as competitive as where we are in terms of our cost and our pricing structure.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zener from Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zener from Macquarie.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: You had given some good details about the gross margin, the increase. You talked about the 300 basis points due to the cost being lower than the decline in sales there. And then you also said 15% of your closings were tied to new lots that were roughly 35
componenttext: You had given some good details about the gross margin, the increase. You talked about the 300 basis points due to the cost being lower than the decline in sales there. And then you also said 15% of your closings were tied to new lots that were roughly 350 points higher. I mean, 60 bps came from the new lots and kind of 250 bps from the overall cost structure. What led to that actual acceleration in this quarter as opposed to the prior quarter and did that surprise you?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: We've been preparing to report better gross profit margins. Our people have been working all this past year to reduce their cost, adjust their products and then adjust their pricing and incentive levels to the new product. And so really, it's the culminat
componenttext: We've been preparing to report better gross profit margins. Our people have been working all this past year to reduce their cost, adjust their products and then adjust their pricing and incentive levels to the new product. And so really, it's the culmination of the work over the past year. Our core margin showed dramatic improvement this quarter for several factors. First, we've done a lot of work on our cost. Secondly, there still is the effect of prior impairments, although the effect of impairments this quarter was actually less than it was in the fourth quarter. And as we have seen over the last several quarters, we have continued to work through our older specs, and so we had less of an impact from old completed specs moving through our closings this quarter. So really, all of those factors contributed to the improvement in our core margin.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: And please realize, we have been in an extraordinarily strong position over the last two to three quarters as we are one of the few builders starting in a significant inventory in any of our subdivisions. And typically, if you go subdivision by subdivisio
componenttext: And please realize, we have been in an extraordinarily strong position over the last two to three quarters as we are one of the few builders starting in a significant inventory in any of our subdivisions. And typically, if you go subdivision by subdivision, as Don Horton and I do, and we see the competing subdivisions across the streets from our existing subdivisions, we have started the most homes of anyone in the industry. So as a result, the subcontractors and the vendors are very excited about doing our work and they're very excited about pricing it competitively so we can continue to start more homes. We have been the lifeblood of a lot of our subcontractors and vendors.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Firm [ph] (52:23) cost, due pricing.
componenttext: Firm [ph] (52:23) cost, due pricing.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: And then I guess related to that, how do you expect over the next two quarters? I realize you're being appropriately cautious on the fourth quarter. But over the next two quarters, do you expect that 15% from new lots to go up? What do you expect it to go
componenttext: And then I guess related to that, how do you expect over the next two quarters? I realize you're being appropriately cautious on the fourth quarter. But over the next two quarters, do you expect that 15% from new lots to go up? What do you expect it to go to? And what are your current units under construction?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: I'll let Bill answer the second part of that question because he knows those numbers better than I. But I would say to you that we expect that for 15% to increase as we continue the attract more and more sellers to us, because one of the things that attra
componenttext: I'll let Bill answer the second part of that question because he knows those numbers better than I. But I would say to you that we expect that for 15% to increase as we continue the attract more and more sellers to us, because one of the things that attracts sellers to us is the fact that we are starting homes and we're carrying a higher spec inventory than most of our competitors. So we are a natural first-time buyer for lots compared to everybody else in the industry.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of our homes under construction, we have 11,500 total homes under construction, of which 1,100 of those are models. That's basically flat in total with where we were a quarter ago. We have 7,300 of those homes are spec this quarter. So we're prep
componenttext: In terms of our homes under construction, we have 11,500 total homes under construction, of which 1,100 of those are models. That's basically flat in total with where we were a quarter ago. We have 7,300 of those homes are spec this quarter. So we're prepared for the selling season with those specs. And just a bit more color in terms of visibility on where the new project percentages could go. During the first quarter, our sales in our new projects were 25% of our total sales. So we're seeing that increase coming down the line. And where it could go, that will be really the result of the work of our people and continuing to work and sign up new projects. But we will see the increase coming in for the quarters.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joel Locker from FBN Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joel Locker from FBN Securities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Feb-02-2010
