headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is in any of our markets where your concern either about the impact of rising foreclosed homes or the banks with shadow inventory, I'm sure you have comments on those.
componenttext: My first question is in any of our markets where your concern either about the impact of rising foreclosed homes or the banks with shadow inventory, I'm sure you have comments on those.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're dealing with foreclosures in every market. Some markets have some more than others clearly. Our goal as a company has been to price our new homes competitively with the foreclosure prices in each respective markets. So as a result, we can give
componenttext: Well, we're dealing with foreclosures in every market. Some markets have some more than others clearly. Our goal as a company has been to price our new homes competitively with the foreclosure prices in each respective markets. So as a result, we can give the buyer a compelling purchase with the new home for essentially of the same price that they can buy a foreclosure, and further smooth and more transparent process because as you know on the short sales and the foreclosures just because you want to buy one of them, doesn't mean you're going to be able do it in a short period of time.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Also, with a rising market and rising demand, this question probably isn't come up in some time, just about your supply chain. Any issues related to either labor or material cost?

componenttext: Well, clearly with the volume that we're doing in each one of our markets, our labor is not an issue at all. As a matter of fact we still have plenty of excess labor in most of our markets and our subs are really appreciating the opportunity to be able to grow their businesses again, and to build homes for us, as opposed to the other builders who are not building much inventory out there are sold not only labor out there but with the labor on a very compelling price simply because we are the most active builder, in virtually every one of our markets

componenttext: We will continue to hire sales people. And as one of our strengths in this company clearly is our quality of our sales force. But we continue to upgrade our sales force. So as a result, we're constantly looking for those people who are not outperforming or performance after our expectations so we constantly to upgrade our sales force. But currently, I think we have upgrade sales force in the industry.

componenttext: Now, clearly, we're entering into most of our contracts are in the East, Southeast and south Central Divisions, as parts of the country. So our focus has been across the country, whether you're in Chicago, whether you're in  Seattle that your focus as the division president is how do you secure option contracts so that we can continue to increase our market share in each one of our markets.

componenttext: And also, are you seeing any increase in potential deal flow from banks? Or is the land available still mostly from developers and other types of sellers.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: It's a combination of both, and we're beginning to see more deals from banks. It depends upon the part of the country. It seems like most of our deals were seeing from smaller and medium-sized financial as opposed to the larger institutions. And we expect
componenttext: It's a combination of both, and we're beginning to see more deals from banks. It depends upon the part of the country. It seems like most of our deals were seeing from smaller and medium-sized financial as opposed to the larger institutions. And we expect the larger institutions to begin to free up some of their OREO assets on a go forward basis because certainly there are a number of banks that would like to sell those assets. But mostly it's the small and medium-size regional banks that we're attracted to us. They know as well, and we're a proven entity in their backyard, and we're doing more construction than any other building in the marketplace. So we are a sought-after builder to help them work their ways to their OREO assets.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Our final question is from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan Securities.
componenttext: Our final question is from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan Securities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up with regard to your last comments about where you're more active in land contracts and you kind of thinking about that. And also the fact that you said you're seeing pricing across the country at this point, more being led by California
componenttext: Just to follow up with regard to your last comments about where you're more active in land contracts and you kind of thinking about that. And also the fact that you said you're seeing pricing across the country at this point, more being led by California and in the quarter, California kind of lagged some of the other regions in terms of order growth. So I was just wondering if you could talk about your level of activity in California right now in terms of land deals, and if that's lagging as well and what are your thoughts in terms of possibly stepping it up there or is it  just that the pricing on the land is getting a little bit away from you?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: I think California has been and always will be a difficult market to operate in. It's characterized by expensive lots and typically all cash transactions are certainly higher earnest money deposits than most other parts of the country. Clearly, we think C
componenttext: I think California has been and always will be a difficult market to operate in. It's characterized by expensive lots and typically all cash transactions are certainly higher earnest money deposits than most other parts of the country. Clearly, we think California is a very important state to us. Currently we're still operating, they're operating, we're operating California under the same criteria as we are the rest of the divisions in the country. So to the extent that Californians is more difficult to do business with for us with our current operating parameters, we may relax those some that were certainly focusing on where can we put our capital and get the best return and the quickest return on our capital.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Despite that, we feel like our operations in California are performing very well. Our West region net home sold this quarter increased 17% in our West region. So while that might not be inline with our overall increase, that's still a very solid increase
componenttext: Despite that, we feel like our operations in California are performing very well. Our West region net home sold this quarter increased 17% in our West region. So while that might not be inline with our overall increase, that's still a very solid increase in a challenging market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, that's all the time we have for question and answer. And at this time, I'd like to turn the floor over to Mr. Tomnitz for any closing comments.
componenttext: Thank you, ladies and gentlemen, that's all the time we have for question and answer. And at this time, I'd like to turn the floor over to Mr. Tomnitz for any closing comments.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Apr-30-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you for joining us today, and once again, I want to thank all the DHI team members who once again, we outperformed everyone else in the industry. And I want to make sure that our purchasing managers, our construction managers, our superintendents an
componenttext: Thank you for joining us today, and once again, I want to thank all the DHI team members who once again, we outperformed everyone else in the industry. And I want to make sure that our purchasing managers, our construction managers, our superintendents and our salespeople are all equally to be really thanked for outstanding performance. But we look forward to a great third quarter, and to continuing the lead the home building industry into the recovery and business model that we think is a superior in the industry. Thank you.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the D.R. Horton American (sic) [America's] Builder, the largest builder in the United States, Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Don Tomn
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the D.R. Horton American (sic) [America's] Builder, the largest builder in the United States, Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Mr. Don Tomnitz, President and CEO for D.R. Horton. Thank you, Mr. Tomnitz. You may now begin.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Joining me this morning are Bill Wheat, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Stacey Dwyer, Executive Vice President and Treasurer. As usual, before we get started, Stacey?
componenttext: Thank you, and good morning. Joining me this morning are Bill Wheat, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Stacey Dwyer, Executive Vice President and Treasurer. As usual, before we get started, Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Some comments made on this call may constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although D.R. Horton believes any such statements are based on reasonable assumptions, there is no assurance that
componenttext:
Some comments made on this call may constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although D.R. Horton believes any such statements are based on reasonable assumptions, there is no assurance that actual outcomes will not be materially different. All forward-looking statements are based upon information available to D.R. Horton on the date of this conference call, and D.R. Horton does not undertake any obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements. 
Additional information about issues that could lead to material changes in performance is contained in D.R. Horton's current report on Form 8-K dated February 8, 2010, which updated our annual report on Form 10-K and our most recent quarterly report on Form 10-Q, all of which are filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Stacey. We want to thank all of our DHI team members for generating an operating profit for the third consecutive quarter. Congratulations to each of you. You are successfully competing in a difficult housing market. We are three quarters of th
componenttext:
Thank you, Stacey. We want to thank all of our DHI team members for generating an operating profit for the third consecutive quarter. Congratulations to each of you. You are successfully competing in a difficult housing market. We are three quarters of the way through our goal of profitability in each and every quarter, but we still have a very challenging quarter in front of us. 
So far, this year has unfolded as we expected. We saw strong sales through April, and we just had our strongest third quarter homes closed in three years. We entered the year expecting the second half of the calendar year to be more challenging because of the pull-forward effect of the federal tax credit, combined with normal seasonality and a continued weak economy. Consequently, we began slowing our construction starts at the end of March quarter in anticipation of a drop-off in demand. We will continue to be realistic on our expectations, and we'll adjust our business to compete now and in the future. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our net income for the quarter was $50.5 million or $0.16 per diluted share compared to a net loss of $143.8 million or $0.45 per diluted share in the prior-year quarter. Homebuilding pretax income was $37.4 million, which included $30.3 million of invent
componenttext: Our net income for the quarter was $50.5 million or $0.16 per diluted share compared to a net loss of $143.8 million or $0.45 per diluted share in the prior-year quarter. Homebuilding pretax income was $37.4 million, which included $30.3 million of inventory impairments and land option charges, and an $8.3 million loss on early retirement of debt. Financial services pretax income was $8.9 million, which included $3.1 million of recourse expense. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our third quarter home sales revenues increased 54% to $1.4 billion on 6,805 homes closed from $896.6 million on 4,240 homes closed in the year-ago quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was down 4% to $202,500. The timing of our revenues and
componenttext: Our third quarter home sales revenues increased 54% to $1.4 billion on 6,805 homes closed from $896.6 million on 4,240 homes closed in the year-ago quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was down 4% to $202,500. The timing of our revenues and earnings so far this year have been driven by the timing of tax credits instead of normal seasonality, and we believe our operating strategy of having specs available to close by June 30 let us capture more of the available tax credit demand. While the September quarter would typically be our strongest for closing volume and profitability, our June quarter will be our strongest quarter in fiscal year 2010. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: As we expected, sales have slowed significantly after the April 30 deadline for signing a home purchase contract to qualify for the federal tax credit. As a result, net sales orders for the third quarter were down slightly, 3% from the prior year at 4,921
componenttext:
As we expected, sales have slowed significantly after the April 30 deadline for signing a home purchase contract to qualify for the federal tax credit. As a result, net sales orders for the third quarter were down slightly, 3% from the prior year at 4,921 homes. Our sales in April were extremely strong followed by a sharp decline in May, a 20% sequential increase in June and then an approximate 10% increase in July. 
As we look at our sales comps for the next three quarters, it will be difficult to achieve year-over-year increases since each of the quarter saw a strong sales volume, driven by the various tax credits in effect. While we remain focused on gaining market share for us to see significant sustainable sales growth, we need to see improvement in the overall economy, the jobs landscape and consumer confidence. 
In the June quarter, our average sales price on net sales orders in the quarter was essentially flat at $208,400. Our cancellation rate was 28%. Our active selling communities were up 7% sequentially. 39% of our net sales came from communities opened in fiscal year 2009 or later. Our sales backlog decreased 18% from the prior year to 4,430 homes or $954.4 million. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the third quarter was 17.2%, up 590 basis points from our home sales margin in the year-ago period and down 80 basis points sequentially from our March quarter. Our gross margins have been in the 17% to 18%
componenttext:
Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the third quarter was 17.2%, up 590 basis points from our home sales margin in the year-ago period and down 80 basis points sequentially from our March quarter. Our gross margins have been in the 17% to 18% range in each of the first three quarters this year, with some volatility within the range. Our core margin increased 50 basis points from Q2 to Q3 as the average cost of our homes declined by more than our average selling prices. This was more than offset by the sequential gross margin impact from typical changes and estimates for development and construction completion cost and warranty and litigation accruals, which are magnified when quarterly revenues fluctuate significantly as they have this year.
A contributing factor to our core margin improvement was that 35% of third quarter closings were from new deals that were put under contract in fiscal 2009 or later. Margins on closings in our new projects are approximately 200 to 300 basis points higher than on the remainder of our closings. Our goal is to maintain our gross margin in the 17% to 18% range or higher. However, if current market conditions persist, we could see margin pressure in future quarters. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: In our third quarter impairment analysis, we reviewed all projects in the company and determined that projects with a pre-impairment carrying value of $86.8 million were impaired, which resulted in $29.1 million of impairment charges. The majority of whic
componenttext:
In our third quarter impairment analysis, we reviewed all projects in the company and determined that projects with a pre-impairment carrying value of $86.8 million were impaired, which resulted in $29.1 million of impairment charges. The majority of which were in the Chicago land area. 
We've referred to our projects, which have indicators of potential impairment but were not impaired this quarter, as our watch list, which represents those projects deemed to be at the highest risk for future impairments. Our watch list is currently approximately $350 million, down from $525 million at March 31, with the largest concentrations in California, Illinois and Florida. $350 million is the lowest watch list balance we have reported during the downturn and about half of the sequential reduction resulted from the removal of projects that no longer needed to be on the watch list. 
Our inventory impairment process in future quarters will incorporate any changes in market conditions and any adjustments we make in our business. However, we continue to expect fewer impairments than we incurred in 2009 and previous years. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our consistent focus on controlling SG&A has been a key to our return to profitability. We have leveraged our SG&A structure to focus on profitable opportunities in our existing markets with our current division operations. Homebuilding SG&A expense for t
componenttext: Our consistent focus on controlling SG&A has been a key to our return to profitability. We have leveraged our SG&A structure to focus on profitable opportunities in our existing markets with our current division operations. Homebuilding SG&A expense for the quarter, which includes all corporate overhead, was $143.2 million or 10.4% of homebuilding revenues compared to 14.7% in the year-ago quarter. SG&A increased only $8.9 million or 7% on a 60% increase in homes closed. We will continue to actively manage our SG&A levels relative to our expected number of home closings. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We recorded $19.6 million in homebuilding interest expense during the quarter, which was approximately 47% of the $41.3 million of interest we incurred. We are required to directly expense a portion of our interest incurred while our homebuilding debt lev
componenttext: We recorded $19.6 million in homebuilding interest expense during the quarter, which was approximately 47% of the $41.3 million of interest we incurred. We are required to directly expense a portion of our interest incurred while our homebuilding debt level exceeds our active inventory. We recognized the loss of $8.3 million on the early retirement of $345 million, a principal amount of our senior notes during the June quarter. This charge primarily related to the premium paid for the debt and also includes the write-off of unamortized discounts and issuance costs. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Financial services pretax income for the quarter was $8.9 million compared to $2.8 million in the year-ago quarter. 93% of our mortgage company's business was captive during the quarter. Our company-wide capture rate was approximately 61%, our average FIC
componenttext: Financial services pretax income for the quarter was $8.9 million compared to $2.8 million in the year-ago quarter. 93% of our mortgage company's business was captive during the quarter. Our company-wide capture rate was approximately 61%, our average FICO score was 705, and our average combined loan to value was 92%. Our product mix in the quarter was essentially 100% agency eligible, with government loan accounting for 66% of our volume. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our total inventory decreased by approximately $169 million excluding non-cash impairment charges during the quarter. We reduced our homes in inventory by $220 million and increased our investment in residential and in lots and land held for development b
componenttext:
Our total inventory decreased by approximately $169 million excluding non-cash impairment charges during the quarter. We reduced our homes in inventory by $220 million and increased our investment in residential and in lots and land held for development by $51 million. Our homes in inventory at the end of June totaled 10,800 homes, down 22% from March, of which 1,200 were models, 6,100 homes were speculative and 3,100 of these specs were completed. We continue to manage our total homes in inventory relative to our expectations of sales demand, and we offer spec homes primarily to accommodate our first-time homebuyers, who represented 60% of the third quarter closings captured by our mortgage company. 
As we entered the second half of the calendar year, which is a slower selling season, we expect that our homes in inventory will decrease further in our September quarter. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our land and lot acquisition investments remained controlled, and they continue to evaluate our land development plans based on current sales trends. We have been actively contracting for finished lots to increase our active selling communities and increa
componenttext:
Our land and lot acquisition investments remained controlled, and they continue to evaluate our land development plans based on current sales trends. We have been actively contracting for finished lots to increase our active selling communities and increase our gross margins. 
In our third fiscal quarter, we invested approximately $228 million, primarily in finished lots. Our spending on finished lots will remain largely dependent on our sales pace, while our spending on land and development cost will continue to be at low levels. Our supply of owned land and lots at June 30, 2010, was approximately 89,200 lots, of which approximately 22,200 are finished. We control an additional of 27,300 lots through option contracts, up 24% from March 31, and our net earnest money deposit balance for these lots is only $10.6 million. We are focused on managing our supply of owned finished lots in line with our sales demand in a low-risk, capital-efficient manner. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Cash flow from operations for the June quarter totaled $159.3 million, primarily from earnings and the decrease of homes in inventory. This cash generation was offset by our spending on finished lots and development and an increase in our mortgage loans h
componenttext:
Cash flow from operations for the June quarter totaled $159.3 million, primarily from earnings and the decrease of homes in inventory. This cash generation was offset by our spending on finished lots and development and an increase in our mortgage loans held for sale. Our fiscal year-to-date cash flow from operations totaled $587.1 million. We ended the quarter with approximately $1.7 billion of homebuilding cash and marketable securities even after repurchasing $345 million of our outstanding notes in the open markets through reversed inquiries during the quarter. 
The balance of our public notes outstanding at June 30 was $2.2 billion. Our remaining note maturities now total only $63 million in fiscal 2010 and $205 million in fiscal 2011. After June 30, we repurchased an additional $53.3 million of our outstanding notes. Subsequent to those repurchases, our board has approved a $500 million debt repurchase authorization effective through July 31, 2011. As we mentioned on our press release, with these repurchases and the scheduled maturities in September, our retirement of debt for the fiscal year will total at least $1 billion. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: At June 30, our homebuilding leverage ratio, net of cash and marketable securities, was 17.5%, a 13.2 percentage-point improvement from a year ago. Gross homebuilding leverage at June 30 was 45.6%, an 8.6 percentage-point improvement from a year ago. This
componenttext: At June 30, our homebuilding leverage ratio, net of cash and marketable securities, was 17.5%, a 13.2 percentage-point improvement from a year ago. Gross homebuilding leverage at June 30 was 45.6%, an 8.6 percentage-point improvement from a year ago. This improvement in leverage is due primarily to our cash generation and reductions of outstanding debt. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: In summary, our financial performance this quarter demonstrates the progress of our company has made toward achieving profitability, balance sheet strength and market share gains in this challenging and uncertain housing market. Our most important accompl
componenttext:
In summary, our financial performance this quarter demonstrates the progress of our company has made toward achieving profitability, balance sheet strength and market share gains in this challenging and uncertain housing market. Our most important accomplishments this quarter include: pretax income totaling $46.3 million; home sales gross margins increased 590 basis points over the prior year, same quarter, as we continue to improve the cost and design of our products and continue to open new communities on recently acquired lots at higher margins; fully loaded SG&A, which again includes all corporate overhead as a percentage of revenues, was 10.4%, up only $9 million on a 60% increase in homes closed; $883.6 million in homebuilding debt repurchases and redemptions this fiscal year to date; and total principal payments on fiscal year 2010 will total more than $1 billion. 
There are still challenges in the homebuilding industry: rising foreclosures, significant existing home inventory, high unemployment, tight mortgage lending standards, the expiration of certain government support for the housing and mortgage markets and weak consumer confidence. However, new home inventory remains low, interest rates are favorable and housing affordability is near record highs. We will continue to focus on providing affordable homes for the first-time buyer, controlling our cost, contracting for new communities with attractive, priced-finished lots and maintaining our strong balance sheet. Consistent profitability at DHI is the ultimate goal.
D.R. and I celebrated our 28th anniversary in 12 days. In the 28 years we've been together, DHI is currently in the strongest position ever as evidenced by the strongest balance sheet in our history, a large national footprint with significant increasing penetrations in the majority of our markets and the best people in the industry. 
DHI is in a preeminent position to capitalize on the future of the homebuilding industry, whatever it may be. Again, we thank all of our DHI team members who continue to outsell and outperform the industry. Our third quarter is over. Now we need to focus intently on marching toward profitability in Q4. Keep up the great work. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. We'll host any questions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from Joshua Pollard with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is coming from Joshua Pollard with Goldman Sachs.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is on your comments on June and July, the 20% and 10% sequential increases there. I'm wondering if you feel like that is the performance you're seeing across your markets in these two months. And if not, where do you think you're taking
componenttext: My first question is on your comments on June and July, the 20% and 10% sequential increases there. I'm wondering if you feel like that is the performance you're seeing across your markets in these two months. And if not, where do you think you're taking share? Do you think it's from other smaller private builders? Or do you think it's coming from the Short Sale side and the existing home side?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll handle the second part of the question. Frankly, I believe that we're taking market share from both the small- and medium-sized builders who are under-financed, undercapitalized. But also, we continue to sell the largest percentage of new homes
componenttext: Well, I'll handle the second part of the question. Frankly, I believe that we're taking market share from both the small- and medium-sized builders who are under-financed, undercapitalized. But also, we continue to sell the largest percentage of new homes each quarter of all the public homebuilders. I think that's reflective clearly of our strategy of making spec homes available essentially to the first-time homebuyers and also the realtor community who sells a large percentage of our homes. So clearly, we are taking market share from the whole industry currently.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of across our company, we are seeing increases from May to June to July in each of our internal regions.
componenttext: And then in terms of across our company, we are seeing increases from May to June to July in each of our internal regions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: The quick follow-up to that is, what percent of your sales are coming from realtors this quarter? And maybe if you can compare it to a year ago. And then my sort of bigger follow-up is, if you look at the backlog burn rate, it's just been trailing right a
componenttext: The quick follow-up to that is, what percent of your sales are coming from realtors this quarter? And maybe if you can compare it to a year ago. And then my sort of bigger follow-up is, if you look at the backlog burn rate, it's just been trailing right around that 100% range. Is that something that you guys feel like you can keep up for a long time? Or is that a bit more of a phenomena of what's been going on with different tax credits?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I think the backlog turn will moderate back in the more historical ranges. We may be able to achieve something better than what we achieved before we went into the downturn simply because we are running with a little bit higher spec percentage because our
componenttext: I think the backlog turn will moderate back in the more historical ranges. We may be able to achieve something better than what we achieved before we went into the downturn simply because we are running with a little bit higher spec percentage because our first-time home buyer percentage is higher. But the 100%-plus conversion rates that you see in the last two quarters are not something that we would expect to sustain. In terms of realtors?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: On a historical basis, we have focused largely on the realtor community because as you know, advertising is a very small percent of our overall revenues, which is much lower than all the other builders. And frankly, we appreciate the realtors very much be
componenttext: On a historical basis, we have focused largely on the realtor community because as you know, advertising is a very small percent of our overall revenues, which is much lower than all the other builders. And frankly, we appreciate the realtors very much because they bring us a qualified buyer in most instances, and we can actually assign a success rate to that a lot easier than we can in advertising. And just a rough number, I would say that our realtor sales consistently average above 60%, and it depends upon clearly what kind of promotions we have going in various markets at various times. But again, the realtor community has been a big aid to Horton over its existence since 1978.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: First question, I was hoping if you could describe on the gross margin side if specs -- obviously, it's been a key part of your strategy going forward, but if you were -- with ending the quarter down sequentially in terms of your homes under construction,
componenttext: First question, I was hoping if you could describe on the gross margin side if specs -- obviously, it's been a key part of your strategy going forward, but if you were -- with ending the quarter down sequentially in terms of your homes under construction, and I believe your specs as well, did that play a role in some of the sequential falloff from 2Q to 3Q? And are you comfortable right now in terms of your specs in terms of what you have in inventory? I know you mentioned that you plan for further lower homes under construction in general, but would you say that, that sequential falloff was more due to more aggressive inventory work-down during the quarter?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: No, we really wouldn't, Mike. As Stacey mentioned during the call, our core margins in the quarter, which really represent the margins on the homes that closed, actually increased by 50 bps from Q2 to Q3. We do continue to see our historic, just differenc
componenttext: No, we really wouldn't, Mike. As Stacey mentioned during the call, our core margins in the quarter, which really represent the margins on the homes that closed, actually increased by 50 bps from Q2 to Q3. We do continue to see our historic, just difference of 200 to 300 basis points in margins between spec and build jobs, but that certainly did not weaken during the quarter.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, Bill, but when you say core margins, I mean, you had pre-impairments. It went from 18.0% to 17.2%, right?
componenttext: I'm sorry, Bill, but when you say core margins, I mean, you had pre-impairments. It went from 18.0% to 17.2%, right?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: The reported homes margin decreased 80 bps sequentially. Our core margins increased by 50 bps, and as Stacey referenced, that was offset by routine adjustments in estimates and accruals for development and construction completion cost and warranty and lit
componenttext: The reported homes margin decreased 80 bps sequentially. Our core margins increased by 50 bps, and as Stacey referenced, that was offset by routine adjustments in estimates and accruals for development and construction completion cost and warranty and litigation accruals. The impact on gross margin from Q2 to Q3 offset that. I can give you an example to describe what the type of adjustment like that would be. But really, it's driven by the fluctuation in revenues. We've seen significant volatility in our revenues from quarter-to-quarter. And so the same adjustment on an accrual and a low-volume quarter will have a much greater impact on margin than it will in a higher-volume quarter.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And if there's confusion on that, I certainly wish you'd follow up on it, because one of the things that we're very sensitive about, but also very proud of, is that our core margins on our homes closed did increase by 50 bps.
componenttext: And if there's confusion on that, I certainly wish you'd follow up on it, because one of the things that we're very sensitive about, but also very proud of, is that our core margins on our homes closed did increase by 50 bps.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: The second question, just in terms of the strength in orders and the rebound that you've seen a little bit sequentially, I was wondering -- and I know you don't break this out as much, but I think it's an important part of the story, I believe last quarte
componenttext: The second question, just in terms of the strength in orders and the rebound that you've seen a little bit sequentially, I was wondering -- and I know you don't break this out as much, but I think it's an important part of the story, I believe last quarter you had said that community count was up sequentially and year-over-year by -- it was either low- or mid-single digits, if I recall. I was wondering if you could give an update as to where you are there in terms of year-over-year and sequentially for 3Q, and how you're thinking about 2011 as well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our active selling communities were up about 7% sequentially from Q2 to Q3. On a year-over-year basis, they're up about 20%.
componenttext: Our active selling communities were up about 7% sequentially from Q2 to Q3. On a year-over-year basis, they're up about 20%.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And our goal for fiscal year '11 is to continue to increase our community count as we help investors, as well as developers, as well as banks work through their own lot positions.
componenttext: And our goal for fiscal year '11 is to continue to increase our community count as we help investors, as well as developers, as well as banks work through their own lot positions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Would you say for 2011, you're also looking for double-digit gain or...
componenttext: Would you say for 2011, you're also looking for double-digit gain or...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We're focusing on the gain. I don't want to get focused on a single- or double-digit increase, but we're certainly continuing to enter into new contracts on a daily basis in each one of our regions.
componenttext: We're focusing on the gain. I don't want to get focused on a single- or double-digit increase, but we're certainly continuing to enter into new contracts on a daily basis in each one of our regions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And a lot of it, whether it's a double-digit increase or a single-digit increase, will be dependent on the level of sales that we see in the market.
componenttext: And a lot of it, whether it's a double-digit increase or a single-digit increase, will be dependent on the level of sales that we see in the market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Josh Levin with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Josh Levin with Citigroup.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: You said that we could see some gross margin pressure if sales, I guess, don't pick up. So how do we think about that? I mean if sales continue to trend along these levels, do you start lowering prices or increasing incentives? Or would you wait for sales
componenttext: You said that we could see some gross margin pressure if sales, I guess, don't pick up. So how do we think about that? I mean if sales continue to trend along these levels, do you start lowering prices or increasing incentives? Or would you wait for sales to drop from here? Or what's the evolution of the pricing strategy over the next few months?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, each one of our divisions and each one of our regions have stated specific sales goals, and they adjust their incentives relative to the number of units we want them to sell and close. As we've said before, it doesn't make any sense to hold
componenttext: Well, clearly, each one of our divisions and each one of our regions have stated specific sales goals, and they adjust their incentives relative to the number of units we want them to sell and close. As we've said before, it doesn't make any sense to hold out for unrealistic gross margins if the market's not willing to pay you those margins. So as Stacey said on our conference call, our margins have really ranged between 17% and 18%. Our goal is to keep it between 17% and 18%. And I would say to you that we're going to make small adjustments as necessary to continue to hit the sales volumes and the closing volumes that we want to have as a company.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And you talked about sequential increases in orders in June and July. Was that driven primarily by increase in incentives over the prices? Or was it more of just a rebound after the tax credit dropped?
componenttext: And you talked about sequential increases in orders in June and July. Was that driven primarily by increase in incentives over the prices? Or was it more of just a rebound after the tax credit dropped?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I think a focus of two things. Really, a slight rebound. But secondly, we have focused on sales programs and sales contest in each one of our regions. And we just completed one in our South Region as of this weekend and had a very good sales over the week
componenttext: I think a focus of two things. Really, a slight rebound. But secondly, we have focused on sales programs and sales contest in each one of our regions. And we just completed one in our South Region as of this weekend and had a very good sales over the weekend. So as a result, one thing that Horton has not done a lot in the past in our history is had national and regional sales contest and sales incentives, and we are focusing on that to drive our sales and our volume and our closings in those regions where we want to drive it further.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Alex Barron with the Housing Research Center.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Alex Barron with the Housing Research Center.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask or get a little bit more insight into your impairments. I noticed you mentioned your watch list have been dropping significantly especially quarter-over-quarter, and I guess given the slowdown in the sales in the last few months, I'm tryin
componenttext: I wanted to ask or get a little bit more insight into your impairments. I noticed you mentioned your watch list have been dropping significantly especially quarter-over-quarter, and I guess given the slowdown in the sales in the last few months, I'm trying to, I guess, understand what are the drivers of the watch list coming down so significantly.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Alex, the biggest driver this year has been the improvement in our gross margin. As referenced this quarter, our margins were up 590 bps in Q3 versus a year ago. So as we're achieving better margins across the board, that has caused a significant reductio
componenttext: Alex, the biggest driver this year has been the improvement in our gross margin. As referenced this quarter, our margins were up 590 bps in Q3 versus a year ago. So as we're achieving better margins across the board, that has caused a significant reduction in our watch list. This quarter specifically, as we got past the tax credit and we're able to get a glimpse as to post tax credit demand, we were able to more closely evaluate some individual projects. And those projects that were performing better than we had assumed, when we put them on the watch list, we were able to remove some of those from the watch list. So it's a continual evaluation quarter-to-quarter, project by project. And when it no longer makes sense to be on the watch list, we take it off.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: My other question has to do, I guess, with kind of the absolute sales level or sales pace we've seen in the last few months. Now that the tax credit is gone, do you guys feel that that's just borrowing sales from the future? Or do you think it's something
componenttext: My other question has to do, I guess, with kind of the absolute sales level or sales pace we've seen in the last few months. Now that the tax credit is gone, do you guys feel that that's just borrowing sales from the future? Or do you think it's something more structural, where certain first-time buyers maybe just don't have the means to buy a home? And what are your general thoughts about the tax credit? Do you want it to come back? Or do you want it to stay off? Or have you heard anything about along those lines?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think clearly, the two tax credits have pull-forward demand. And now as we see, in July, we're getting back to a more normalized demand. We had a couple of months there where we're going through the pain and the process of getting off the tax cred
componenttext: Well, I think clearly, the two tax credits have pull-forward demand. And now as we see, in July, we're getting back to a more normalized demand. We had a couple of months there where we're going through the pain and the process of getting off the tax credits, so withdrawal from the federal tax credits. Frankly, I don't want the tax credits to be reenacted or be recreated or re-extended. We want to get back to a normalized market. It's a lot easier to run a business based upon designing your business with a current demand as opposed to having any kind of stimulus-es or incentives to create abnormal demand. I do believe that a lot of the first-time homebuyers are back in the market slowly but surely as they adapt to the changing guidelines for down payments and in mortgage underwriting. And one of our preeminent parts of our company is our  Home Buyers Club, who continually graduate people as they educate them on how to clean up their credit and become aware of the credit systems.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And the expiration of the tax credit really doesn't change the mortgage qualification or approval process. Those funds could not be used toward closing, at the time of closing toward closing costs, and they could not be considered in terms of the debt-to-
componenttext: And the expiration of the tax credit really doesn't change the mortgage qualification or approval process. Those funds could not be used toward closing, at the time of closing toward closing costs, and they could not be considered in terms of the debt-to-income levels for people's qualification process.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Timothy Jones with Moloney Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Timothy Jones with Moloney Securities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, what were your finished and total specs at homes under construction in March?
componenttext: First of all, what were your finished and total specs at homes under construction in March?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: 13,900 homes under construction at March 31. And of that, 7,300 were set; 2,900, completed.
componenttext: 13,900 homes under construction at March 31. And of that, 7,300 were set; 2,900, completed.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And how many models?
componenttext: And how many models?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: So you basically brought your spec inventory down, the total specs by 1,200 units. You said at that time that you expected it to dramatically reduce your specs, and I think you did a very good job in April. But I still think that probably, having only 200
componenttext: So you basically brought your spec inventory down, the total specs by 1,200 units. You said at that time that you expected it to dramatically reduce your specs, and I think you did a very good job in April. But I still think that probably, having only 200 less finished units and still having over 6,000 spec accounts for over half of your units under construction, it's still too high, given the market we're in right now. Would you like to comment on that?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly. We're bringing that down as we speak, and we've been bringing that down. And at September 30, we will tell you that it will be much lower than what it is today because we'll get our total inventory in line with pretty much what we expect
componenttext: Well, certainly. We're bringing that down as we speak, and we've been bringing that down. And at September 30, we will tell you that it will be much lower than what it is today because we'll get our total inventory in line with pretty much what we expect to close times two over the course of the next 12 months. And we'll have our specs running somewhere around 50% of our total inventory, which is where historically we've run.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And one of the things we're doing with our spec inventory in particular is we're trying to match that and keep the supply of homes out there for the first-time homebuyer. First-time homebuyers for us in this last quarter were 60%, and so we're doing a goo
componenttext: And one of the things we're doing with our spec inventory in particular is we're trying to match that and keep the supply of homes out there for the first-time homebuyer. First-time homebuyers for us in this last quarter were 60%, and so we're doing a good job of keeping those two numbers pretty close together.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: So we're in route to accomplishing your goal.
componenttext: So we're in route to accomplishing your goal.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then explain a little more about this core margin and the three things that have affected your gross margins by 80 basis points. It's actually more, 130 plus 50. Can you give a warranty and so forth, especially the land development, how is that flowin
componenttext: And then explain a little more about this core margin and the three things that have affected your gross margins by 80 basis points. It's actually more, 130 plus 50. Can you give a warranty and so forth, especially the land development, how is that flowing in?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Let me give you an example. Our core margins would increase by 50 basis points during the quarter. These other factors, which is the largest portion of this quarter, related to changes in estimates on development and construction completion co
componenttext: Absolutely. Let me give you an example. Our core margins would increase by 50 basis points during the quarter. These other factors, which is the largest portion of this quarter, related to changes in estimates on development and construction completion cost. All these other things offset that by 130 basis points.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Is that a nice way of saying cost overruns?
componenttext: Is that a nice way of saying cost overruns?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: No. Actually, no. It's actually the opposite. That's why I want to give you an example. What we see a lot of times when we wrap up a development project is we close out the project, and we have credits that may be available to us. Maybe for reimbursements
componenttext: No. Actually, no. It's actually the opposite. That's why I want to give you an example. What we see a lot of times when we wrap up a development project is we close out the project, and we have credits that may be available to us. Maybe for reimbursements of certain of our development cost from municipalities or other entities that we may see. And so those are actually positive, have a positive impact on margin. So in last quarter, Q2, we saw $7 million of those sorts of development credits come through as positive impact on margin. Last quarter, on the low revenue that we saw in Q2, that was a 75 basis-point improvement to margin, positive impact on margin. This...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: That was the second quarter, right?
componenttext: That was the second quarter, right?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: That was the second quarter, right. Now of course these credits have nothing to do with our quarterly closings volume. They just occur when we wrap up the projects. This quarter, development reimbursements, post-closing credits from developments, were aro
componenttext: That was the second quarter, right. Now of course these credits have nothing to do with our quarterly closings volume. They just occur when we wrap up the projects. This quarter, development reimbursements, post-closing credits from developments, were around $3 million. Of course, our homebuilding revenue was much higher this quarter. So that $3 million positive impact on this quarter's homebuilding revenue was about a 25 basis-point positive impact on margin. So the sequential difference between those two, 75 basis-point positive in Q2, 25 basis-point positive in Q3, that actually causes a sequential decline, a negative impact sequentially of 50 bps. It's a timing issue. It's timing, and those items have nothing to do with the actual closings volume and we've seen a lot more volatility in quarterly closings volume from quarter-to-quarter.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And the warranties, anything out of the normal goal there?
componenttext: And the warranties, anything out of the normal goal there?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: No. You see some of the same sort of things in terms of sequential changes based on the revenue volume, but the warranty litigation had a 20 bps negative sequential impact. The other biggest piece was also changes in estimates on our vertical construction
componenttext: No. You see some of the same sort of things in terms of sequential changes based on the revenue volume, but the warranty litigation had a 20 bps negative sequential impact. The other biggest piece was also changes in estimates on our vertical construction, and the sequential change there was 40 bps.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And how did that happen? Why did you change the bps?
componenttext: And how did that happen? Why did you change the bps?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it's the same sort of things. When we close out our homes and we have estimates of what is remaining to spend, we will leave those accruals out there. We will pay our bills. And at some point, there's a day of reckoning in terms of, do we need these
componenttext: Well, it's the same sort of things. When we close out our homes and we have estimates of what is remaining to spend, we will leave those accruals out there. We will pay our bills. And at some point, there's a day of reckoning in terms of, do we need these remaining accruals? So typically, there's some relief of that accrual several months after our homes close. And so that's typically a positive impact on margin. Last quarter, in Q2, that was a 70-basis-point benefit to margin. This quarter, it was a 30-basis-point benefit to margin. So sequentially, we lost 40 bps.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is coming from Stephen East with Ticonderoga Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question is coming from Stephen East with Ticonderoga Securities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: If you look at the gross margin in your backlog, your core gross margin in your backlog, or given how you all have been talking about specs and pricing and driving volumes, is there any deterioration in the backlog?
componenttext: If you look at the gross margin in your backlog, your core gross margin in your backlog, or given how you all have been talking about specs and pricing and driving volumes, is there any deterioration in the backlog?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Overall, it's hanging in pretty good, Stephen. We've been looking at our new projects and our old projects. Our new projects are hanging in above our threshold. We've actually been seeing continual improvement in our old projects as we continue to work do
componenttext: Overall, it's hanging in pretty good, Stephen. We've been looking at our new projects and our old projects. Our new projects are hanging in above our threshold. We've actually been seeing continual improvement in our old projects as we continue to work down the cost of our homes and adjust our product to the lower-priced affordable product. So we've seen improvement there. Our historic spread between spec and build jobs has stand about the same and overall improving versus what we were seeing a year ago. So overall I think we're continuing to make progress on our margins. Obviously, we don't know what the environment will be going forward. And we do expect us to going to continue to be a challenging environment, so we could see some pressure. But so far, we've been able to maintain margins pretty well in the last few quarters.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And I would say to you that in dealing with Rick Horton, our South Regional President, and we had a screaming home sale in Texas this past weekend, and we sold a number of homes, and the good thing that I heard from him yesterday late was that he thinks o
componenttext: And I would say to you that in dealing with Rick Horton, our South Regional President, and we had a screaming home sale in Texas this past weekend, and we sold a number of homes, and the good thing that I heard from him yesterday late was that he thinks our margins in his region stayed pretty much in the same range in all of his divisions as they were prior to the sales. So very good news to me.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: You all have done a great job in buying back your debt, and I wish other builders would do the same. But as you look at it, when do you have, at debt-level target, that you're trying to get to over the next year or two? And then if you look at qualifying
componenttext: You all have done a great job in buying back your debt, and I wish other builders would do the same. But as you look at it, when do you have, at debt-level target, that you're trying to get to over the next year or two? And then if you look at qualifying inventory, how close are you to your debt levels? And will we see interest expense?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Before Stacey answers that question, I'll tell you what the heart desire is. None. We have little ways to go to get them mobbed.
componenttext: Before Stacey answers that question, I'll tell you what the heart desire is. None. We have little ways to go to get them mobbed.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't know. I think we have a specific goal, Stephen. We're going to opportunistically continue to reduce our debt as long as that seems to be one of our best investment alternatives. If we could see a sharp recovery in the homebuilding industry that
componenttext: I wouldn't know. I think we have a specific goal, Stephen. We're going to opportunistically continue to reduce our debt as long as that seems to be one of our best investment alternatives. If we could see a sharp recovery in the homebuilding industry that may change our plans in terms of future debt reduction, we still have unscheduled maturities of just over $400 million coming due in the next three years. And so we're cognizant of that fact as well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And the qualifying inventory on it?
componenttext: And the qualifying inventory on it?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: The qualifying inventory right now, this quarter, we expensed 47% of our interest incurred. There are two factors, our debt is coming down. But depending on our sales level, our active inventory could come down as well. At a minimum, where we would expect
componenttext: The qualifying inventory right now, this quarter, we expensed 47% of our interest incurred. There are two factors, our debt is coming down. But depending on our sales level, our active inventory could come down as well. At a minimum, where we would expect our interest that we directly expense to continue to come down, it may not come down as a percentage of our incurred.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Dave Goldberg with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Dave Goldberg with UBS.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on the question on the watch list a little bit, and I understand that projects come off as the margin proves to be better than what you expected. But what I'm trying to understand a little bit better is how you think about pricing as
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on the question on the watch list a little bit, and I understand that projects come off as the margin proves to be better than what you expected. But what I'm trying to understand a little bit better is how you think about pricing as you kind of consider the watch list on a go-forward basis? Clearly, even though things improved in June and July, maybe things weren't as good as the last time you ran the analysis, and I'm just trying to get an idea of -- get some more detail maybe on how you think about sales pace and price when you think about putting the other on the watch list?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We try to be as realistic as we can with what we know at the time. Clearly, when were evaluating our projects during the tax credit time, we realized that the tax credit was driving some of our sales, driving some of the volume we were seeing. So we recog
componenttext: We try to be as realistic as we can with what we know at the time. Clearly, when were evaluating our projects during the tax credit time, we realized that the tax credit was driving some of our sales, driving some of the volume we were seeing. So we recognized and expected that there would be some decline in absorptions post the tax credit. So this certainly has not been a surprise really in any area of our business. But our assumptions, when we're looking at our projects, have typically assumed volumes either at or below current absorptions and typically pricing, at or below current pricing. So we try to be realistic, try to be conservative in our assumptions, but it is a project-by-project analysis, and we'll revisit again next quarter.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And frankly, we appreciate the questions about our watch list because I'm sure all of you appreciate that we do have a watch list, and we share it with you as opposed to our competitors.
componenttext: And frankly, we appreciate the questions about our watch list because I'm sure all of you appreciate that we do have a watch list, and we share it with you as opposed to our competitors.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Just to make sure I understand, is it fair to say that if conditions kind of stayed where they were at the end of July, and I realized maybe at the depressed base, it's not necessary if I can exactly what's happening there, some hangover, would the watch
componenttext: Just to make sure I understand, is it fair to say that if conditions kind of stayed where they were at the end of July, and I realized maybe at the depressed base, it's not necessary if I can exactly what's happening there, some hangover, would the watch list grow from where we are now if we just kind of stayed where we were?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: No, not necessarily. Again, it's project by project, but I would not expect it to change materially if things stay basically the same. As time moves on, those projects that perform a little better than we assumed may come off the watch list, those that pe
componenttext: No, not necessarily. Again, it's project by project, but I would not expect it to change materially if things stay basically the same. As time moves on, those projects that perform a little better than we assumed may come off the watch list, those that perform a little worst, may come on the watch list. So there'll be movement in and out. But overall, things stabilize from here. I wouldn't expect significant changes.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: One of the things helping our watch list quite frankly is our purchasing managers in the field who are doing a better and better job of buying our jobs. And we've frankly, as we, I think, explained on the last conference call, seeing noticeable improvemen
componenttext: One of the things helping our watch list quite frankly is our purchasing managers in the field who are doing a better and better job of buying our jobs. And we've frankly, as we, I think, explained on the last conference call, seeing noticeable improvements on our cost, our direct cost.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: That's the primary driver. Behind our margin improvement this year is our cost decreases.
componenttext: That's the primary driver. Behind our margin improvement this year is our cost decreases.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I know you guys talk about the realtors and realtors helping your sales. I'm just wondering kind of commission-wise, what you end up paying realtors versus internal sales people? And how negotiable that is on a go-forward basis? If existing home sales slo
componenttext: I know you guys talk about the realtors and realtors helping your sales. I'm just wondering kind of commission-wise, what you end up paying realtors versus internal sales people? And how negotiable that is on a go-forward basis? If existing home sales slow and maybe that's a good avenue for realtors to kind of look at?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our typical commission to an outside realtor would be around 3%. There are times when we will pay more for running a specific promotion, we may pay 4% or 5%. There are certain divisions that have a bonus structure. So if a realtor within a specified time
componenttext: Our typical commission to an outside realtor would be around 3%. There are times when we will pay more for running a specific promotion, we may pay 4% or 5%. There are certain divisions that have a bonus structure. So if a realtor within a specified time period sells three homes, then they would get a bonus of $500 per additional home that they close on top of the 3%. In terms of what you're seeing right into our cost of sales, it's really close to 3%. Internal sales commissions are starting a little bit differently. They're probably going to closer to 1.25% to 1.5%. And those are paid consistently on 100% of our homes that we closed.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Carl Reichardt with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Carl Reichardt with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I'm trying to get granular on this issue, but I just want to make sure, Bill, you can't take the development credits that you anticipate and amortize them over the life of the community on a per-house basis. It's got to be timed at the end, is that right?
componenttext: I'm trying to get granular on this issue, but I just want to make sure, Bill, you can't take the development credits that you anticipate and amortize them over the life of the community on a per-house basis. It's got to be timed at the end, is that right?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: No. In an ongoing project, if there's a change in estimate in an ongoing active project, then that would be spread over the entire project. What I was discussing earlier were primarily credits that we received after Aid, the project is complete. We do our
componenttext: No. In an ongoing project, if there's a change in estimate in an ongoing active project, then that would be spread over the entire project. What I was discussing earlier were primarily credits that we received after Aid, the project is complete. We do our best to try to estimate what those may be, what those reimbursements may be, but there's a lot of factors that go into what the ultimate reimbursements or credits may be. And so, once the project's done, we've closed all the homes. We own no more lots. Any adjustments post-closing, post closeout, do immediately come through the P&L.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Don, I'm curious about what you're seeing in the finished lot market. Some of your peers have talked about continued competition for finished lots, and is that up to what you own now where you have a 22,000 or so finished? Is it your sense especially if y
componenttext: Don, I'm curious about what you're seeing in the finished lot market. Some of your peers have talked about continued competition for finished lots, and is that up to what you own now where you have a 22,000 or so finished? Is it your sense especially if you think sales are going to slow and the contribution from new projects is only 200, 300 basis points up on the gross, that you may be much less aggressive at looking at finished lots over the next two to three quarters, which would be of course beneficial to your cash flow and your debt buyback?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: With the right price and the right terms, we're going to be very aggressive as we continue to replace some of our core performing option contracts. So I believe as we move forward, we'll continue to be in the preeminent position, simply because of the fac
componenttext: With the right price and the right terms, we're going to be very aggressive as we continue to replace some of our core performing option contracts. So I believe as we move forward, we'll continue to be in the preeminent position, simply because of the fact that our inventory strategy of building specs and making them available to those first-time homebuyers, places us in a strong position when we're dealing with sellers, whether they'd banks, investors or developers [indiscernible]. So I anticipate continuing to add new deals into 2011 as we mentioned earlier.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And the way we're approaching these new deals, the investment level is limited in each project. We don't own a lot at any point in time. So we're turning our cash very quickly on this deal. So right now, it's not been a significant drain on our overall ca
componenttext: And the way we're approaching these new deals, the investment level is limited in each project. We don't own a lot at any point in time. So we're turning our cash very quickly on this deal. So right now, it's not been a significant drain on our overall cash position simply because of the terms that we're trying to strike on our new deals.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Nishu Sood with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Nishu Sood with Deutsche Bank.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up with my first question about Carl was just asking about your land strategy. So sticking to, as you're talking about with Carl, mainly land spend on finished lots for quick turnaround. I wanted to ask specifically about challenges to
componenttext:
I wanted to follow up with my first question about Carl was just asking about your land strategy. So sticking to, as you're talking about with Carl, mainly land spend on finished lots for quick turnaround. I wanted to ask specifically about challenges to that, that might cause you to begin to look more upstream to land position that 
require more development. First thing was obviously some of the other builders have been talking about rising lot cost that are flowing through their income statement just because of how much more aggressive a lot of your competitors have become. Obviously, you're earlier than folks. And the other thing was just the scarcity of those finished lots. I mean, most of the markets that we looked at, it sounds like there's not that many opportunities left like that. So are either of those challenges creeping up? And so do you expect to begin to look at lesser developed deals?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Currently, given what we see as the demand's going forward, and we believe that the next 12 to 24 months will be challenging in the homebuilding industry, we have one focus right now, and that is if we invest a $1 in a piece of land or a lot. We want that
componenttext: Currently, given what we see as the demand's going forward, and we believe that the next 12 to 24 months will be challenging in the homebuilding industry, we have one focus right now, and that is if we invest a $1 in a piece of land or a lot. We want that $1 returned to us within 12 months, and that's our underwriting criteria today. Are we missing some deals out there? Yes, we are missing some deals out there. By our calculations, those competitors were losing those deals. Two are working for 15% gross margins and lot of the deals that they're closing in their inventory and their banking. And we don't understand that. And we don't want to try to understand that, but we're focused on continuing to produce some margin on our houses between 17% and 18% in getting back every dollar we put out to our divisions within 12 months, if it's on a piece of raw land, or whether it's on a finished lot. But our main focus is continuing to do low-earnest money, rolling option contracts with structured takedowns and limiting our spec inventory in those communities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: At the beginning of this fiscal year, you told us that you had a goal of achieving profitability for this fiscal year. And it looks like you're going to come through on that, which is certainly a nice achievement, given how tough things are out there., Bu
componenttext: At the beginning of this fiscal year, you told us that you had a goal of achieving profitability for this fiscal year. And it looks like you're going to come through on that, which is certainly a nice achievement, given how tough things are out there., But borrow one of my favorite phrases of yours, "No good deed shall go unpunished." So I have to ask you about 2011, what are your initial thoughts on that? Anything you're willing to give us on that?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I think 2011, as I said before, and 2012, both are going to be tough years in the homebuilding industry. As we mentioned on our conference call, I just don't see any sustainability of growth or profitability until we get some jobs created in this country,
componenttext: I think 2011, as I said before, and 2012, both are going to be tough years in the homebuilding industry. As we mentioned on our conference call, I just don't see any sustainability of growth or profitability until we get some jobs created in this country, until consumer confidence improves, and I don't see either one of those factors benefiting us in '11 and '12. What I will say is, is that we will structure this corporation's SG&A to meet the demand that's out there. As far as our fourth quarter's concerned, we're sitting today with about 4,400 homes in backlog. We think that places us in a decent position to have a decent shot at being profitable in Q4, but it's going to be a real challenge. Our goal is to continue to take market share.
