As I was in our purchasing managers meeting out in Las Vegas last week addressing over 90 vendors who came to Las Vegas, one of the things I told them was that we're focusing on market share. And at the end of the second quarter, we don't have the statistics yet, but we will have. DR Horton sold 25% of all the new homes at the end of our second quarter, sold by all the public homebuilders. So clearly, we're increasing our market share across the country. And we've plan on continuing to do that at the expense of the small, medium-sized and large builders.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Jonathan Ellis with BofA Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Jonathan Ellis with BofA Merrill Lynch.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: In any event, the first question I have is just on your cancellation rate. I noticed that it did pick up sequentially, and I'm just wondering was that a function of orders that, at least initially before the tax groups extended the expectation, that the h
componenttext: In any event, the first question I have is just on your cancellation rate. I noticed that it did pick up sequentially, and I'm just wondering was that a function of orders that, at least initially before the tax groups extended the expectation, that the homes wouldn't be completed by the end of June? Or anything else we should be sensitive to in terms of the sequential changing cancellations?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: No. As a matter of fact, what it was directly a function of is that we wrote every deal that we could write by April 30. And we knew our cancellation rate was going to increase, and I was surprised it only increased to 28%. But nevertheless, we wanted to
componenttext: No. As a matter of fact, what it was directly a function of is that we wrote every deal that we could write by April 30. And we knew our cancellation rate was going to increase, and I was surprised it only increased to 28%. But nevertheless, we wanted to get every buyer the opportunity to buy and close on our home. And so if they had a pulse and they were warm, we wrote them. And so as a result, we did have some cancellations because people couldn't qualify.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: You talked a little bit about some of the promotions in place, and I think you would, at least initially, the Eastern Region perhaps have been a little bit more proactive, and other regions have followed subsequently in terms of offering promotions. I gue
componenttext: You talked a little bit about some of the promotions in place, and I think you would, at least initially, the Eastern Region perhaps have been a little bit more proactive, and other regions have followed subsequently in terms of offering promotions. I guess the question is, if I look at the trends in the quarter, pricing on orders were down in the East on a year-over-year basis for orders more so than any other region, and most of them were actually up. Is that just because the East was more aggressive? Or was it because the promotions were just more effective, meaning that the customer base is more receptive to the promotions in the East than in any other parts of the country?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: You sort of had a pet peeve when I was in Stacey's office this morning sort of discussing with her why we get hit with the fact that if our ASPs, average sale price, goes down, that is a function of our incentives. When really, in the East specifically, i
componenttext: You sort of had a pet peeve when I was in Stacey's office this morning sort of discussing with her why we get hit with the fact that if our ASPs, average sale price, goes down, that is a function of our incentives. When really, in the East specifically, it's a function of our pricing and product offerings. And two of the things the company has done is, one, we've downsized our product significantly over the course of the past two years. Secondly, we've taken a lot of the amenities and upgrades out of the house, which also leads to a lower sales price. So if you look at those two factors in particular, that's one of the things that's bribing our ASPs lower as we continue to try to capture as big a percentage of the first-time homebuyers as we possibly can.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: So the mix was more of a factor in the East than in any other regions, is that fair to say?
componenttext: So the mix was more of a factor in the East than in any other regions, is that fair to say?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: It was function of the East building smaller and lower-priced homes, large project. And part of that is also that they have a greater number of new communities that have factored in, which are focused on the affordable products. So yes, their mix in affor
componenttext: It was function of the East building smaller and lower-priced homes, large project. And part of that is also that they have a greater number of new communities that have factored in, which are focused on the affordable products. So yes, their mix in affordable product has increased more than other regions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Megan McGrath with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Megan McGrath with Barclays Capital.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask a little bit of a follow-up to that. And could you give us any regional colors specifically on Texas. We've heard some mixing around the Texas market recently, but primarily focusing with that market is weakening a little bit or not gro
componenttext: Just wanted to ask a little bit of a follow-up to that. And could you give us any regional colors specifically on Texas. We've heard some mixing around the Texas market recently, but primarily focusing with that market is weakening a little bit or not growing as fast as other markets? So any commentary on Texas?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Boy, they are sure a lot of whiners out there among our competitors about Texas. I would have to say we're kicking a lot of tail in Texas, and we have some great operators in Texas. And I would say to you, in Houston, we've increased our market share dram
componenttext: Boy, they are sure a lot of whiners out there among our competitors about Texas. I would have to say we're kicking a lot of tail in Texas, and we have some great operators in Texas. And I would say to you, in Houston, we've increased our market share dramatically down there because we've got a great Division President, it's a great team down there. We continue to increase our market share in San Antonio. We continue to increase our market share in Austin and Killeen. And we also continue to increase our market share in the Dallas-Forth Worth area, which there was a report that came out recently which reflected that the DR Horton had started 3,200 homes, and the number two builder, with their five business names and operating entities in the Texas market, started less than a thousand homes. And so that's an incredible position for Horton to be in, to have well over 2/3 of the market in the Dallas-Forth Worth area, and we're continuing to penetrate our existing markets in Texas deeper and deeper and taking market share away from our competitors. Well, let them whine.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow-up to the conversation about the land market. Just want to ask, in general, do you feel as if the land market and the market for finished lots, or lots in general, has adjusted yet to the slowdown and pace that we've seen in the mar
componenttext: And then just a follow-up to the conversation about the land market. Just want to ask, in general, do you feel as if the land market and the market for finished lots, or lots in general, has adjusted yet to the slowdown and pace that we've seen in the market? Or are they lagging a little bit in getting sort of may be prices more in line to get you guys in...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Land sellers are always unrealistic, whether it be an upmarket or a down-market. And I would tell you that a lot of the land and even finished lot pricing that we're seeing today, is a function of the benefit of the tax credits over the last nine months.
componenttext: Land sellers are always unrealistic, whether it be an upmarket or a down-market. And I would tell you that a lot of the land and even finished lot pricing that we're seeing today, is a function of the benefit of the tax credits over the last nine months. And clearly, the demand associated with the tax credit is far higher than the demand is going to be without the tax credit. So I think the land sellers invest a major adjustments downward in their finished lot prices to be able to sell the lots, where we can market home at a current market price.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Do you have your deferred tax asset as of the end of the quarter?
componenttext: Do you have your deferred tax asset as of the end of the quarter?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me get that for you. We're at $879.2 million, which is still fully reserved by valuation allowance.
componenttext: Yes. Let me get that for you. We're at $879.2 million, which is still fully reserved by valuation allowance.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Oppenheim with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Oppenheim with Credit Suisse.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can talk a little bit about these trends in terms of the orders and such where you touched about the increase there in June and July. With July, where is the absorption relative to what you would likely to be in terms of your goal?
componenttext: I was wondering if you can talk a little bit about these trends in terms of the orders and such where you touched about the increase there in June and July. With July, where is the absorption relative to what you would likely to be in terms of your goal? Is that a satisfactory level for sales per community? Or do you think you need to still do more in terms of promotions and marketing in terms of trends, August, September?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: I will clearly say that our July sales are not where our goal is. And so as a result, we're going to continue to be aggressively marketing homes in all of our regions and all of our divisions. Our sales are slower than what we want them to be. They're not
componenttext: I will clearly say that our July sales are not where our goal is. And so as a result, we're going to continue to be aggressively marketing homes in all of our regions and all of our divisions. Our sales are slower than what we want them to be. They're not slower than we anticipated. We anticipated that post the tax credit that our sales would drop off further dramatically, and unfortunately, they did, but we're focused on a specific level of sales and closings, and we'll focus on that, and I'll achieve that --

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And then in the South, you talked about the ability to have the promotions and then generate strong sales without hurting margins there, certainly great to have customers respond without having to give anything away that way, but wondering how aggressive
componenttext: And then in the South, you talked about the ability to have the promotions and then generate strong sales without hurting margins there, certainly great to have customers respond without having to give anything away that way, but wondering how aggressive you would end up being in terms of trying to go up for the absorption?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Clearly our goal, as Stacey mentioned, is to keep our gross margins at the 17% to 18% range. As I mentioned earlier, our phenomenal sale this past weekend in the South Region, and specifically state of Texas, we held our margin very nicely during that sal
componenttext: Clearly our goal, as Stacey mentioned, is to keep our gross margins at the 17% to 18% range. As I mentioned earlier, our phenomenal sale this past weekend in the South Region, and specifically state of Texas, we held our margin very nicely during that sale. And we would anticipate, as we move forward, is to keep our margins between 17% and 18% unless there's a dramatic slowing of demand more than we're seeing today.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from George Bose with KBW.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from George Bose with KBW.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: This is Jade Rahmani for Bose George from KBW. I just wanted on your gross margin, can you quantify the direct impact to margin of, say, a 1% price decline? Are there possible offsets in lower materials or construction costs that you're currently seeing?
componenttext: This is Jade Rahmani for Bose George from KBW. I just wanted on your gross margin, can you quantify the direct impact to margin of, say, a 1% price decline? Are there possible offsets in lower materials or construction costs that you're currently seeing?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: We are continuing to see significant reductions, ongoing reductions in our construction cost. As you can see on a year-over-year basis, our average selling prices are still down slightly. But our margins are up significantly. So we have been successful in
componenttext: We are continuing to see significant reductions, ongoing reductions in our construction cost. As you can see on a year-over-year basis, our average selling prices are still down slightly. But our margins are up significantly. So we have been successful in offsetting those thus far. That's not guarantee going forward. It's something we'll continue to work on, but if we see, on an apples-to-apples, a house, a reduction in price of 1%, we're going to do the best to offset as much of it as we can. But I don't have a clear answer for you just in a theoretical case or exactly what we'd be able to accomplish.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: But rest assured that our vendors and our subcontractors are working very closely with us simply based on our volume. They clearly are interested in doing business with Horton in growing their business as we continue to grow our business. So we have ultim
componenttext: But rest assured that our vendors and our subcontractors are working very closely with us simply based on our volume. They clearly are interested in doing business with Horton in growing their business as we continue to grow our business. So we have ultimate cooperation from our vendors, which is tremendous based upon the trade show that we had in Las Vegas last week.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: On the first-time home buyer and tax credit-related sales, were those on average at lower prices? And can you give the percentage of May through July sales that are coming from first-time home buyers?
componenttext: On the first-time home buyer and tax credit-related sales, were those on average at lower prices? And can you give the percentage of May through July sales that are coming from first-time home buyers?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: For the quarter, first-time home buyers were representing 60% of the closings that our mortgage company handled for the company. On average, since we do have probably greater percentage of those being first-time home buyers, the average selling prices wou
componenttext: For the quarter, first-time home buyers were representing 60% of the closings that our mortgage company handled for the company. On average, since we do have probably greater percentage of those being first-time home buyers, the average selling prices would be lower on those homes. It doesn't mean margins are lower, but on average, the average selling prices are a bit lower when we have a higher home buyer, first-time home buyer percentage.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: And so then, the May through July sales were around 60% level?
componenttext: And so then, the May through July sales were around 60% level?

componenttext: May through July, we actually got our best indications when homes closed from our mortgage company. So I don't really have good color to give you on May through July.

componenttext: We only have closings through June. That's...

componenttextpreview: Thanks very much.
componenttext: Thanks very much.

componenttext: I've always said a month is not a trend. So basically, we refuse to do that over the year. It just simply because the quarter is really what we're focused on. April wasn't a trend, neither was May.

componenttext: I don't have any expectations of any of those people right now. So we're just focusing in reacting to the market and continue to grow our business back. Hopefully, we'll deal with the stable market relative to what the government's doing to Housing.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010

So we'll continue to adapt and adjust, but Don said that we don't have any specific expectations or goals for that conference.

componenttext: As far as the off-balance sheet DTAs that you guys have that you've taken evaluation allowance, now that you've been profitable a few quarters in a row and maybe going forward, do you have any visibility on when you will be able to start bringing those back on your book, and what that process might eventually look like?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: However, if we continue to generate profits on a quarter-to-quarter basis, and other builders do not, we will recognize it before them. Now going forward, it'll all depend on the level of profits that we generate and how consistent we are able to and our
componenttext: However, if we continue to generate profits on a quarter-to-quarter basis, and other builders do not, we will recognize it before them. Now going forward, it'll all depend on the level of profits that we generate and how consistent we are able to and our visibility into how well we can operate profitably in a post-tax credit environment. So this is our last quarter in which we'll be getting some profits from the tax credit. Next quarter, as Don has already said, it's going to be challenging to be profitable, but we believe it is achievable. And then to the extent that we're successful in adjusting our business to the environment for 2011, and we can continue profitability, then we can start having some serious discussions around when is the appropriate time to bring that back onto the balance sheet. As far as trying to nail a specific time, right now, I'm not going to do that. We don't know what the next quarter and next year are going to bring. But rest assured, as we get closer to that time, as we have better visibility, we will share that, we will disclose that in our 10-Q. We'll let you know what we're looking at, and then you'll start having better feel for the timing, but it's not going to be the next quarter or two.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010

componenttext: It would typically be in larger chunks, if not all, is the guidance that we hear. But that's on ongoing discussion as well. There's actually not a lot of precedent out there for companies who have taken full valuation allowances and then recover and actually get back to a point where they can bring it back on their balance sheets. So it's an emerging item and issue for the accounting firms to deal with as well.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Aug-03-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. We're very proud of the fact that our closings increased dramatically this last quarter. Our sales orders were only down slightly. And most importantly, our core margins continued to improve. I believe that, proved beyond the doubt, that DR Hor
componenttext:
Thank you. We're very proud of the fact that our closings increased dramatically this last quarter. Our sales orders were only down slightly. And most importantly, our core margins continued to improve. I believe that, proved beyond the doubt, that DR Horton strategy was correct and our business model, superior. 
I want to thank two people, our two groups of people. One, all of the DR Horton team members who continue to outperform everyone else in industry. And most importantly, our realtors who have been with us for many, many years, and I think enabled us to outsell everyone else in the industry. The realtors have been a great asset to DR Horton, and we appreciate all the buyers you bring us. 
Bottom line is, as we have finished the third quarter, and as I told all of our people earlier in the conference call we had, the third quarter's over, and now we need to march toward profitability in the fourth quarter. So thank you very much, and we appreciate everything you do for us.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the D.R. Horton America's Builder, the largest builder in the United States, 2010 fiscal Year-End Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Donald J. Tomnitz, Presi
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the D.R. Horton America's Builder, the largest builder in the United States, 2010 fiscal Year-End Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Donald J. Tomnitz, President and Chief Executive Officer for D.R. Horton. Thank you, Mr. Tomnitz. You may now begin.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Joining me this morning are Bill Wheat, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Stacey Dwyer, Executive Vice President and Treasurer. Before we get started, Stacey?
componenttext: Thank you, and good morning. Joining me this morning are Bill Wheat, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Stacey Dwyer, Executive Vice President and Treasurer. Before we get started, Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Some comments made on this call may constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although D.R. Horton believes any such statements are based on reasonable assumptions, there's no assurance that
componenttext:
Some comments made on this call may constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although D.R. Horton believes any such statements are based on reasonable assumptions, there's no assurance that actual outcomes will not be materially different. All forward-looking statements are based upon information available to D.R. Horton on the date of this conference call, and D.R. Horton does not undertake any obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statement.
Additional information about issues that could lead to material changes in performance is contained in D.R. Horton's current report on Form 8-K dated February 8, 2010, which updated our annual report on Form 10-K and our most recent quarterly report on Form 10-Q, all of which are filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Fiscal 2010 was a year of the tax credit. This calls volatile sales and closings, but the year was consistent with our expectations and preparations. While the federal tax credit was in place, we experienced strong sales demand through the April 30 sales
componenttext:
Fiscal 2010 was a year of the tax credit. This calls volatile sales and closings, but the year was consistent with our expectations and preparations. While the federal tax credit was in place, we experienced strong sales demand through the April 30 sales contract deadline, specially from first-time homebuyers. Our closings were strong through the June 30 closing deadline for the tax credit. However, after the tax credit expired, sales demand dropped sharply in May. From June through August, our sales trend showed sequential improvement, and then we began experiencing a normal, seasonal slowdown in September and October. 
Overall, housing demand is weak. Even with significant fluctuations in the level of demand for our homes in fiscal 2010, our approach was very consistent. Manager homes and inventory to current demand generate cash, reduce debt, position ourselves for profitability and maintain a strong balance sheet to be positioned to take advantage of opportunities.
As we look to fiscal 2011, we continue to be realistic in our expectations and will adjust our business to compete in the current market conditions. We expect another very challenging year for the homebuilding industry as a fundamental drivers of demand. The overall economy, job growth and consumer confidence are still very weak. In addition, we do not expect any stimulus in fiscal 2011 similar to the federal tax credits that were in effect last year. All of these factors make it likely that our sales and closing volumes will be below our volumes in fiscal 2010. 
However, we plan to continue to gain market share by opening new communities and adjusting our price points and product offerings due to demand we see in each of our individual markets. I want to congratulate each member of the D.R. Horton team for turning in a strong performance in fiscal 2010 despite continued difficult industry conditions. We appreciate very much your efforts. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our net loss for the quarter was $8.9 million or $0.03 per diluted share compared to a net loss of $234.9 million or $0.74 per diluted share in the prior year quarter. Homebuilding pretax loss were $6.5 million, which included $30.8 million of inventory i
componenttext: Our net loss for the quarter was $8.9 million or $0.03 per diluted share compared to a net loss of $234.9 million or $0.74 per diluted share in the prior year quarter. Homebuilding pretax loss were $6.5 million, which included $30.8 million of inventory impairments and lot option charges. Financial services pretax income was $4.8 million, which included $2.1 million of recourse expense. Our fourth quarter income tax provision was $7.2 million due primarily to an increase in our tax reserves. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our fourth quarter home sales revenue decreased 9% to $921 million on 4,281 homes closed from $1 billion on 4,810 homes closed in the year-ago quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was up 2% from the prior year and up 6% sequentially to $215,
componenttext: Our fourth quarter home sales revenue decreased 9% to $921 million on 4,281 homes closed from $1 billion on 4,810 homes closed in the year-ago quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was up 2% from the prior year and up 6% sequentially to $215,200. The sequential increase was primarily due to a higher percentage of our closings coming from the West region in the fourth quarter versus the third quarter. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Net sales orders for the fourth quarter were down 21% from last year to 3,979 homes. The net sales orders in the prior year quarter included demand from the first-time homebuyer tax credit that was in effect last year. Based on current sales demand and th
componenttext:
Net sales orders for the fourth quarter were down 21% from last year to 3,979 homes. The net sales orders in the prior year quarter included demand from the first-time homebuyer tax credit that was in effect last year. Based on current sales demand and the fact that the tax credits were supporting sales demand last year, we expect sales in the next two quarters to be lower than last year. 
While we remain focused on opening new communities and gaining market share for us to see significant sustainable sales growth, we need to see improvements in the overall economy, the jobs landscape and consumer confidence. In the September quarter, our average sales price on net sales orders was essentially flat year-over-year at $205,500. 
Our cancellation rate was 31%. Our active selling communities were up 6% sequentially. 49% of our net sales came from communities opened in fiscal year 2009 or later. Our sales backlog decreased 27% from the prior year to 4,128 homes or $850.8 million. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the fourth quarter was 17%, up 450 basis points from our home sales margin in the year-ago period. A contributing factor to our margin improvement from last year was at 39% of fourth quarter closings or fro
componenttext:
Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the fourth quarter was 17%, up 450 basis points from our home sales margin in the year-ago period. A contributing factor to our margin improvement from last year was at 39% of fourth quarter closings or from new deals that were under contract in fiscal 2009 or later. 
Margins on closings in our new projects are approximately 200 to 300 basis points higher than on the remainder of our closings. Our margin decreased 20 basis points sequentially from the third to the fourth quarter, reflecting a weaker housing market we have experienced during the second half of this year. Although our gross margins have been in the 17% to 18% range each quarter this fiscal year, we expect to experience gross margin pressure over the next few quarters, as we continually adjust to the prevailing market in each of our communities. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: In our fourth quarter impairment analysis, we reviewed all projects in the company and determined that projects with a pre-impairment carrying value of $63.1 million were impaired, which resulted in $29.1 million of impairment charges, the majority of whi
componenttext:
In our fourth quarter impairment analysis, we reviewed all projects in the company and determined that projects with a pre-impairment carrying value of $63.1 million were impaired, which resulted in $29.1 million of impairment charges, the majority of which were in Texas, Florida and Illinois.
We refer to our projects, which have indicators of potential impairment but were not impaired as our watch list, which represents those projects deemed to be at the highest risk for future impairments. Our watch list is currently $346.7 million, similar to the amount at June 30, 2010, with the largest concentrations in California, Illinois and Arizona. Our inventory impairment process in future quarters will incorporate any changes in market conditions and any adjustments we make in our business. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our consistent focus on controlling SG&A has been a key to our return to profitability. We have leveraged our SG&A structure to focus on profitable opportunities in our existing markets with our current division operation. For fiscal 2010, we closed 25% m
componenttext:
Our consistent focus on controlling SG&A has been a key to our return to profitability. We have leveraged our SG&A structure to focus on profitable opportunities in our existing markets with our current division operation. For fiscal 2010, we closed 25% more homes on essentially flat SG&A dollars compared to fiscal 2009. 
Homebuilding SG&A expense for the quarter, which includes all corporate overhead, was $121.8 million or 13.2% of homebuilding revenues compared to 13.3% in the year-ago quarter. Fourth quarter homebuilding SG&A expense was lower than recent quarters due in part to the impact of the $7.9 million reduction in our executive compensation accrual. We will continue to actively manage our SG&A levels relative to our expected number of homes closings. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we are required to directly expense a portion of our interest incurred while our homebuilding debt level exceeds our active inventory, we recorded $17.1 million in homebuilding interest expense during the quarter. This was approximately 47% of the $36.
componenttext:
As we are required to directly expense a portion of our interest incurred while our homebuilding debt level exceeds our active inventory, we recorded $17.1 million in homebuilding interest expense during the quarter. This was approximately 47% of the $36.3 million of homebuilding interest we incurred. 
Our fourth quarter homebuilding interest incurred decreased 31% compared to the prior year, and our homebuilding interest incurred for the entire fiscal year decreased 16% as a result of the debt reductions we achieved this year. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Financial services pretax income for the quarter was $4.8 million compared to a loss of $2.9 million in the year-ago quarter. 83% of our mortgage company's business was captured during the quarter. Our company-wide capture rate was approximately 60%, and
componenttext:
Financial services pretax income for the quarter was $4.8 million compared to a loss of $2.9 million in the year-ago quarter. 83% of our mortgage company's business was captured during the quarter. Our company-wide capture rate was approximately 60%, and our average FICO score was 719 and our average combined loan to value was 90%. 
Our product mix in the quarter was essentially 100% agency eligible with government loans accounting for 63% of our volume. For fiscal 2007 through fiscal 2010, we have recognized recourse expense totaling $94.8 million. Our fiscal 2010 recourse expense was $13.7 million, which is down from $33.2 million in fiscal 2009. The majority of the recourse expense in 2007 and early 2008 related to early payment default provision. Since then, the more significant portion of the recourse expense relates to misrepresentations by the borrower in the loan origination process. Cumulatively through September 30, 2010, we have settled approximately 1,500 mortgage claims, and we are currently evaluating less than 300 additional claims. 
While mortgage claim activity can be volatile from month to month, mortgage claims in the second half of fiscal 2010 declined approximately 23% compared to the first half of the year. Each quarter, we analyze recent trends and claim activity to evaluate reserves for potential future claim exposure. Our reserve balance has currently totaled $39 million with $10.8 million reserves for owned mortgages and foreclosed real estate and $28.2 million for pending and projected claims. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our total inventory decreased by approximately $87 million excluding non-cash impairment charges during the quarter. We reduced our homes in inventory by $129 million and increased our investment in residential land and lots and land held for development
componenttext:
Our total inventory decreased by approximately $87 million excluding non-cash impairment charges during the quarter. We reduced our homes in inventory by $129 million and increased our investment in residential land and lots and land held for development by $42 million. 
Our homes in inventory at the end of September totaled 9,500 homes, down 1,300 homes from June. 1,200 of our homes were models, 5,200 were speculative homes and 3,200 of these specs were completed. We continue to manage our total homes in inventory relative to our expectations of sales demand. We offer spec homes primarily to accommodate our first-time homebuyers and relocation homebuyers. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our land and lot purchases remain controlled, and we continue to evaluate our land development plans based on current sales trends. We have been actively contracting for finished lots to increase our active selling communities and increase our gross margi
componenttext:
Our land and lot purchases remain controlled, and we continue to evaluate our land development plans based on current sales trends. We have been actively contracting for finished lots to increase our active selling communities and increase our gross margins. 
In our fourth fiscal quarter, we invested approximately $188 million primarily in finished lots. Our spending on finished lots will remain largely dependent on our sales pace, while our spending on land and development cost will continue to be at relatively low levels. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our supply of owned land and lots at September 30, 2010, was approximately 90,000 lots, of which approximately 23,000 are finished. We control an additional 30,000 lots through option contracts, up 9% from June 30 with a net earnest money deposit balance
componenttext: Our supply of owned land and lots at September 30, 2010, was approximately 90,000 lots, of which approximately 23,000 are finished. We control an additional 30,000 lots through option contracts, up 9% from June 30 with a net earnest money deposit balance for these lots of only $13.3 million. We are focused on managing our supply of owned, finished lots in line with our sales demand in a low-risk capital efficient manner. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cash flow from operations for the September quarter totaled $122.3 million generated by the decrease in homes and inventory and mortgage loans held for sale, offset by our spending on finished lots and development and a decrease in our accounts payable. O
componenttext:
Cash flow from operations for the September quarter totaled $122.3 million generated by the decrease in homes and inventory and mortgage loans held for sale, offset by our spending on finished lots and development and a decrease in our accounts payable. Our fiscal year 2010 cash flow from operations totaled $709.4 million. 
We ended the fiscal year with $1.6 billion of homebuilding cash and marketable securities. The balance of our public notes outstanding at September 30, 2010, was $2.1 billion, and our note maturities in fiscal 2011 and 2012 are $189 million and $146.6 million, respectively. We retired over $1 billion of debt in fiscal 2010, and we have $483.8 million remaining on our debt repurchase authorization at September 30, 2010. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: At September 30, our homebuilding leverage ratio, net of cash and marketable securities, was 16.1%, a 16.4 percentage point improvement from year ago. Gross homebuilding leverage at September 30 was 44.3%, an 11.9 percentage point improvement from a year
componenttext: At September 30, our homebuilding leverage ratio, net of cash and marketable securities, was 16.1%, a 16.4 percentage point improvement from year ago. Gross homebuilding leverage at September 30 was 44.3%, an 11.9 percentage point improvement from a year ago. These leverage improvements compared to the prior year are due primarily to our cash generation and significant debt reductions. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: In summary, our financial performance this fiscal year demonstrates the progress DHI has made toward achieving profitability, balance sheet strength and market share gains in this challenging and uncertain housing market. Some of our most important acco
componenttext:
In summary, our financial performance this fiscal year demonstrates the progress DHI has made toward achieving profitability, balance sheet strength and market share gains in this challenging and uncertain housing market. 
Some of our most important accomplishments this year include: pretax income totaled $99.5 million; home sales gross margins increased 420 basis points over the prior year, as we improve the cost and design of our products and open new communities on recently acquired lots at higher margins; fully loaded homebuilding SG&A, which includes all of corporate overhead as a percentage of revenues was 12.1%, essentially flat in dollars with fiscal 2009 on a 25% increase at homes closed; cash flow from operations of $709.4 million, bringing our total over the last 17 consecutive quarters to $5.9 billion; over $1 billion in homebuilding debt repurchases and redemptions this fiscal year, contributing to our net homebuilding leverage ratio of 16.1%. There are still challenges in the homebuilding industry: rising foreclosures, significant existing home inventory, high unemployment, tight mortgage lending standards and weak consumer confidence. However, new home inventory remains low, interest rates are favorable and housing affordability is near record highs. 
We, at Horton, will continue to focus on providing affordable homes, controlling our cost, contracting for new communities with attractively priced finished lots and maintaining our strong balance sheet. Again, we want to thank all of our DHI team members to continue to outsell and outperform everyone in the industry. Keep up the great work. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. Now we'll host any questions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question I just had was on community growth. If you could give us a sense of where it was year-over-year for the quarter. And as you look into fiscal '11, we appreciate the comments with regards to expectation for sales and closings to be down.
componenttext: The first question I just had was on community growth. If you could give us a sense of where it was year-over-year for the quarter. And as you look into fiscal '11, we appreciate the comments with regards to expectation for sales and closings to be down. And obviously, you're facing a tough first half comp to say the least. But how do you look at community growth going into next year as obviously offsetting some of that comp and also maybe limiting incremental downside on gross margins to the extent that you still have a positive mix shift into next year as well?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll start and I'm sure Don will jump in in a moment. Our community count year-over-year in terms of exit selling communities was up 17%. Since we look forward into next year, we are continuing to try to fit new communities under option contracts primaril
componenttext: I'll start and I'm sure Don will jump in in a moment. Our community count year-over-year in terms of exit selling communities was up 17%. Since we look forward into next year, we are continuing to try to fit new communities under option contracts primarily rolling option on finished lots. And we would certainly anticipate continuing to increase our exit selling communities that will be offset by some of our current communities rolling off, and our pace of increase in the communities will be dependent on the sales demand that we see.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we think most all of our growth next year, Mike, will come from penetrating our existing markets deeper and taking market share from the other builders who are less, I think, proactive in the markets and more undercapitalized than we. We continue on e
componenttext: And we think most all of our growth next year, Mike, will come from penetrating our existing markets deeper and taking market share from the other builders who are less, I think, proactive in the markets and more undercapitalized than we. We continue on each and every one of our markets to work with the banks and work with the developers to auction lots, which are already finished, which we can put into construction immediately. And those lots are obviously at more favorable prices than many of the lots that we've had over the course of 2005 to 2008.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I appreciate that. So just to follow up just to drill down a little bit. So are you willing to give us a sense of what you think community count might grow next year? Do you think you can still hit this double-digit mark? And secondly, the gross margin
componenttext: So I appreciate that. So just to follow up just to drill down a little bit. So are you willing to give us a sense of what you think community count might grow next year? Do you think you can still hit this double-digit mark? And secondly, the gross margin impact or benefit, does that kind of offset to the extent that you can increase even your percent of closings from new communities? Or do you think that that positive mix shift has largely occurred given you're near 40% right now?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think clearly that our community count will grow just as it did. And our goal, clearly, is to hit double-digit community growth. Whether we do that or not is going to be really dependent upon what deals become available in each of our markets. One
componenttext: Well, I think clearly that our community count will grow just as it did. And our goal, clearly, is to hit double-digit community growth. Whether we do that or not is going to be really dependent upon what deals become available in each of our markets. One of the things that we've realized is in certain of our markets, we saw no opportunities or very few opportunities a year ago. And all of a sudden, we're beginning to see more and more communities. And simply, that's a reflection of the banks and the developers dealing with the current market conditions and being honest with themselves about what the real market price of those lots are. As far as the gross margin, I believe that our gross margins have some potential to come under pressure come this spring, irrespective of the fact that we continue to bring on new communities with higher gross margins, simply because we're not right now projecting a huge spring bump. It's uncertain on what's going to happen on the spring, and certainly other builders have brought on what we think are additional specs late in the market post the tax credit. And we believe that to the extent that there's not a significant spring bump, there could be some gross margin deterioration come spring.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And clearly, part of our strategy and continuing to add new communities at today's prices is to help mitigate that margin pressure. We still continue to see higher margins in the range of 200 to 300 basis points on our new communities. The communities tha
componenttext: And clearly, part of our strategy and continuing to add new communities at today's prices is to help mitigate that margin pressure. We still continue to see higher margins in the range of 200 to 300 basis points on our new communities. The communities that we contracted since 2009 are now almost half of our business. So that's becoming really a core part of our business. And so we will continue to do that to help offset the margin pressure that we're seeing in the market. But on the whole, we will not be surprised to see some pressure on margins in a downward fashion in the coming quarters.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And really, on conclusion on that, I'd like to say is that to the extent that Horton has been proactive earlier than any other builder in terms of securing these option contracts, we've proven beyond any reasonable doubt amongst the sellers, the banks as
componenttext: And really, on conclusion on that, I'd like to say is that to the extent that Horton has been proactive earlier than any other builder in terms of securing these option contracts, we've proven beyond any reasonable doubt amongst the sellers, the banks as well as the lot owners that one, we are there; and two, we are performing; and three, we are putting specs on their lots and working their way through their lots at a faster pace. So I believe as I travel through all these markets, as D.R. does, we are definitely the pre-eminent desired buyer of lots in each and every market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Megan McGrath with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Megan McGrath with Barclays Capital.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on that last conversation a little bit more in terms of your expectation for the spring. Clearly, not a lot of visibility yet, but is there a desire to exit these old communities faster, and that's where you think some of this pri
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on that last conversation a little bit more in terms of your expectation for the spring. Clearly, not a lot of visibility yet, but is there a desire to exit these old communities faster, and that's where you think some of this pricing pressure will come from? Or generally, do you just think across the board, you're going to have to make up for lower volume with across-the-board price cut even in some of these new communities?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great job on CNBC this morning. I thought you did a great presentation. Would we like exit our older communities faster? Yes, we've been focusing on that for quite some time. And obviously, the basis in those older communities doesn't afford us the opport
componenttext: Great job on CNBC this morning. I thought you did a great presentation. Would we like exit our older communities faster? Yes, we've been focusing on that for quite some time. And obviously, the basis in those older communities doesn't afford us the opportunity to exit those clearly as possible. But clearly, we're focusing on adding the new communities. And as Stacey said, we're 200 to 300 basis points higher in our gross margin on newer communities. And to the extent that we can continue to add those, yes, I think it will offset what we anticipate to be some margin compression come the spring, unless there's a stronger spring market than what we're anticipating right now. And with the job growth, where it is; consumer confidence, where it is, I just don't see a lot of hopes for a great spring market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: A little depressing. But stepping back a little bit, Rutherford 2011, can you maybe just give us an idea of any sort of corporate goals that you're willing to share whether profitability or what you're telling your sales folks in terms of what they should
componenttext: A little depressing. But stepping back a little bit, Rutherford 2011, can you maybe just give us an idea of any sort of corporate goals that you're willing to share whether profitability or what you're telling your sales folks in terms of what they should focus on for next fiscal year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. As I tell our salespeople as I travel around the country, if they're warm and have a pulse, write them, and then we'll create about qualifying them. But I think that we need to clearly take the buyers out of the market. We have the best pricing in th
componenttext: Yes. As I tell our salespeople as I travel around the country, if they're warm and have a pulse, write them, and then we'll create about qualifying them. But I think that we need to clearly take the buyers out of the market. We have the best pricing in the industry, the most speculative inventory that's available for immediate move in in the industry. So our focus on our salespeople is you write them, and then we'll figure out whether or not we can get them qualified. But most importantly, what this company has always focused on, Megan, and we continue to focus on everyday that we get up and that is, how do we consistently turn a profit in this company. So the sales is working, says nothing happens until we sell something. But the reality of life is we have to sell these houses at a profit, and our focus is clearly how do we consistently be profitable in this corporation.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Josh Levin with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Josh Levin with Citi.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Given your looking to be a fairly weak outlook for 2011, are you exploring more significant SG&A cuts in the quarters ahead? I'm not talking about just trimming fast but really trying to cut bone again.
componenttext: Given your looking to be a fairly weak outlook for 2011, are you exploring more significant SG&A cuts in the quarters ahead? I'm not talking about just trimming fast but really trying to cut bone again.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's get back to the bleak outlook. I think what we're telling you is what we see out there based upon the current economic conditions, but don't get confused. We have been, and we currently are, the best-positioned builder from an SG&A perspective, a le
componenttext: Let's get back to the bleak outlook. I think what we're telling you is what we see out there based upon the current economic conditions, but don't get confused. We have been, and we currently are, the best-positioned builder from an SG&A perspective, a leverage perspective, shareholders' equity perspective to continue to deal better with the existing market, whatever maybe relative to our competition. As far as SG&A cuts, yes, we have already identified with our regional presidents additional SG&A cuts to the extent that the sales do not materialize in accordance with our five-year plan for fiscal year '11. So, yes, I think those SG&A cuts will be more difficult than what they've been in the past, but we definitely have identified additional cuts that need to be made if the sales do not materialize.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're talking about sales being kind of flattish, not seeing a bump. You're talking about margin pressure, some margins compressing, but your impairment watch list didn't really go up. How do we reconcile all those facts? I mean...
componenttext: You're talking about sales being kind of flattish, not seeing a bump. You're talking about margin pressure, some margins compressing, but your impairment watch list didn't really go up. How do we reconcile all those facts? I mean...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it really comes down to -- what we're really dealing with is our current margins are still about 17%. And so we haven't seen a significant reduction in our margins yet. We do expect some pressure. And so we certainly did add some projects to the lis
componenttext: Well, it really comes down to -- what we're really dealing with is our current margins are still about 17%. And so we haven't seen a significant reduction in our margins yet. We do expect some pressure. And so we certainly did add some projects to the list this quarter. But at the same time, we did impair a number of projects this quarter as well. So on a net basis, the list did not increase this quarter, but that's something we will continue to evaluate each quarter as we move into fiscal 2011. And by the way, Josh, that's an important point. We're sitting with a 17% gross margin. Most of our competitors would be very happy to be facing what may be a bleak outlook in the spring with a 17% gross margin versus what they have.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Goldberg with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Goldberg with UBS.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question I have is, Don, I think you gave some great detail on some of the issues that are facing demand pool. But I'm wondering if you could talk about timing. I don't want to say wank them both. What I'm trying to get to is the problem to mark
componenttext: The first question I have is, Don, I think you gave some great detail on some of the issues that are facing demand pool. But I'm wondering if you could talk about timing. I don't want to say wank them both. What I'm trying to get to is the problem to market today is there's just a lot of buyers that might want to buy a house but can't qualify that they don't have a down payment or they don't have a FICO score? So how would you weigh the ability to qualify for a loan even with 1.25% 30-year fixed rate mortgages and only 3.5% down payments relative to selling my confidence in terms of what's inhibiting demand today?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say our biggest problem is not quantifying our buyers. The biggest problem right now is consumer confidence and the number of unemployed people out there. As we always say, it's hard to sell a home to an unemployed person. But the real key is that
componenttext: I would say our biggest problem is not quantifying our buyers. The biggest problem right now is consumer confidence and the number of unemployed people out there. As we always say, it's hard to sell a home to an unemployed person. But the real key is that the traffic count and our subdivisions is down, and I don't think there's a lot of pricing adjustment that we can do. It's just a function on the lack of traffic. So until there's some consumer confidence, until we start to grow jobs, I think we're going to continue to be faced with rather flat demand just simply because buyers don't feel confident about the future, and they're not going out there looking for a house and the numbers that they were certainly when the tax credits were there.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: But they're going to pull potential buyers. I mean, if people who can qualify could if they wanted to buy a home.
componenttext: But they're going to pull potential buyers. I mean, if people who can qualify could if they wanted to buy a home.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there's a huge pool of buyers out there. But again, and that pool, is less than what it was a year ago with unemployment where it is and the lack of job growth. But again, those people don't have the confidence to purchase today is going to be rew
componenttext: I think there's a huge pool of buyers out there. But again, and that pool, is less than what it was a year ago with unemployment where it is and the lack of job growth. But again, those people don't have the confidence to purchase today is going to be rewarding. Although I will tell you that as I have keep telling people and I've been an example of this myself, I don't think there's ever been a better time in the history, my history in the homebuilding industry, with affordability and pricing where it is today to buy a home. And if you think that we're going to have inflation in this country, which I don't know how we can not have with all the money we're printing, hard assets like a home are going to be the very best investment that you can make.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just for a follow up, Stacey, the comment that you made on claims, I'm wondering if we could focus, not on the mortgage-backed side, but just on the warranty side. Is it correct to say you haven't really seen the pickup pick up in claims on a war
componenttext: And then just for a follow up, Stacey, the comment that you made on claims, I'm wondering if we could focus, not on the mortgage-backed side, but just on the warranty side. Is it correct to say you haven't really seen the pickup pick up in claims on a warranty side that maybe some of your peers have talked about this quarter or over the last couple of quarters?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: That would be a fair statement. We have not seen anything and currently unusual in our warranty claims. We'll have full disclosure around our warranty reserves in our 10-K, but I think you'll see or count our typical role forward of our royalty claim.
componenttext: That would be a fair statement. We have not seen anything and currently unusual in our warranty claims. We'll have full disclosure around our warranty reserves in our 10-K, but I think you'll see or count our typical role forward of our royalty claim.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just overall, we do have a litigation reserve and have four for years. The gross estimated liability in terms of our actuarially determined litigation reserve is $571.3 million. Offset against that, we have an estimated interest receivable of $251.5 m
componenttext: And just overall, we do have a litigation reserve and have four for years. The gross estimated liability in terms of our actuarially determined litigation reserve is $571.3 million. Offset against that, we have an estimated interest receivable of $251.5 million. So our net reserve is $319.8 million. The year-over-year change in that net reserve has increased about $20 million, primarily just due to adding our estimates for the closings that occurred this year and then offset by anything that rolled off of the tale or any claims that were settled during the year. That's something we evaluate on a quarter-to-quarter basis and adjust as we need to, but we haven't seen any major changes in the activity. We've been very proactive on that in the history of the company. And again, I don't think we get credit for the conservative nature of our balance sheet, but we have been very conservative in all of our accruals, so I think we're well prepared for whatever the warranty claims are in a go-forward basis.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jade Rahmani with KBW.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jade Rahmani with KBW.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to ask on mortgage repurchase. Can you provide any insight on how you're looking at the risk efforts future purchase request? It sounds like you do. The risk gets fairly low specially given your recent provision experience. Why do you think yo
componenttext: I just want to ask on mortgage repurchase. Can you provide any insight on how you're looking at the risk efforts future purchase request? It sounds like you do. The risk gets fairly low specially given your recent provision experience. Why do you think you haven't seen more of an increase in repurchase request given what the banks are seeing? Is it the nature of the new home product or because the mortgages originated were all purchase loans and didn't include refi activity? Or is it something else?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, there's probably several reasons. I think there actually has been a lower experience on new home mortgage originations, and there have been on existing homes. Part of it is because there's less refinance activity. So we haven't had people taking a lot
componenttext: No, there's probably several reasons. I think there actually has been a lower experience on new home mortgage originations, and there have been on existing homes. Part of it is because there's less refinance activity. So we haven't had people taking a lot of equity out based on large depreciation in home prices in certain markets where the home prices have adjusted back down as much. Beyond that, our provisions are based on a complete analysis of the loans that we have originated, the types of those that we have originated, the put back experience we've had on each type of loan and you're just -- well, I'm talking about in the comps post script with the decrease in mortgages put back to us a 23% in the second half of the year versus the first half of the year. That's indicating that we're seeing fewer requests in a time when this is a headline. And one thing I would point out's we've been recording recourse expense for four years. This isn't a new issue. I know it's kind of new in terms of the headline essentially, but we've been practically dealing with it through our mortgage company.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Joshua Pollard with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Joshua Pollard with Goldman Sachs.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is a pretty simple one. Do you guys expect to be profitable in 2011?
componenttext: My first question is a pretty simple one. Do you guys expect to be profitable in 2011?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do, and I will tell you that it's going to be a greater challenge than it was in 2010 simply because, as we mentioned to you, our sales and closing volumes will be -- we anticipate to be less, unless we have some significant spring sales bumps tha
componenttext: Yes, we do, and I will tell you that it's going to be a greater challenge than it was in 2010 simply because, as we mentioned to you, our sales and closing volumes will be -- we anticipate to be less, unless we have some significant spring sales bumps that we are having a hard time seeing today. So, yes, that's our goal. But again, it's going to be a larger challenge than it was last year in 2010.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if I understand everything that you're saying right, it will be fewer deliveries, lighter gross margin. You guys are looking to hold the line at least from a percentage basis on SG&A. Is there anywhere else that we should be expecting you guys to gene
componenttext: And if I understand everything that you're saying right, it will be fewer deliveries, lighter gross margin. You guys are looking to hold the line at least from a percentage basis on SG&A. Is there anywhere else that we should be expecting you guys to generate profits? Are you guys looking to do anything different in your business. You've had a number of your competitors getting to ancillary pieces about the rest of internal commercial market? I'm wondering if any of those things are interesting to you at this stage.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, frankly, we know one thing, we're a homebuilder, and what we're focusing on is the homebuilding operation and to the extent that financial services supplements that, the financial service side of the business. I don't see any significant opportuniti
componenttext: Well, frankly, we know one thing, we're a homebuilder, and what we're focusing on is the homebuilding operation and to the extent that financial services supplements that, the financial service side of the business. I don't see any significant opportunities out there that are going to enhance our performance other than continuing to execute on building, selling, closing homes and making money as I call it BSCM. That's our focus and really largely our sole focus at this point. And I think that our revenues and our closings, we do expect them to be down some based upon the tax credits not being with us. But I also believe that on the SG&A side, we're going to continue to look for opportunities to improve our SG&A. That's going to be more challenging, but this company has always come to the forefront in terms of dealing with whatever the market conditions are, and that's where we'll be.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And one other contributing factor, Josh, will be on our interest expense. We have continued to reduce our debt, dramatically reduced by about $1 billion this year. So our interest incurred has been coming down sharply. That will continue to flow through,
componenttext: And one other contributing factor, Josh, will be on our interest expense. We have continued to reduce our debt, dramatically reduced by about $1 billion this year. So our interest incurred has been coming down sharply. That will continue to flow through, and we'll see continued reductions in our direct interest expense. We see less interest capitalized in our inventory today than we did a year ago given our reduction in debt. So that is some offset, some mitigating factor to the margin pressure we expect to see in the marketplace. So both of those factors on the interest will contribute to some incremental improvement. And hopefully, it helps to offset the market conditions we expect to see.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I don't mean to be redundant, Josh. But once again, I think that a lot of companies would love to be in our position of having a 17% gross margin to deal with the future.
componenttext: And I don't mean to be redundant, Josh. But once again, I think that a lot of companies would love to be in our position of having a 17% gross margin to deal with the future.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as you the made that comment about your reversed gross margin, could you just talk very quickly about the difference between your margins on spec versus third sales? I mean, we're hearing a lot of different numbers across the industry. I would love
componenttext: Well, as you the made that comment about your reversed gross margin, could you just talk very quickly about the difference between your margins on spec versus third sales? I mean, we're hearing a lot of different numbers across the industry. I would love to hear where you guys stand now, and where do you think it could be if specs continue to make up a large portion of your sales.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our margins on our specs are typically lower than our margins on our build jobs. But, yes, at the same time, we know two things. One, by having specs, it satisfies the buyer who needs to be a relocation buyer or a first-time home buyer, who can all
componenttext: Well, our margins on our specs are typically lower than our margins on our build jobs. But, yes, at the same time, we know two things. One, by having specs, it satisfies the buyer who needs to be a relocation buyer or a first-time home buyer, who can all of a sudden qualify because they've gotten their credits right now or they're ready to move out of an apartment or out of their parents' home. The other thing we know about specs to own our focus in the company is that to the extent that a spec is 90 days older, it's 90 days past completion, we need to move that spec as quickly as possible because the profits on those specs have a tendency to decline the older they become.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's really a matter of focusing on managing them carefully, and that's something we've been doing for a long time. That's part of our business. And while there are lower margins on the spec versus build jobs, I think you can look at an overall margin and
componenttext: It's really a matter of focusing on managing them carefully, and that's something we've been doing for a long time. That's part of our business. And while there are lower margins on the spec versus build jobs, I think you can look at an overall margin and see that we are managing it reasonably well. There's always room for improvement, but that's something we're always focused on.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And to be specific, as we've always said, specs are a part of our business and is a part of our business model, and that's why we've been so affected by it over the years.
componenttext: And to be specific, as we've always said, specs are a part of our business and is a part of our business model, and that's why we've been so affected by it over the years.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Zener with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Zener with KeyBanc.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to get a little more granularity. Obviously, you guys have been aggressive on the debt pay-down to lower your interest expense. If you were to look at simply the homebuilding operation, do you expect that business to be profitable, realizing t
componenttext: I just want to get a little more granularity. Obviously, you guys have been aggressive on the debt pay-down to lower your interest expense. If you were to look at simply the homebuilding operation, do you expect that business to be profitable, realizing there's a couple leverage that could affect the EPS relative to the interest expense and impairments?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, we expect the Homebuilding business to be profitable, and that's our focus, that's what our business plans call for. And then as we move to the fiscal year quarter-by-quarter, we'll see how successful we are at executing what our business plan
componenttext: Absolutely, we expect the Homebuilding business to be profitable, and that's our focus, that's what our business plans call for. And then as we move to the fiscal year quarter-by-quarter, we'll see how successful we are at executing what our business plan is. But, yes, we get up everyday, starting to shave and put our makeup on, and our goal is to be profitable in the homebuilding side of our business.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, I guess, related to the differential of new communities purchase post in '09 or later, that 200 to 300 basis points seems to be lower than what we might hear from other builders. Could you comment on, is that a function of where you initially un
componenttext: And then, I guess, related to the differential of new communities purchase post in '09 or later, that 200 to 300 basis points seems to be lower than what we might hear from other builders. Could you comment on, is that a function of where you initially underwrote it at a tighter range? Did it come in? And I guess kind of related to the first question on profitably, do you think your DTA could come back next year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the new communities, we've been consistently saying 200 to 300 basis points for two years. And we started doing our new communities almost two years ago and have a significant history of closings on those communities and has become a significant portio
componenttext: On the new communities, we've been consistently saying 200 to 300 basis points for two years. And we started doing our new communities almost two years ago and have a significant history of closings on those communities and has become a significant portion of our business. So we're confident that that's a good level. Certainly, some do better than that. Some may be a little lower than that, but that's our average. And so I'm confident in our history, and I will see over time whether other builders' new communities contributed a similar level or better.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think that point is we do have a track record on our older communities, our new communities, I should say. And the other builders are just now beginning to enter into a lot of new deals or some new deals. So I think we certainly have a better t
componenttext: Yes, and I think that point is we do have a track record on our older communities, our new communities, I should say. And the other builders are just now beginning to enter into a lot of new deals or some new deals. So I think we certainly have a better track record in our 200 to 300 basis points is probably a lot more accurate than you're receiving from some.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And other thing I'd say on our existing communities is they're not static either, and we continue to renegotiate the costs, redesign the product, do everything we can to bring the costs down on those and improve the margins on those. At the same time, we'
componenttext: And other thing I'd say on our existing communities is they're not static either, and we continue to renegotiate the costs, redesign the product, do everything we can to bring the costs down on those and improve the margins on those. At the same time, we're layering in the higher margins from the options, and that's all reflected in our 17% to 18% margin that we've been running this year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: So clearly, if our margins improved by 400 basis points versus last year, that did not come from new communities. Our existing communities improved their margins as well. So while the gap may be to only 200 to 300, both levels are rising. I think you also
componenttext: So clearly, if our margins improved by 400 basis points versus last year, that did not come from new communities. Our existing communities improved their margins as well.
