So while the gap may be to only 200 to 300, both levels are rising. I think you also asked about the DTA for tax asset. It's a little over $900 million. Right now, the analysis of whether and when that might come on will be solely dependent, largely dependent on our profitability. The ability for us to have sustained substantial profitability and our expectations for forward profitability. So that will be dependent on our ability to execute on our goal and our plan to be profitable in fiscal 2011. And we'll be evaluating that as we move through the year. We can't say anything definitive about that right now until we show a consistent profitable record.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Oppenheim with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Oppenheim with Crédit Suisse.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can just talk about your thoughts on community count. You've said that the community count will be dependent on the market and the sales, others trying to bring on new communities to effectively offset the tougher conditions. Is you
componenttext: I was wondering if you can just talk about your thoughts on community count. You've said that the community count will be dependent on the market and the sales, others trying to bring on new communities to effectively offset the tougher conditions. Is your thought that there's effectively too much supply out there as it is, and why deal with that? Can you just talk about your thoughts there?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not really, Dan. I'd tell you what it mainly surrounds is the willingness of the sellers, whether they be banks or developers, to write their lots down to current market conditions. And we've had a lot of institutions, who have been unwilling to park thei
componenttext: Not really, Dan. I'd tell you what it mainly surrounds is the willingness of the sellers, whether they be banks or developers, to write their lots down to current market conditions. And we've had a lot of institutions, who have been unwilling to park their lots to the price that really is the market price. So it's more of getting a log jam undone and many lenders relative to our ability to bring on those new communities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's already been a focus for us. It's up to 49% of our sales this quarter, and we'll continue to focus on it as far as incremental increase. But we're clearly just as focused on it because it's important to our business going forward.
componenttext: It's already been a focus for us. It's up to 49% of our sales this quarter, and we'll continue to focus on it as far as incremental increase. But we're clearly just as focused on it because it's important to our business going forward.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a function, too, in our division presence, in our regional presence and our land that people spend a lot of time with banks. And the first time you go in to discuss with the bank a foreclosed asset, they're typically in denial or they don't have the
componenttext: It's a function, too, in our division presence, in our regional presence and our land that people spend a lot of time with banks. And the first time you go in to discuss with the bank a foreclosed asset, they're typically in denial or they don't have the capital that they want to use to write down the loan to get the lots of the market price. So it takes a while, sometimes it takes a year before they are willing to deal with it. And at that point in time, as I said earlier, without a doubt, based upon our performance over the last couple of years in these foreclosed communities, we are the pre-imminent buyer in the marketplace today.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, just wondering, you're talking about the specs, and you've done a great job in the past in the terms of managing the specs and delivering the order growth of observing margin. Your comments in terms of the weaker demand, while still goi
componenttext: And then secondly, just wondering, you're talking about the specs, and you've done a great job in the past in the terms of managing the specs and delivering the order growth of observing margin. Your comments in terms of the weaker demand, while still going after buyers' pulse, is this especially you're not going after too much in terms of demand right now? I think there's too much worry in terms of having margins here. What's your thought there?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, we continually adjust our specs, as well as our inventory, relative to the demand that we see on a go-forward basis. So clearly, we have been reducing our unit inventory. We've been reducing our specs. Because as we said earlier, we expect our s
componenttext: Actually, we continually adjust our specs, as well as our inventory, relative to the demand that we see on a go-forward basis. So clearly, we have been reducing our unit inventory. We've been reducing our specs. Because as we said earlier, we expect our sales and closings to be less in 2011 than they were in 2010. So clearly, we're adjusting that inventory in accordance with what we think's going to happen is. As Don Horton said, one thing we can do is we can start them quickly, and we can get them built quickly. So to the extent that the demand exceeds where our current inventory level is, which is based upon what a lower number than perhaps what could be out there next year, we're well prepared to meet the demand because we can build them quickly.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you like our inventory levels, we're sufficient to meet our expectations right now.
componenttext: If you like our inventory levels, we're sufficient to meet our expectations right now.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jonathan Ellis with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jonathan Ellis with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: First question, just on what happened this quarter and then sort of looking forward with respect to pricing and use of incentives, I appreciate the commentary on the effect of mix benefited pricing this quarter. But I guess, as you think through the gross
componenttext: First question, just on what happened this quarter and then sort of looking forward with respect to pricing and use of incentives, I appreciate the commentary on the effect of mix benefited pricing this quarter. But I guess, as you think through the gross margin pressures to come and recognizing that pricing in your orders was fairly stable quarter-over-quarter, is it possible that more of the incentives could be coming below the price line in a form of closing costs or free options or upgrades that would impact margin with the price. So basically, the question is, could you see a scenario play out where pricing hold fairly stable over the next few quarters, where margins may come under pressure?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly, that's our goal is to hold pricing stable in all of our communities. And to the extent that we need to incentivize our homes to be sold at a faster pace, we like to do that below the line as opposed to above the line.
componenttext: Certainly, that's our goal is to hold pricing stable in all of our communities. And to the extent that we need to incentivize our homes to be sold at a faster pace, we like to do that below the line as opposed to above the line.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: So you think as of right now, you're feeling fairly comfortable you should be able to achieve that over the next few quarters?
componenttext: So you think as of right now, you're feeling fairly comfortable you should be able to achieve that over the next few quarters?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that let's back up...
componenttext: Yes, I think that let's back up...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are going to be two things that impact our average sales price. One would be just absolute pricing pressure, which, as Don said, our first response to that is going to be to offer additional incentives because we do want to try to hold on to our bas
componenttext: There are going to be two things that impact our average sales price. One would be just absolute pricing pressure, which, as Don said, our first response to that is going to be to offer additional incentives because we do want to try to hold on to our base pricing. The other thing that we're continuing to do then is we're opening new communities with lower cost. And that is letting us continue to offer new product and lower prices than in some of the current communities that we have open. So you could see some change in our pricing going forward as a combination of those two factors.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And also if you look at our stick-and-brick cost this quarter, we are down 320 bps on stick and brick. And one of the things that we've done over the last two years consistently is continue to drive down those stick-and-brick cost. I just came at Southeas
componenttext: And also if you look at our stick-and-brick cost this quarter, we are down 320 bps on stick and brick. And one of the things that we've done over the last two years consistently is continue to drive down those stick-and-brick cost. I just came at Southeast Florida, where we had a vendor meeting with our Southeast Florida division. And we had that Southwest Florida, we have a number of communities, and I will tell you we were frank with our vendors. We appreciated them having cooperated with us over the last couple of years. But to the extent of the market softer on a go-forward basis, we're going to be expecting better pricing and more concessions from our vendors because we're all in this together. We're trying to get to the point where we all can achieve profitability, but the only way we can do that is to continue to meet the market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the second question, if you could offer up any guidance for what you think percentage of deliveries or closings next year will be from recently purchased lots. And then a related question, I've heard you talk about the 200 to 300 basis points mar
componenttext: And then the second question, if you could offer up any guidance for what you think percentage of deliveries or closings next year will be from recently purchased lots. And then a related question, I've heard you talk about the 200 to 300 basis points margin, right, for at least the last few quarters. I guess given your commentary about some of your competitors perhaps putting more spec inventory to the market and potential challenges in the spring selling season and next year, I guess, why are you still comfortable or confident that you can maintain that margin spread over your legacy communities? Why would you not see just as much pricing pressure perhaps or if more in newer communities that may narrow that spread?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, one thing that we're going to continue to do is to continue to add new communities at current market pricing. So to the extent that the market get softer, we're going to be negotiating better finished lot prices. Also, we consistently renegotiate ou
componenttext: Well, one thing that we're going to continue to do is to continue to add new communities at current market pricing. So to the extent that the market get softer, we're going to be negotiating better finished lot prices. Also, we consistently renegotiate our existing rolling option contracts. And that's one of the beauties of a rolling option contract is we don't own the lots, someone else owns them. And to the extent our gross margins get compressed before we do the next take down, we're back renegotiating the lot price downward. And I'm personally approving all of the lot contract and all the renegotiations. So I can tell you, we see a lot of renegotiated contracts there. Additionally, I would say to you that we are going to put pressure on our vendors, and they've supported us throughout the years. And especially, since we're such a significant portion of every market, our vendors are very focused on additional business. And as we continue to aggregate market share in each one of our divisions, then we are going to be able to get price concessions from them. Just as an example, I just noticed the other day that we got something that' of a Las Vegas, where we are the largest builder in Las Vegas with 14.2% of the market share. I was in Southeast Florida, where a year ago, we had five communities. We're going to have 20 communities by the end of this calendar year and 25 communities by midyear next year. In Southwest Florida, we had seven two years ago and now, we have 34 communities. So if anyone has the opportunity to continue to put pricing pressure on the land sellers and the lot sellers and the vendors, someone is doing the volume in those markets to the extent that we are.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one distinction, the 200 to 300 basis points spread between newer communities and legacy communities is simply the spread in their margins. Competitive market pressures affect both new communities and legacy communities. So both of them, if they're u
componenttext: Just one distinction, the 200 to 300 basis points spread between newer communities and legacy communities is simply the spread in their margins. Competitive market pressures affect both new communities and legacy communities. So both of them, if they're under pressure, would move in the same direction, but we would still expect the spread to be better on our newer communities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And with option contracts, if we see significant price movement, we still have the opportunities to go back and renegotiate those lot costs.
componenttext: And with option contracts, if we see significant price movement, we still have the opportunities to go back and renegotiate those lot costs.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you have a guidance or percentage of deliveries or closings from recently purchased land for '11?
componenttext: Do you have a guidance or percentage of deliveries or closings from recently purchased land for '11?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our recent sales in the most recent quarter were up to 49% of our business. We expect that to continue to grow. It's now become a core part of our business, will continue to be a core part of our business, and so we expect that to continue to grow.
componenttext: Our recent sales in the most recent quarter were up to 49% of our business. We expect that to continue to grow. It's now become a core part of our business, will continue to be a core part of our business, and so we expect that to continue to grow.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Nishu Sood with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Nishu Sood with Deutsche Bank.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to come back to this December outlook that is surprising a lot of people, I suppose. If I look at what you're reporting this quarter, I guess, I don't get it. I don't understand where this incremental somberness comes from. Because if I look at,
componenttext: I wanted to come back to this December outlook that is surprising a lot of people, I suppose. If I look at what you're reporting this quarter, I guess, I don't get it. I don't understand where this incremental somberness comes from. Because if I look at, for example, what you said about demand, it's after the post-tax credit drop off in April and May, a pick up from July through September, and then really normal seasonality from there. Pricing, it seems, has not been great but has been kind of stable. Your gross margins, your September quarter was obviously after the post-tax credit closings. And that was pretty strong considering, specially with all the specs that you moved. So I mean, what am I missing here? I mean, is this really just boiled down to a comp issue that's the last year, you had two tax credits in it from a volume perspective and this year, you won't? So what am I missing here in terms of what's happening now that is driving this increased level of pessimism from you folks?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe you're not watching as much Fox news as I watched, and maybe I'm watching too much of it. But to be quite candid with you, I don't see much on the horizon that would give anybody a great degree of comfort on the financial condition of the countr
componenttext: And maybe you're not watching as much Fox news as I watched, and maybe I'm watching too much of it. But to be quite candid with you, I don't see much on the horizon that would give anybody a great degree of comfort on the financial condition of the country. I see still high unemployment. I see very lack luster job growth or no job growth. We see continued high unemployment, and I see any corporations sitting with over $1 trillion in cash. So perhaps, I'm more somber than they, but they obviously are voting with their pocket book because we're all keeping a lot of cash on our balance sheets until we have some future that's being driven by the government that says, "Hey, here's what the rules are, and we can go forward and play for the next three to five years. And here's what the rules are." We don't know what the rules are, and we're by virtue of who we are and our experience in business a little more adept at dealing with that. But if you're a consumer out there and you're working at Boeing or working on Microsoft, you're working on one of those companies and you see what's going on in the economy, I don't know how you can have any confidence that you're going to have a job tomorrow because people are still being laid off. So our somber outlook is one that, perhaps, I'd call it realistic. It's no job growth, high unemployment and a tremendous amount of debt in this country, which is focusing on are we going to have issues going forward, which I think we will with our debt. So until those major factors are fixed in the economy, I don't think any business can have any great insurance as to what's going to happen in the future.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I guess to frame it in terms of what you're not saying, you are not saying that you saw a dramatic drop-off in demand, which has driven you to be more pessimistic. You are not saying that you've seen pricing fall apart. You're basically saying that as
componenttext: So I guess to frame it in terms of what you're not saying, you are not saying that you saw a dramatic drop-off in demand, which has driven you to be more pessimistic. You are not saying that you've seen pricing fall apart. You're basically saying that as you look in the past two year, which benefited from some government stimulus and a lot of uncertainty going forward, it sounds more like a macro statement as opposed with other things, which you're not saying.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, yes. This company is positioned today better than any company in our industry to deal whether will be somber, realistic or optimistic come the spring selling season. I'm just dealing with the macro issues, and the macro issues, I think, have a
componenttext: Absolutely, yes. This company is positioned today better than any company in our industry to deal whether will be somber, realistic or optimistic come the spring selling season. I'm just dealing with the macro issues, and the macro issues, I think, have a bigger impact on our industry than any of the other factors are involved.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Stephen East with Ticonderoga.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Stephen East with Ticonderoga.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Whether you're seeing something in your order trends that made you change your mind, are you seeing any shift among buyers? Are you seeing a shift from entry level toward move up, anything like that that's going on in the market?
componenttext: Whether you're seeing something in your order trends that made you change your mind, are you seeing any shift among buyers? Are you seeing a shift from entry level toward move up, anything like that that's going on in the market?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Subsequent to that tax credit, we have seen our first-time home buyers now into the high 40% instead of in the 50% to 55% range, so we have seen a little bit of that. But we're still seeing the strongest demand from the first-time homebuyers simply becaus
componenttext: Subsequent to that tax credit, we have seen our first-time home buyers now into the high 40% instead of in the 50% to 55% range, so we have seen a little bit of that. But we're still seeing the strongest demand from the first-time homebuyers simply because they don't have some of the hurdles in terms of selling the existing homes before they can move into another home.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And could you just remind us when you would start seeing your first indications of the spring selling season?
componenttext: And could you just remind us when you would start seeing your first indications of the spring selling season?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we think that -- well, clearly, Super Bowl Sunday. But as we're talking the other day, it's going to be end of February and most likely in the March before we can really ascertain whether there's been any spring selling season.
componenttext: Well, we think that -- well, clearly, Super Bowl Sunday. But as we're talking the other day, it's going to be end of February and most likely in the March before we can really ascertain whether there's been any spring selling season.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Carl Reichardt from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Carl Reichardt from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Stacey, last quarter, we talked about this quarter being potentially profitable by the challenge, and one of the issues was focused on backlog turnover. And your backlog turnover was close to 100% this quarter and actually that way pretty much through the
componenttext: Stacey, last quarter, we talked about this quarter being potentially profitable by the challenge, and one of the issues was focused on backlog turnover. And your backlog turnover was close to 100% this quarter and actually that way pretty much through the year. What are you thinking about 2011? Are we going to continue to see you turn your backlog close to 100% a quarter? Is that going to slow up?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's hard to say, but we achieved 100% in the Q4, which is typically our highest backlog conversion. The other times, we exceeded 100% this fiscal year were typically quarters where we have tax credit, expirations either in the quarter or imminent. So it'
componenttext: It's hard to say, but we achieved 100% in the Q4, which is typically our highest backlog conversion. The other times, we exceeded 100% this fiscal year were typically quarters where we have tax credit, expirations either in the quarter or imminent. So it's hard to say that we will continue to see that. We have seen, though, a continued higher percentage of our home closings coming from the specs, which can be a shorter contract to close process. And we do continue to have those homes available, so that can keep our conversion rate elevated. But in terms of giving you a definite answer on what we can achieve going forward is difficult to do.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Don, going back to your thought process on market share gains, are there some specific regions in the country or metro areas, maybe two or three, where you think the gain potential for you guys is most great? I know you're going to say it's pret
componenttext: And then, Don, going back to your thought process on market share gains, are there some specific regions in the country or metro areas, maybe two or three, where you think the gain potential for you guys is most great? I know you're going to say it's pretty much everywhere, but I'd like you to focus on two to three that where you think the opportunity is the best?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, I think Florida has been really a great story for us over the course of the last 12, 18 months. I also look at Texas because of the fact that in Texas, there are a lot of rolling option opportunities here more so than elsewhere. And clearly
componenttext: Well, clearly, I think Florida has been really a great story for us over the course of the last 12, 18 months. I also look at Texas because of the fact that in Texas, there are a lot of rolling option opportunities here more so than elsewhere. And clearly, Texas is our home, and Texas continues to be a very profitable market for us. And we have some very good operators here. We also have some very good operators in Florida. Ironically, I look at our position in Las Vegas, and Las Vegas is really a marginal market. And we've got a division President out there in Scotstone and has a great team, and we continue to take market share in Las Vegas in a really, really sad market. I think that also that we have opportunities in the Atlanta market, and we have a good operator there. But those are really where I see some of our best market opportunities and big markets where we can continue to take market share.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jack Micenko with FIG.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jack Micenko with FIG.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Most of the questions have been answered. Just two quick ones. Can you talk about your sub-prime process in '06 and '07 and how that's really changed for today? And what kind of sales mix in terms of financing versus GSC versus otherwise private label in
componenttext: Most of the questions have been answered. Just two quick ones. Can you talk about your sub-prime process in '06 and '07 and how that's really changed for today? And what kind of sales mix in terms of financing versus GSC versus otherwise private label in that time period? And then a follow up.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Basically, sub-prime was available. There were investors who were interested in buying sub-prime product. And so our mortgage company originated sub-prime in '05 and '06. The sub-prime and all pay combined essentially replaced the governmental lending in
componenttext: Basically, sub-prime was available. There were investors who were interested in buying sub-prime product. And so our mortgage company originated sub-prime in '05 and '06. The sub-prime and all pay combined essentially replaced the governmental lending in terms of percentages, so government had been 50% to 60% of our business prior to the availability of sub-prime in Alt-A. Alt-A and sub-prime grew, while government shrink. And then there are no investors today buying either sub-prime or Alt-A. Most of them, mortgage investors are looking for full documentation with the implicit guarantee of the U.S. government behind it. And so the government portion of our loans has grown again to 66% this quarter.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And when you say, government, are you breaking out or you're putting FHA in that total?
componenttext: And when you say, government, are you breaking out or you're putting FHA in that total?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: FHA is in there. it's usually in about a mid-40% range, and then the balance of that is going to be DA.
componenttext: FHA is in there. it's usually in about a mid-40% range, and then the balance of that is going to be DA.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the $350 million or so on the watch list, do you offer a state-by-state breakdown of that number?
componenttext: And then on the $350 million or so on the watch list, do you offer a state-by-state breakdown of that number?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I believe we gave our top three states, which account for more than 50%, and that is California, Illinois and Arizona. And this is a point I always like to mention that we're the only builder, I think, that gives you a watch list.
componenttext: I believe we gave our top three states, which account for more than 50%, and that is California, Illinois and Arizona. And this is a point I always like to mention that we're the only builder, I think, that gives you a watch list.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jay McCanless with Guggenheim.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jay McCanless with Guggenheim.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: ASPs for fiscal '11, I know it's been a little over the map this year because of mix shift. But the land that you're buying now, what should we expect for ASPs in '11?
componenttext: ASPs for fiscal '11, I know it's been a little over the map this year because of mix shift. But the land that you're buying now, what should we expect for ASPs in '11?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: We expect our ASPs to be flat to slightly up.
componenttext: We expect our ASPs to be flat to slightly up.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I agree with your commentary about inflation being the looming problem in front of us, but how soon or what should we expect in terms of it showing up in your stick-and-brick cost? I mean, you said it was down 320 bps this year, but how long do y
componenttext: And then I agree with your commentary about inflation being the looming problem in front of us, but how soon or what should we expect in terms of it showing up in your stick-and-brick cost? I mean, you said it was down 320 bps this year, but how long do you think you're going to be able to sustain that if we do see a sharp pick up in inflation?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Don has addressed a lot of that. Just in terms of as long as the top line continues to be soft for us and we see continued margin pressure, we're going to be back negotiating. We cannot accept price increases right now. And so there's been a lot o
componenttext: I think Don has addressed a lot of that. Just in terms of as long as the top line continues to be soft for us and we see continued margin pressure, we're going to be back negotiating. We cannot accept price increases right now. And so there's been a lot of talk about increases in commodities. I think we had some tough round inflation in paint, and we have price protection in all of those categories in most of our markets. And so we're going to negotiate very aggressively even in the markets where we don't just based on our volume. And so we've heard a lot about price increases over the last year. And in general, we're able to hold the line in our pricing, and we'll continue to do that until we can sell our end product for a greater price.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if we think that what happens in the marketplace, where we have softer sales and softer closings for the industry on a go-forward basis, I think a lot of these, even if they are inflationary pressures from our vendors on commodities, I think is going
componenttext: And if we think that what happens in the marketplace, where we have softer sales and softer closings for the industry on a go-forward basis, I think a lot of these, even if they are inflationary pressures from our vendors on commodities, I think is going to be a difficult time for them to push those through based upon the slowing demand both on the sales and the closings.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Smith with JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Smith with JMP Securities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I've heard from some other builders and, Don, you kind of mentioned a little bit earlier, but just if you could give a little more color on it. This idea that pricing right now for consumers, because it's much more of a confidence question than anything e
componenttext: I've heard from some other builders and, Don, you kind of mentioned a little bit earlier, but just if you could give a little more color on it. This idea that pricing right now for consumers, because it's much more of a confidence question than anything else and people just don't feel comfortable going out in buying a house that pricing for homes is fairly inelastic. And I'm wondering if you can comment on whether or not you agree with that, and how much of that impacts your decisions going forward about pricing and incentives and if that offers some measure of margin protection for you guys knowing that people are going to kind of come out of the woodwork, when they're going to come out of the woodwork and there's not a whole lot on pricing that you can do affect that or if you think that's the wrong way to look at?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think pricing is inelastic. We talked to our salespeople more than I do on a daily basis, our sales managers and it's just not a lot that we can do to continue to sell homes, increase our sales base relative to the traffic that we've got. Now we've got
componenttext: I think pricing is inelastic. We talked to our salespeople more than I do on a daily basis, our sales managers and it's just not a lot that we can do to continue to sell homes, increase our sales base relative to the traffic that we've got. Now we've got a lot of plans for this year as we did for last year to increase our traffic vis-a-vis sales events that we had last year, and we got plans for those in each one of our divisions and our regions in the country and also in a nationwide basis. I think the way that we continue to handle the softness is by virtue of offering incentives, so we can maintain our pricing structure in most all of our communities. The last thing we really want to do is to enter into a decrease in our prices. Basically, we prefer to offer them on the incentive side.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Leon with Standard & Poor’s.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Leon with Standard & Poor’s.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: There such a high concentration in the Southeast and South Central markets, and can you speak to those markets first in terms of the first-time buyer? And whether compared to past cycles, what's going to give you more confidence in just anything more spec
componenttext: There such a high concentration in the Southeast and South Central markets, and can you speak to those markets first in terms of the first-time buyer? And whether compared to past cycles, what's going to give you more confidence in just anything more specific than just saying confidence or jobs employment.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, as I was reading the other day, you're talking about the South and the South Central and the Southeast. One of our strongest markets is Texas, and I was reading the report, I think this Perris report or something like that on a wake up, jus
componenttext: Well, clearly, as I was reading the other day, you're talking about the South and the South Central and the Southeast. One of our strongest markets is Texas, and I was reading the report, I think this Perris report or something like that on a wake up, just talking about all the 380,000 jobs have been generated over the last decade or something like that has all been in Texas. So clearly, we believe that Texas is a fantastic state that acquired a lot of corporations. We continue to get corporations moving in from California and other parts of the country. So I think Texas will continue to be a very strong market for us both in terms of just relocations as well as job growth within the state.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just staying again on Southeast or South Central, and you have positive comments. Congratulations on building more communities in Florida at a lower cost and a higher return. But the foreclosures are substantial and it's an overhang that's going to be
componenttext: And just staying again on Southeast or South Central, and you have positive comments. Congratulations on building more communities in Florida at a lower cost and a higher return. But the foreclosures are substantial and it's an overhang that's going to be there for a few years. So relative to other builders, national builders, do you feel that you could be successful and still gain share?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do. And one of those reasons is because we are penetrating our markets, and we are tying up the finished lots in most all of those communities. So we have more flags in those communities than other builders. In terms of the foreclosures, we deal wi
componenttext: Yes, I do. And one of those reasons is because we are penetrating our markets, and we are tying up the finished lots in most all of those communities. So we have more flags in those communities than other builders. In terms of the foreclosures, we deal with foreclosures in virtually every market everyday. We believe we offer a very competitively priced product, a new product with a warranty on it vis-à-vis the foreclosures. In addition to us, ours is a seamless process as opposed to a very frustrating project trying to buy something from the government or from the bank. So as a result, I think we can continue to effectively compete with those foreclosures and not only do I think I know we have to because they are going to be a problem for the industry probably for the next three to four or five years.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, we have ran out of time for questions. I will now turn the conference back over to management for closing remarks.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, we have ran out of time for questions. I will now turn the conference back over to management for closing remarks.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and we appreciate all of you who joined us on our conference call. I want to be certain that everyone understands that we believe that we had a very successful fiscal year 2010. And most importantly, we are prepared to meet whatever the market
componenttext:
Thank you, and we appreciate all of you who joined us on our conference call. I want to be certain that everyone understands that we believe that we had a very successful fiscal year 2010. And most importantly, we are prepared to meet whatever the market conditions are in fiscal 2011. I can't thank all of our salespeople enough in each one of our communities because you've done a successful, very successful job out there. And to all of our construction people, who we continue to build houses faster more efficiently and better than ever, I thank you. Our vendors, who continue to support us over the years and we need your support on a go-forward basis to meet the market, we thank you, too. 
We clearly continue and will plan to continue to outperform everyone else in the industry. D.R. Horton is the largest builder in America for the eighth consecutive years, and our goal clearly is to be the largest builder for the ninth consecutive year, all the while focusing on the most important aspect of our business and that is profitability. But as Don Horton has said this many times, it all starts with the people. And i frankly believe we have the best people in the industry, and we appreciate your phenomenal job that you've done for us. Thank you very much.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. This concludes today's conference. All parties may disconnect now.
componenttext: Thank you. This concludes today's conference. All parties may disconnect now.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the D.R. Horton, America’s Builder, the largest builder in the United States, 2010 fiscal year end earnings release conference call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. A brief question-and-answer sessi
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the D.R. Horton, America’s Builder, the largest builder in the United States, 2010 fiscal year end earnings release conference call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. A brief question-and-answer session will follow the formal presentation. As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Donald J. Tomnitz, President and CEO for D.R. Horton. Thank you. Mr. Tomnitz, you may begin.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Joining me this morning are Bill Wheat, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Stacey Dwyer, Executive Vice President and Treasurer. Before we get started, Stacey?
componenttext: Thank you, and good morning. Joining me this morning are Bill Wheat, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Stacey Dwyer, Executive Vice President and Treasurer. Before we get started, Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Some comments made on this call may constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although D.R. Horton believes any such statements are based on reasonable assumptions, there is no assurance that
componenttext:
Some comments made on this call may constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although D.R. Horton believes any such statements are based on reasonable assumptions, there is no assurance that actual outcomes will not be materially different.
All forward-looking statements are based upon information available to D.R. Horton on the date of this conference call and D.R. Horton does not undertake any obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements.
Additional information about issues that could lead to material changes in performance is contained in D.R. Horton’s current report on Form 8-K, dated February 8, 2010, which updated our Annual Report on Form 10-K, and our most recent quarterly report on Form 10-Q, all of which are filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Fiscal 2010 was a year of the tax credit. This calls volatile sales and closings, but the year was consistent with our expectations and preparations. While the federal tax credit was in place, we experienced strong sales demand through the April 30, the s
componenttext:
Fiscal 2010 was a year of the tax credit. This calls volatile sales and closings, but the year was consistent with our expectations and preparations. While the federal tax credit was in place, we experienced strong sales demand through the April 30, the sales contract deadline, especially from first time home buyers.
Our closings were strong through the June 30 closing deadline for the tax credit. However, after the tax credit expired sales demand dropped sharply in May. From June through August, our sales trend showed sequential improvement, and then we began experiencing a normal seasonal slowdown in September and October.
Overall, housing demand is weak. Even with significant fluctuations in the level of demand for our new homes in fiscal 2010, our approach was very consistent, manage our homes in inventory to current demand, generate cash, reduce debt, position ourselves for profitability and maintain a strong balance sheet to be positioned to take advantage of opportunities.
As we look to fiscal 2011, we continue to be realistic in our expectations, and will adjust our business to compete in the current market conditions. We expect another very challenging year for the homebuilding industry, as the fundamental drivers of demand, the overall economy, job growth, and consumer confidence are still very weak. In addition, we do not expect any stimulus in fiscal 2011 similar to the federal tax credits that were in effect last year.
All of these factors make it likely that our sales and closing volumes will be below our volumes in fiscal 2010. However, we plan to continue to gain market share by opening new communities and adjusting our price points and product offerings to the demand we see in each of our individual markets.
I want to congratulate each member of the D.R. Horton team for turning in a strong performance on fiscal 2010, despite continued difficult industry conditions. We appreciate very you’re your efforts. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our net loss for the quarter was $8.9 million or $0.03 per diluted share compared to a net loss of $234.9 million or $0.74 per diluted share in the prior year quarter. Homebuilding pre-tax loss was $6.5 million, which included $30.8 million of inventory i
componenttext:
Our net loss for the quarter was $8.9 million or $0.03 per diluted share compared to a net loss of $234.9 million or $0.74 per diluted share in the prior year quarter. Homebuilding pre-tax loss was $6.5 million, which included $30.8 million of inventory impairment and lot option charges.
Financial services pre-tax income was $4.8 million, which included $2.1 million of recourse expense. Our fourth quarter income tax provision was $7.2 million, due primarily to an increase in our tax reserves. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our fourth quarter home sales revenue decreased 9% to $921 million on 4,281 homes closed from $1 billion on 4,810 homes closed in the year ago quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was up 2% from the prior year, and up 6% sequentially to $215
componenttext: Our fourth quarter home sales revenue decreased 9% to $921 million on 4,281 homes closed from $1 billion on 4,810 homes closed in the year ago quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was up 2% from the prior year, and up 6% sequentially to $215,200. The sequential increase was primarily due to a higher percentage of our closings coming from the west region in the fourth quarter versus the third quarter. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Net sales orders for the fourth quarter were down 21% from last year to 3,979 homes. The net sales orders in the prior year quarter included demand from the first time home buyer tax credit that was in effect last year.Based on current sales demand and
componenttext:
Net sales orders for the fourth quarter were down 21% from last year to 3,979 homes. The net sales orders in the prior year quarter included demand from the first time home buyer tax credit that was in effect last year.
Based on current sales demand and the fact that the tax credits were supporting sales demand last year, we expect sales in the next two quarters to be lower than last year. While we remain focused on opening new communities and gaining market share for us to see significant sustainable sales growth, we need to see improvements in the overall economy, the jobs landscape, and consumer confidence.
In the September quarter, our average sales price on net sales orders was essentially flat year-over-year at $205,500. Our cancellation rate was 31%. Our active selling communities were up 6% sequentially. 49% of our net sales came from communities opened in fiscal year 2009 or later. Our sales backlog decreased 27% from the prior year to 4,128 homes or $850.8 million. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the fourth quarter was 17%, up 450 basis points from our home sales margin in the year ago period. A contributing factor to our margin improvement from last year was that 39% of fourth quarter closings were
componenttext:
Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the fourth quarter was 17%, up 450 basis points from our home sales margin in the year ago period. A contributing factor to our margin improvement from last year was that 39% of fourth quarter closings were from new deals that were put under contract in fiscal 2009 or later. Margins on closings in our new projects are approximately 200 to 300 basis points higher than on the remainder of our closings.
Our margin decreased 20 basis points sequentially from the third to the fourth quarter, reflecting the weaker housing market we had experienced during the second half of this year.
Although our gross margins have been in the 17% to 18% range each quarter this fiscal year, we expect to experience gross margin pressure over the next few quarters as we continually adjust to the prevailing market in each of our communities. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: In our fourth quarter impairment analysis, we reviewed all projects in the company and determined that projects with a pre-impairment carrying value of $63.1 million were impaired, which resulted in $29.1 million of impairment charges. The majority of whi
componenttext:
In our fourth quarter impairment analysis, we reviewed all projects in the company and determined that projects with a pre-impairment carrying value of $63.1 million were impaired, which resulted in $29.1 million of impairment charges. The majority of which were in Texas, Florida, and Illinois.
We refer to our projects, which have indicators of potential impairment, but were not impaired as our watch list, which represents those projects deemed to be at the highest risk for future impairments. Our watch list is currently $346.7 million, similar to the amount at June 30, 2010, with the largest concentrations in California, Illinois, and Arizona.
Our inventory impairment process in future quarters will incorporate any changes in market conditions and any adjustments we make in our business. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our consistent focus on controlling SG&A has been a key to our return to profitability. We have leveraged our SG&A structure to focus on profitable opportunities in our existing market with our current division operations.Through fiscal 2010, we closed
componenttext:
Our consistent focus on controlling SG&A has been a key to our return to profitability. We have leveraged our SG&A structure to focus on profitable opportunities in our existing market with our current division operations.
Through fiscal 2010, we closed 25% more homes on essentially flat SG&A dollars compared to fiscal 2009. Homebuilding SG&A expense for the quarter, which includes all corporate overhead was $121.8 million or 13.2% of homebuilding revenues compared to 13.3% in the year ago quarter.
Fourth quarter homebuilding SG&A expense was lower than recent quarters due in part to the impact of the $7.9 million reduction in our executive compensation accruals. We will continue to actively manage our SG&A levels relative to our expected number of homes closings. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we are required to directly expense a portion of our interest incurred while our homebuilding debt level exceeds our active inventory, we recorded $17.1 million in homebuilding interest expense during the quarter. This was approximately 47% of the $36.
componenttext:
As we are required to directly expense a portion of our interest incurred while our homebuilding debt level exceeds our active inventory, we recorded $17.1 million in homebuilding interest expense during the quarter. This was approximately 47% of the $36.3 million of homebuilding interest we incurred.
Our fourth quarter homebuilding interest incurred decreased 31% compared to the prior year, and our homebuilding interest incurred for the entire fiscal year decreased 16% as a result of the debt reductions we achieved this year. Stacy?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Financial services pre-tax income for the quarter was $4.8 million compared to a loss of $2.9 million in the year ago quarter. 83% of our mortgage company’s business was captive during the quarter. Our company-wide capture rate was approximately 60% and
componenttext:
Financial services pre-tax income for the quarter was $4.8 million compared to a loss of $2.9 million in the year ago quarter. 83% of our mortgage company’s business was captive during the quarter. Our company-wide capture rate was approximately 60% and our average FICO score was 719 and our average combined loan-to-value was 90%.
Our product mix in the quarter was essentially 100% agency-eligible, with government loans accounting for 63% of our volumes.
From fiscal 2007 through fiscal 2010 we have recognized recourse expense totaling $94.8 million. Our fiscal 2010 recourse expense was $13.7 million, which is down from $33.2 million in fiscal 2009.
The majority of the recourse expense in 2007 and early 2008 related to early payment default provisions. Since then the more significant portion of the recourse expense relates to misrepresentations by the borrower in the loan origination process. Cumulatively through September 30, 2010 we have settled approximately 1,500 mortgage claims and we are currently evaluating less than 300 additional claims.
While mortgage claim activity can be volatile from month-to-month, mortgage claims in the second half of fiscal 2010 declined approximately 23% compared to the first half of the year. Each quarter, we analyze recent trends in claim activity to evaluate reserves for potential future claim exposure.
Our reserve balances currently total $39 million with $10.8 million reserved for owned mortgages and foreclosed real estates, and $28.2 million for pending and projected claims. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our total inventory decreased by approximately $87 million excluding noncash impairment charges during the quarter. We’ve reduced our homes in inventory by $129 million, and increased our investment in residential land and lots and land held for develop
componenttext:
Our total inventory decreased by approximately $87 million excluding noncash impairment charges during the quarter. We’ve reduced our homes in inventory by $129 million, and increased our investment in residential land and lots and land held for development by $42 million.
Our homes in inventory at the end of September totaled 9,500 homes down 1,300 homes from June. 1,200 of our homes were models, 5,200 were speculative homes, and 3,200 of these specs were completed. We continued to manage our total homes in inventory relative to our expectations of sales demand. We offer spec homes primarily to accommodate our first time home buyers and relocation home buyers. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our land and lot purchases remain controlled and we continue to evaluate our land development plans based on current sales trends. We have been actively contracting for finished lots to increase our active selling communities and increase our gross margin
componenttext:
Our land and lot purchases remain controlled and we continue to evaluate our land development plans based on current sales trends. We have been actively contracting for finished lots to increase our active selling communities and increase our gross margins.
In our fourth fiscal quarter, we invested approximately $188 million primarily in finished lots. Our spending on finished lots will remain largely dependent on our sales pace, while our spending on land and development costs will continue to be at relatively low levels. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our supply of owned land and lots at September 30, 2010 was approximately 90,000 lots, of which approximately 23,000 are finished. We control an additional 30,000 lots through option contracts, up 9% from June 30, with a net earnest money deposit balance
componenttext: Our supply of owned land and lots at September 30, 2010 was approximately 90,000 lots, of which approximately 23,000 are finished. We control an additional 30,000 lots through option contracts, up 9% from June 30, with a net earnest money deposit balance for these lots of only $13.3 million. We are focused on managing our supply of owned, finished lots in line with our sales demand in a low risk capital efficient manner. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cash flow from operations for the September quarter totaled $122.3 million generated by the decrease in homes in inventory and mortgage loans held for sale offset by our spending on finished lots and development, and a decrease in our accounts payable.O
componenttext:
Cash flow from operations for the September quarter totaled $122.3 million generated by the decrease in homes in inventory and mortgage loans held for sale offset by our spending on finished lots and development, and a decrease in our accounts payable.
Our fiscal year 2010 cash flow from operations totaled $709.4 million. We ended the fiscal year with $1.6 billion of homebuilding cash and marketable security.
The balance of our public notes outstanding at September 30, 2010 was $2.1 billion, and our note maturities in fiscal 2011 and 2012 are $189 million and $146.6 million respectively. We retired over $1 billion of debt in fiscal 2010, and we have $483.8 million remaining on our debt repurchase authorization at September 30, 2010. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: At September 30, our homebuilding leverage ratio, net of cash and marketable securities, was 16.1% a 16.4 percentage point improvement from a year ago. Gross homebuilding leverage at September 30 was 44.3%, an 11.9 percentage point improvement from a year
componenttext: At September 30, our homebuilding leverage ratio, net of cash and marketable securities, was 16.1% a 16.4 percentage point improvement from a year ago. Gross homebuilding leverage at September 30 was 44.3%, an 11.9 percentage point improvement from a year ago. These leverage improvements compared to the prior year are due primarily to our cash generation and significant debt reductions. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: In summary, our financial performance this fiscal year demonstrates the progress DHI has made toward achieving profitability, balance sheet strength, and market share gains in this challenging and uncertain housing market.Some of our most important acco
componenttext:
In summary, our financial performance this fiscal year demonstrates the progress DHI has made toward achieving profitability, balance sheet strength, and market share gains in this challenging and uncertain housing market.
Some of our most important accomplishments this year include pre-tax income totaled $99.5 million. Home sales gross margins increased 420 basis points over the prior year as we improved the cost and design of our products and opened new communities on recently acquired lots at higher margins.
Fully loaded homebuilding SG&A, which includes all of corporate overhead as a percentage of revenues, was 12.1% essentially flat in dollars with fiscal 2009 on a 25% increase in homes closed.
Cash flow from operations of $709.4 million bringing our total over the last 17 consecutive quarters to $5.9 billion. Over $1 billion in homebuilding debt repurchases and redemptions this fiscal year contributing to our net homebuilding leverage ratio of 16.1%.
There are still challenges in the homebuilding industry. Rising foreclosures, significant existing home inventory, high unemployment, tight mortgage lending standards, and the weak consumer confidence. However, new home inventory remains low, interest rates are favorable, and housing affordability is near record highs.
We, at Horton, will continue to focus on providing affordable homes, controlling our costs, contracting for new communities with attractively priced and finished lots and maintaining our strong balance sheet. Again, we want to thank all of our DHI team members who continue to outsell and outperform everyone in the industry. Keep up the great work.
This concludes our prepared remarks and now we’ll host any questions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. (Operator instructions) Our first question comes from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan. Please state your question.
componenttext: Thank you. (Operator instructions) Our first question comes from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan. Please state your question.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Good morning, everyone.
componenttext: Thanks. Good morning, everyone.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Mike.
componenttext: Good morning, Mike.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question I just had was on community growth. If you could give us a sense of where it was year-over-year for the quarter and as you look into fiscal ‘11, we appreciate the comments with regards to expectation for sales and closings to be down,
componenttext: The first question I just had was on community growth. If you could give us a sense of where it was year-over-year for the quarter and as you look into fiscal ‘11, we appreciate the comments with regards to expectation for sales and closings to be down, and obviously you’re facing a tough first half comp to say the least. How do you look at community growth going into next year as, obviously, offsetting some of that comp and also maybe limiting incremental downside on gross margins to the extent that you still have a positive mix shift into next year as well?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’ll start and I am sure Don will jump in, in a moment. Our community count year-over-year in terms of actual selling communities was up 17%. Since we look forward into next year, we are continuing to try to put new communities under option contracts, p
componenttext: I’ll start and I am sure Don will jump in, in a moment. Our community count year-over-year in terms of actual selling communities was up 17%. Since we look forward into next year, we are continuing to try to put new communities under option contracts, primarily rolling options on finished lots and we would certainly anticipate and continue to increase our active selling community. That will be offset by some of our current communities rolling off and our pace of increase in the communities will be dependent on the sales demand that we see.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: We think most all of our growth next year, Mike, will come from penetrating our existing markets deeper and taking market share from the other builders who are less, I think proactive in the markets and more undercapitalized than we. We continue on each a
componenttext: We think most all of our growth next year, Mike, will come from penetrating our existing markets deeper and taking market share from the other builders who are less, I think proactive in the markets and more undercapitalized than we. We continue on each and every one of our markets to work with the banks and work with the developers to options lots which are already finished which we can put into construction immediately and those lots are obviously at more unfavorable prices than many of the lots that we’ve had over the course of 2005 to 2008.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that, so just to follow-up, just to drill down a little bit, so are you willing to give us a sense of what you think community count might grow next year? Do you think it can still hit this double-digit mark and secondly the gross margin impa
componenttext: I appreciate that, so just to follow-up, just to drill down a little bit, so are you willing to give us a sense of what you think community count might grow next year? Do you think it can still hit this double-digit mark and secondly the gross margin impact or benefit, does that kind of offset to the extent that you can increase even your percent of closings from new communities or do you think that that positive mix shift has largely occurred given your 40% right now?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think clearly our community count will grow just as it did. Our goal clearly is to hit double-digit community growth, whether we do that or not is going to be really dependent upon what deals become available in each of our markets.One of the th
componenttext:
Well, I think clearly our community count will grow just as it did. Our goal clearly is to hit double-digit community growth, whether we do that or not is going to be really dependent upon what deals become available in each of our markets.
One of the things that we’ve realized is in certain of our markets, we saw no opportunities, or very few opportunities a year ago and all of a sudden we’re beginning to see more and more communities and simply that’s a reflection of the banks and the developer dealing with the current market conditions of being honest with themselves about what the real market price of those lots are.
As far as the gross margin, I believe that our gross margins have some potential to come under pressure coming this spring irrespective of the fact that we continued to bring on new communities with higher gross margin simply because we are not right now projecting a huge spring bump, it’s uncertain as to what’s going to happen in the spring and certainly other builders have brought on what we think are additional specs late in the market post the tax credit. We believe that to the extent that there is not a significant spring bump there could be some gross margin deterioration come spring.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Clearly, part of our strategy and continuing to add new communities at today’s prices is to help mitigate that margin pressure. We still continue to see higher margins in the range of 200 to 300 basis points on our new communities. The communities that
componenttext: Clearly, part of our strategy and continuing to add new communities at today’s prices is to help mitigate that margin pressure. We still continue to see higher margins in the range of 200 to 300 basis points on our new communities. The communities that we contracted since 2009 are now almost half of our business so that’s becoming really a core part of our business, and so, we’ll continue to do that to help offset the margin pressure that we’re seeing in the market, but on the whole we will not be surprised to see some pressure on margins in a downward fashion in the coming quarters.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Really in conclusion on that, I’d like to say is that to the extent that Horton has been proactive earlier than any other builder in terms of securing these option contracts, we’ve proven beyond any reasonable doubt amongst the sellers, the banks as w
componenttext: Really in conclusion on that, I’d like to say is that to the extent that Horton has been proactive earlier than any other builder in terms of securing these option contracts, we’ve proven beyond any reasonable doubt amongst the sellers, the banks as well as the lot owners, that one we are there and two, we are performing and three, we are putting specs on their lots and working their way through their lots at a faster pace. I believe as I travel through all these markets as DR does, we are definitely the preeminent desired buyer of lots in each and every market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks, guys.
componenttext: Great, thanks, guys.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Our next question comes from Megan McGrath with Barclays Capital. Please state your question.
componenttext: Thank you. Our next question comes from Megan McGrath with Barclays Capital. Please state your question.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks. Just wanted to follow-up on that last conversation a little bit more in terms of your expectations for the spring. Clearly, not a lot of visibility yet, but is there a desire to exit these old communities faster and that’s where yo
componenttext: Good morning. Thanks. Just wanted to follow-up on that last conversation a little bit more in terms of your expectations for the spring. Clearly, not a lot of visibility yet, but is there a desire to exit these old communities faster and that’s where you think some of this pricing pressure will come from, or generally do you just think across the board you’re going to have to make up for lower volume with across the board price cuts even in some of these new communities?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: By the way, great job on CNBC this morning. I thought you did a great presentation. Would we like to exit our older communities faster? Yes, we’ve been focusing on that for quite some time, and obviously, the basis in those older communities doesn’t a
componenttext:
By the way, great job on CNBC this morning. I thought you did a great presentation. Would we like to exit our older communities faster? Yes, we’ve been focusing on that for quite some time, and obviously, the basis in those older communities doesn’t afford us the opportunity to exit those clearly as possible.
But clearly, we’re focusing on adding the new communities, and as Stacey said, we’re 200 to 300 basis points higher in our gross margin on our newer communities, and to the extent that we can continue to add those. Yes, I think it will offset what we anticipate to be some margin compression come the spring unless there is a strongest spring market than what we’re anticipating right now, and with the job growth where it is, consumer confidence where it is, I just don’t see a lot of hope for a great spring market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. A little depressing, but stepping back a little bit, rather for 2011, can you maybe just give us an idea of any sort of corporate goals that you’re willing to share, or what you’re telling your sales folks in terms of what they should focus on f
componenttext: Okay. A little depressing, but stepping back a little bit, rather for 2011, can you maybe just give us an idea of any sort of corporate goals that you’re willing to share, or what you’re telling your sales folks in terms of what they should focus on for the next fiscal year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I tell our sales people as I travel around the country, if they are warm and they have pulse, write them, and then we will worry about qualifying them, but I think that we need to clearly take the buyers out of the market. We have the best pricing
componenttext:
Yes, as I tell our sales people as I travel around the country, if they are warm and they have pulse, write them, and then we will worry about qualifying them, but I think that we need to clearly take the buyers out of the market. We have the best pricing in the industry, the most speculative inventory that’s available for immediate move-in in the industry. So, our focus on our sales people is, you write them and then we’ll figure out whether or not we can get them qualified.
But most importantly, what this company has always focused on, Megan, and we continue to focus on everyday that we get up, and that is how do we consistently turn a profit in this company. So the sales, as Horton says, nothing happens until we sell something, but the reality of life is we have sell these houses at a profit and our focus is clearly how do we consistently be profitable in this corporation.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks very much.
componenttext: Great, thanks very much.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Josh Levin with Citi. Please state your question.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Josh Levin with Citi. Please state your question.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, good morning.
componenttext: Hey, good morning.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning.
componenttext: Good morning.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning.
componenttext: Good morning.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Given your what seems to be a fairly bleak outlook for 2011, are you exploring more significant SG&A cuts in the quarters ahead? I am not talking about just trimming side, but really trying to cut bone again?
componenttext: Given your what seems to be a fairly bleak outlook for 2011, are you exploring more significant SG&A cuts in the quarters ahead? I am not talking about just trimming side, but really trying to cut bone again?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let’s get back to the bleak outlook. I think what we’re telling you is, what we see out there based upon the current economic conditions, but don’t get confused, we have been and we currently are the best position builder from an SG&A perspective, a
componenttext:
Let’s get back to the bleak outlook. I think what we’re telling you is, what we see out there based upon the current economic conditions, but don’t get confused, we have been and we currently are the best position builder from an SG&A perspective, a leverage perspective, shareholders equity perspective to continue to deal better with the existing market whatever may be relative to our competition.
As far as SG&A cuts, yes, we have already identified with our regional presidents additional SG&A cuts to the extent that the sales do not materialize in accordance with our five year plan for fiscal year ‘11. So yes, I think those SG&A cuts will be more difficult than what they’ve been in the past, but we definitely have identified additional cuts that need to be made if the sales do not materialize.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: You’re talking about sales being kind of flattish, not seeing a bump, you’re talking about margin pressure, so margin is compressing. But your impairment watch list didn’t really go up. How do we reconcile all those facts?
componenttext: You’re talking about sales being kind of flattish, not seeing a bump, you’re talking about margin pressure, so margin is compressing. But your impairment watch list didn’t really go up. How do we reconcile all those facts?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it really comes down to, what we’re really dealing with is our current margins are still above 17% and so we haven’t seen a significant reductions in our margin yet. We do expect some pressure and so we certainly did add some projects to the lis
componenttext:
Well, it really comes down to, what we’re really dealing with is our current margins are still above 17% and so we haven’t seen a significant reductions in our margin yet. We do expect some pressure and so we certainly did add some projects to the list this quarter, but at the same time, we did impair a number of projects this quarter as well.
So, on a net basis the list did not increase this quarter, but that’s something we will continue to evaluate each quarter as we move into fiscal 2011. And by the way, Josh, there’s an important point, we’re sitting with a 17% gross margin. Most of our competitors would be very happy to be facing what maybe a bleak outlook in the spring with a 17% gross margin versus what they have.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you very much.
