componenttext: Okay, thank you very much.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Goldberg with UBS. Please state your question.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Goldberg with UBS. Please state your question.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Good morning, everybody.
componenttext: Thanks. Good morning, everybody.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, David.
componenttext: Good morning, David.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question I have is, Don, I think you gave some great detail on some of the issues that are facing demand pool, but I don’t want you to rank them, but what I am trying to get to is, is the problem in the market today that there’s just a lot o
componenttext: The first question I have is, Don, I think you gave some great detail on some of the issues that are facing demand pool, but I don’t want you to rank them, but what I am trying to get to is, is the problem in the market today that there’s just a lot of buyers that might want to buy a house, but can’t qualify, either they don’t have a down payment or they don’t have a FICO score, so how would you weigh the ability to qualify for loan even with 4.25%, 30 year fixed rate mortgages, and only 3.5% down payments relative to something like confidence in terms of what’s inhibiting demand today?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say nothing. Our biggest problem is not qualifying our buyers. The biggest problem right now is consumer confidence and the number of unemployed people out there. As we always say, it’s hard to sell a home to an unemployed person. But the real k
componenttext: I would say nothing. Our biggest problem is not qualifying our buyers. The biggest problem right now is consumer confidence and the number of unemployed people out there. As we always say, it’s hard to sell a home to an unemployed person. But the real key is that the traffic count in our sub-divisions is down, and I don’t think there is a lot of pricing adjustment that we can do, it’s just a function of the lack of traffic. So until there is some consumer confidence, until we start to grow jobs, I think we’re going to continue to be faced with rather flat demand just simply because buyers don’t feel confident about the future and they’re not going out there looking for a house in the numbers that they were certainly when the tax credits were there.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: But there’s pool of potential buyers, I mean, there’s people who can qualify and could if they wanted to go by a home?
componenttext: But there’s pool of potential buyers, I mean, there’s people who can qualify and could if they wanted to go by a home?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there’s a huge pool of buyers out there, but again, and that pool is less than what it was a year ago with unemployment where it is, and the lack of job growth. Again, those people don’t have the confidence that a purchase today is going to be
componenttext:
I think there’s a huge pool of buyers out there, but again, and that pool is less than what it was a year ago with unemployment where it is, and the lack of job growth. Again, those people don’t have the confidence that a purchase today is going to be rewarding.
Although I will tell you that as I keep telling people, and I’ve been an example of this myself, I don’t think there has ever been a better time in the history, my history in the homebuilding industry with affordability and pricing where it is today to buy home. If you think that we’re going to have inflation in this country which I don’t know how we cannot have with all the money we’re printing, hard assets like a home are going to be the very best investment that you can make.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just for a follow-up, Stacey, the comment that you made on claims, I’m wondering if we could focus not on the mortgage putback side but just on warranty side. Is it correct to say you haven’t really seen a pickup in claims on a warranty side
componenttext: And then just for a follow-up, Stacey, the comment that you made on claims, I’m wondering if we could focus not on the mortgage putback side but just on warranty side. Is it correct to say you haven’t really seen a pickup in claims on a warranty side that maybe some of our peers have talked about this quarter or over the last couple of quarters?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: That would be a fair statement. We have not seen anything and currently unusual in our warranty claims. We’ll have full disclosure around our warranty reserves in our 10-K, but I think you’ll see, kind of our typical roll forward of our warranty claim
componenttext: That would be a fair statement. We have not seen anything and currently unusual in our warranty claims. We’ll have full disclosure around our warranty reserves in our 10-K, but I think you’ll see, kind of our typical roll forward of our warranty claim.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just overall, we do have a litigation reserve and have for years. The gross estimated liability in terms of our actuarially determined litigation reserve is $571.3 million offset against that. We have an estimated insurance receivable of $251.5 million. S
componenttext: Just overall, we do have a litigation reserve and have for years. The gross estimated liability in terms of our actuarially determined litigation reserve is $571.3 million offset against that. We have an estimated insurance receivable of $251.5 million. So, our net reserve is $319.8 million. The year-over-year change in that net reserve has increased about $20 million, primarily just due to adding our estimates for the closings that occurred this year and then offset by anything that rolled off of the tail or any claims that were settled during the year, that’s something we evaluate on a quarter-to-quarter basis and adjust as we need to, but we haven’t seen any major changes in activity.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’ve been very proactive on that in the history of the company and again, I don’t think we get credit for the conservative nature of our balance sheet, but we have been very conservative in all of our accruals. So, I think we are well prepared for wh
componenttext: We’ve been very proactive on that in the history of the company and again, I don’t think we get credit for the conservative nature of our balance sheet, but we have been very conservative in all of our accruals. So, I think we are well prepared for whatever the warranty claims are on a go forward basis.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Don.
componenttext: Thank you very much, Don.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jade Rahmani with KBW. Please state your question.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jade Rahmani with KBW. Please state your question.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, hi, thanks for taking the question. I just wanted to ask on mortgage repurchase. Can you provide any insight on future repurchase request. It sounds like you view that risk as fairly low especially given your recent provision experience. Why do you t
componenttext: Yes, hi, thanks for taking the question. I just wanted to ask on mortgage repurchase. Can you provide any insight on future repurchase request. It sounds like you view that risk as fairly low especially given your recent provision experience. Why do you think you haven’t seen more of an increase in repurchase request given what the banks are seeing is it the nature of the new home product or because the mortgages you originated were all purchase loans and didn’t include refin activity or is it something else?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are probably several reasons, I think there actually has been lower experience on new home mortgage originations than there have been existing homes part of it is because there is less refinance activity. So, we haven’t had people taking a lot of
componenttext:
There are probably several reasons, I think there actually has been lower experience on new home mortgage originations than there have been existing homes part of it is because there is less refinance activity. So, we haven’t had people taking a lot of equity out based on large appreciation in home prices in certain markets, where the home prices have just back down as much.
Beyond that, our provisions are based on a complete analysis of the loans that we have originated, the types of loans that we’ve originated, the putback experience we’ve had on each type of loan and what I was talking about in the conference call script with the decrease in mortgages putback to 23% in the second half of the year versus the first half of the year. That’s indicating that we are seeing fewer request, even at a time when this is a headline.
One thing I would point out is we’ve been reporting recourse expense for four years, this isn’t an issue, I know it’s kind of new in terms of headline attention it’s grabbed but we’ve been proactively dealing with it through our mortgage company.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, great, thanks very much.
componenttext: Okay, great, thanks very much.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Joshua Pollard with Goldman Sachs. Please state your question.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Joshua Pollard with Goldman Sachs. Please state your question.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, good morning. How are you guys?
componenttext: Hey, good morning. How are you guys?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’re doing great. Yourself?
componenttext: We’re doing great. Yourself?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not too bad on a level of your enthusiasm relative to your competitor. It’s always praise worth. My first question is a pretty simple one. Do you guys expect to be profitable in 2011.
componenttext: Not too bad on a level of your enthusiasm relative to your competitor. It’s always praise worth. My first question is a pretty simple one. Do you guys expect to be profitable in 2011.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do and I will tell you that it’s going to be a greater challenge than it was in 2010. Simply because as we mentioned to you our sales and closing volumes will be, we anticipate to be, less unless we have some significant spring sales bumps that
componenttext: Yes, we do and I will tell you that it’s going to be a greater challenge than it was in 2010. Simply because as we mentioned to you our sales and closing volumes will be, we anticipate to be, less unless we have some significant spring sales bumps that we are having a hard time seeing today. So, yes that’s our goal, but again it’s going to be a larger challenge than it was last year in 2010.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I understand everything that you’re saying right, it will be fewer deliveries lighter gross margins, you guys are looking to hold the line at least from a percentage basis on SG&A. Is there anywhere else that we should be expecting you guys to genera
componenttext: If I understand everything that you’re saying right, it will be fewer deliveries lighter gross margins, you guys are looking to hold the line at least from a percentage basis on SG&A. Is there anywhere else that we should be expecting you guys to generate profits, are you guys looking to do anything different in your business? You’ve had a number of your competitors get into ancillary pieces of both the residential and commercial market. I am wondering if any of those things are interesting to you at this stage.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, frankly we know one thing, we’re home builder and what we’re focusing on is the homebuilding operation and to the extent that financial services supplements that the financial service side of the business. I don’t see any significant opportuni
componenttext:
Well, frankly we know one thing, we’re home builder and what we’re focusing on is the homebuilding operation and to the extent that financial services supplements that the financial service side of the business. I don’t see any significant opportunities out there that are going to enhance our performance other than continuing to execute on building, selling, closing homes, and making money, as I call it, BSCM. That’s our focus and really largely our sole focus at this point.
I think that our revenues and our closings, we do expect them to be down some based up on the tax credits not being with us. But I also believe that on the SG&A side, we’re going to continue to look for opportunities to improve our SG&A. That’s going to be more challenging, but this company has always come to the forefront in terms of dealing with whatever the market conditions are and that’s where we will be.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: One another contributing factor, Josh, will be on our interest expense. We have continued to reduce our debt dramatically, reduced about $1 billion this year, so our interesting incurred has been coming down sharply. That will continue to flow through and
componenttext: One another contributing factor, Josh, will be on our interest expense. We have continued to reduce our debt dramatically, reduced about $1 billion this year, so our interesting incurred has been coming down sharply. That will continue to flow through and we’ll see continued reductions in our direct interest expense. We see less interest capitalized in our inventory today than we did a year ago given our reduction in debt, so that is some offset, some mitigating factor to the margin pressure we expect to see in the marketplace. So, both of those factors on the interest will contribute to some incremental improvement, and hopefully, it helps to offset the market conditions we expect to see.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don’t mean to be redundant, Josh, but once again, I think a lot of companies would love to be in our position of having a 17% gross margin to deal with the future.
componenttext: I don’t mean to be redundant, Josh, but once again, I think a lot of companies would love to be in our position of having a 17% gross margin to deal with the future.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you made that comment about your gross margin, could you just talk very quickly about the difference between your margins on spec versus dirt sales? I mean, we’re hearing a lot of different numbers across the industry. I would love to hear where you
componenttext: As you made that comment about your gross margin, could you just talk very quickly about the difference between your margins on spec versus dirt sales? I mean, we’re hearing a lot of different numbers across the industry. I would love to hear where you guys stand now and where you think it could be if specs continue to make up a large portion of your sales?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our margins on our specs are typically lower than our margins on our build jobs, but yet at the same time we know two things. One, by having specs, it satisfies the buyer who needs to be a relocation buyer or a first time home buyer, who can all of
componenttext:
Well, our margins on our specs are typically lower than our margins on our build jobs, but yet at the same time we know two things. One, by having specs, it satisfies the buyer who needs to be a relocation buyer or a first time home buyer, who can all of a sudden qualify because they’ve gotten their credit straightened out or they are ready to move out of an apartment or out of their parent’s home.
The other thing we know specs though and our focus in the company is that to the extent that a spec is 90 days older or it’s 90 days past completion, we need to move that spec as quickly as possible because the profits on those specs have a tendency to decline the older they become.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s really a matter of focusing on managing them carefully and that’s something we’ve been doing for a long time, that’s part of our business. While there are lower margins on the spec versus build jobs, I think you can look at our overall margin
componenttext: It’s really a matter of focusing on managing them carefully and that’s something we’ve been doing for a long time, that’s part of our business. While there are lower margins on the spec versus build jobs, I think you can look at our overall margin and see that we’re managing it reasonably well. There is always room for improvement, but that’s something we’re always focused on.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And to be specific, as we’ve always said, specs are a part of our business and it’s a part of our business model and that’s why we’ve been so affected by it over the years.
componenttext: And to be specific, as we’ve always said, specs are a part of our business and it’s a part of our business model and that’s why we’ve been so affected by it over the years.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Zener with KeyBanc. Please state your question.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Zener with KeyBanc. Please state your question.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Just want to get a little more granular. Obviously, you guys have been aggressive on the debt pay down to lower your interest expense. If you were look at simply the homebuilding operation, do you expect that business to be profitable realiz
componenttext: Good morning. Just want to get a little more granular. Obviously, you guys have been aggressive on the debt pay down to lower your interest expense. If you were look at simply the homebuilding operation, do you expect that business to be profitable realizing there is a couple leverage that could affect the EPS relative to the interest expense and impairments?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, we expect the homebuilding business to be profitable, and that’s our focus. That’s what our business plans call for and then as we move through the fiscal year quarter-by-quarter we’ll see how successful we are at executing what our busi
componenttext: Absolutely, we expect the homebuilding business to be profitable, and that’s our focus. That’s what our business plans call for and then as we move through the fiscal year quarter-by-quarter we’ll see how successful we are at executing what our business plan is, but yes, we get up every day shower and shave and put our makeup on and our goal is to be profitable in the homebuilding side of our business.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I guess related to the differential of new communities purchase in ‘09 and later, that 200 to 300 basis points seems to be lower than what we might hear from other builders. Could you comment on is that a function of where you initially underwr
componenttext: And then I guess related to the differential of new communities purchase in ‘09 and later, that 200 to 300 basis points seems to be lower than what we might hear from other builders. Could you comment on is that a function of where you initially underwrote it at a tighter range? Did it come in and I guess kind of related to the first question of profitability, do you think your DTA can come back next year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the new communities we’ve been consistently seeing 200 to 300 basis points for two years. We started doing our new communities almost two years ago and have a significant history of closings on those communities, and it’s become a significant porti
componenttext:
On the new communities we’ve been consistently seeing 200 to 300 basis points for two years. We started doing our new communities almost two years ago and have a significant history of closings on those communities, and it’s become a significant portion of our business. So, we’re confident that that’s a good level. Certainly some do better than that, some may be a little lower than that, but that’s our average, and so I’m confident in our history and we’ll see over time whether other builders’ new communities contributed a similar level or better.
And I think the point is we do have a track record on our older communities, our newer communities I should say. And the other builders are just now beginning to enter into a lot of new deals or some new deals. So, I think we certainly have a better track record and our 200 to 300 basis points is probably a lot more accurate than you’re receiving from some.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other thing I’d say on our existing communities is they’re not static either, and we continue to renegotiate the costs, redesign the product, and do everything we can to bring the cost down on those, improve the margins on those, at the same time
componenttext: The other thing I’d say on our existing communities is they’re not static either, and we continue to renegotiate the costs, redesign the product, and do everything we can to bring the cost down on those, improve the margins on those, at the same time we’re layering in the higher margins from the options. And that’s all reflected in our 17% to 18% margin that we’ve been running this year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, clearly if our margins improved by 400 basis points versus last year, that did not come from new communities. Our existing communities improved their margins as well. So, while the gap may be only 200 to 300, both levels are rising. And you also ask a
componenttext:
So, clearly if our margins improved by 400 basis points versus last year, that did not come from new communities. Our existing communities improved their margins as well. So, while the gap may be only 200 to 300, both levels are rising. And you also ask about the DTA, Deferred Tax Asset, it’s a little over $900 million right now.
The analysis of whether and when that might come on will be solely dependent, largely dependent on our profitability, the ability for us to have sustained substantial profitability and our expectations for forward profitability. So, that will be dependent on our ability to execute on our goal and our plan to be profitable in fiscal 2011, and we’ll be evaluating that as we move through the year. We can’t say anything definitive about that right now until we show a consistent profitable record.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Oppenheim with Credit Suisse. Please state your question.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Oppenheim with Credit Suisse. Please state your question.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much. I was wondering if you can just talk about your thoughts on community count. You said that, the community count will be dependent on the market and the sales, others trying to bring on new communities to effectively offset the tougher co
componenttext: Thanks very much. I was wondering if you can just talk about your thoughts on community count. You said that, the community count will be dependent on the market and the sales, others trying to bring on new communities to effectively offset the tougher conditions. Is your thought that there is effectively too much supply out there as it is and why deal with that, and so can you, just talk about your thoughts there?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, not really Dan. I tell you what it mainly surrounds us is the willingness of the sellers, whether they be banks or developers to write their lots down to current market conditions and we’ve had a lot of institutions who have been unwilling to mark t
componenttext: No, not really Dan. I tell you what it mainly surrounds us is the willingness of the sellers, whether they be banks or developers to write their lots down to current market conditions and we’ve had a lot of institutions who have been unwilling to mark their lots to the price that really is the market price. So, it’s more of, getting a logjam undone and many lenders, relative to our ability to bring on those new communities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s really it’s already been a focus for us. It’s up to 49% of our sales this quarter, and we’ll continue to focus on it as far as incremental increase, but we are clearly just as focused on it because it’s important to our business going forwa
componenttext:
It’s really it’s already been a focus for us. It’s up to 49% of our sales this quarter, and we’ll continue to focus on it as far as incremental increase, but we are clearly just as focused on it because it’s important to our business going forward. It’s a function too, and our division Presidents and our regional Presidents on our land act people spend a lot of time with banks, and the first time you go in to discuss with the bank, a foreclosed asset, they are typically in denial or they don’t have the capital that they want to use to write down the loan to get the lots at the market price.
So, it takes a while, sometimes it takes a year, before they are willing to deal with it. And at that point in time, as I said earlier, without a doubt, based upon our performance over the last couple of years, in these foreclosed communities. We’re the preeminent buyer in the marketplace today.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, just wondering, you were talking about the specs and you’ve done a great job in the past in terms of managing the specs and delivering the order growth while observing margins. Your comments in terms of the weaker demand while still g
componenttext: And then secondly, just wondering, you were talking about the specs and you’ve done a great job in the past in terms of managing the specs and delivering the order growth while observing margins. Your comments in terms of the weaker demand while still going after the buyers, is this especially you’re not going after too much in terms of demand right now thinking there is too much worry in terms of hitting margins here. What’s the thought there?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, we continually adjust our specs as well as inventory relative to the demand that we see on a go forward basis. So clearly we have been reducing our unit inventory, we’ve been reducing our specs because as we said earlier we expect our sales in
componenttext:
Actually, we continually adjust our specs as well as inventory relative to the demand that we see on a go forward basis. So clearly we have been reducing our unit inventory, we’ve been reducing our specs because as we said earlier we expect our sales in closings to be less in 2011 than they were in 2010.
So clearly, we’re adjusting that inventory in accordance of what we think is going to happen as Don Horton said, one think we can do is we can start them quickly and we can get them build quickly so to the extent that the demand exceeds where our current inventory level is which is based upon lower number than perhaps what could be out there next year. We’re well prepared to meet the demand because we can’t build them quickly.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: We feel like our inventory levels were sufficient to meet our expectations right now.
componenttext: We feel like our inventory levels were sufficient to meet our expectations right now.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks very much.
componenttext: Great, thanks very much.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jonathan Ellis with Bank of America-Merrill Lynch. Please state your question.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jonathan Ellis with Bank of America-Merrill Lynch. Please state your question.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. First question, just on what happened this quarter and looking forward with respect to pricing and use of incentives, I appreciate the commentary on that fact that mix benefited pricing this quarter. I guess as you think through the gross margi
componenttext: Thank you. First question, just on what happened this quarter and looking forward with respect to pricing and use of incentives, I appreciate the commentary on that fact that mix benefited pricing this quarter. I guess as you think through the gross margin pressures to come and mechanizing that pricing on your orders was fairly stable quarter-over-quarter. Is it possible that more of the incentives could be coming below the price line in the form of closing cost or free options or upgrades things that would impact margin more than the price? So basically the question is could you see a scenario play out where pricing holds fairly stable over the next few quarters where margins may come under pressure?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly that’s our goal is to hold pricing stable in all of our communities and to the extent that we need to incentivize our homes to be sold at a faster pace, we like to do that below the line as opposed to above the line.
componenttext: Well, certainly that’s our goal is to hold pricing stable in all of our communities and to the extent that we need to incentivize our homes to be sold at a faster pace, we like to do that below the line as opposed to above the line.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: As of right now, you’re fairly comfortable that you should be able to achieve that over next few quarters?
componenttext: As of right now, you’re fairly comfortable that you should be able to achieve that over next few quarters?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let’s back up.
componenttext: Yes, let’s back up.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are going to be two things that impact our average sales price; one would be just absolute pricing pressure, which as Don said our first response to that is going to be to offer additional incentives because we do want to try to hold on to our base
componenttext:
There are going to be two things that impact our average sales price; one would be just absolute pricing pressure, which as Don said our first response to that is going to be to offer additional incentives because we do want to try to hold on to our base pricing.
The other thing that we’re continuing to do that was we’re opening new communities with lower lot cost. That is letting us continue to offer new product at lower prices than in some of the current communities that it has opened. So you could see some change in our pricing going forward as a combination of those two factors.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Also if you look at our stick and brick cost, this quarter, we were down 320 bps on stick and brick and one of the things that we’ve done over the last two years consistently has continued to drive down those stick and brick cost. I just came at a South
componenttext:
Also if you look at our stick and brick cost, this quarter, we were down 320 bps on stick and brick and one of the things that we’ve done over the last two years consistently has continued to drive down those stick and brick cost. I just came at a Southeast Florida where we had a vendor meeting with our Southeast Florida division and we have that in Southwest Florida, we have them in a number of communities.
I would tell you we were frank with our vendors, we appreciated them having cooperated with us over the last couple of years. To the extent that the market’s softer on a go-forward basis, we’re going to be expecting better pricing and more concessions from our vendors because we’re all in this together. We’re trying to get to the point where we all are going to see profitability but the only way we can do that is to continue to meet the market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the second question, if you could offer up any guidance for what you think the percentage of deliveries closings next year will be from recently purchased lots?And then a related question is, I’ve heard you talk about the 200 to 300 basis poi
componenttext:
And then the second question, if you could offer up any guidance for what you think the percentage of deliveries closings next year will be from recently purchased lots?
And then a related question is, I’ve heard you talk about the 200 to 300 basis point margin spread for at least the last few quarters, I guess, given your commentary about some of your competitors perhaps putting more spec inventory into the market and potential challenges in this spring selling season and next year, I guess, why are you still comfortable or confident that you can maintain that margin spread over your legacy communities. Why would you not see just as much pricing pressure perhaps or more in newer communities that may narrow that spread?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, one thing that we’re going to continue to do is to continue to add new communities at current market pricing or so to the extent that the market gets softer, we’re going to be negotiating better finished lot prices. Also, we consistently renegot
componenttext:
Well, one thing that we’re going to continue to do is to continue to add new communities at current market pricing or so to the extent that the market gets softer, we’re going to be negotiating better finished lot prices. Also, we consistently renegotiate our existing rolling option contracts, and that’s one of the beauties of a rolling option contract is we don’t own the lots, someone else owns them, and to the extent our gross margins get compressed before we do the next takedown, we’re back renegotiating the lot price downward. I’m personally approving all the lot contracts and all the renegotiation. So, I can tell you we see a lot of renegotiated contracts there.
Additionally, I would say to you that we are going to put pressure on our vendors, and they have supported us throughout the years, and especially since we’re such a significant portion of every market, our vendors are very focused on additional business, and as we continue to aggregate market share in each one of our divisions, then we are going to be able to get price concessions from them.
Just as an example, I just noticed the other day that we got something out of Las Vegas where we are the largest builder in Las Vegas with 14.2% of the market share. I was in Southeast Florida where a year ago we had five communities. We’re going to have 20 communities by the end of this calendar year, and 25 communities by midyear next year.
In Southwest Florida, we had 7 communities two years ago, and now we have 34 communities. So, if anyone has the opportunity to continue to put pricing pressure on the land sellers and the lot sellers and the vendors, it’s someone who is doing the volume in those markets to the extent that we are.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one distinction, the 200 to 300 basis points spread between newer communities and legacy communities is simply the spread in their margins. Competitive market pressures effect both new communities and legacy communities, and so both of them if they a
componenttext: Just one distinction, the 200 to 300 basis points spread between newer communities and legacy communities is simply the spread in their margins. Competitive market pressures effect both new communities and legacy communities, and so both of them if they are under pressure would move in the same direction, but we would still expect the spread to be better on our newer communities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: With option contracts if we see significant price movements, we still have opportunities to go back and renegotiate those lot costs.
componenttext: With option contracts if we see significant price movements, we still have opportunities to go back and renegotiate those lot costs.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just the earlier question was, do you have a guidance for percentage of deliveries or closings from recently purchased land for ‘11?
componenttext: Just the earlier question was, do you have a guidance for percentage of deliveries or closings from recently purchased land for ‘11?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our recent sales in the most recent quarter were up to 49% of our business. We expect that to continue to grow. It’s now become a core part of our business, will continue to be a core part of our business, and so we expect that to continue to grow
componenttext: Well, our recent sales in the most recent quarter were up to 49% of our business. We expect that to continue to grow. It’s now become a core part of our business, will continue to be a core part of our business, and so we expect that to continue to grow.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you.
componenttext: Okay, thank you.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: (Operator instructions) Our next question comes from Nishu Sood with Deutsche Bank. Please state your question.
componenttext: (Operator instructions) Our next question comes from Nishu Sood with Deutsche Bank. Please state your question.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. I wanted to come back to this somber outlook that is surprising a lot of people I suppose. If I look at what you’re reporting this quarter, I guess I don’t get it. I don’t understand where this incremental somberness comes from, because if I
componenttext:
Thanks. I wanted to come back to this somber outlook that is surprising a lot of people I suppose. If I look at what you’re reporting this quarter, I guess I don’t get it. I don’t understand where this incremental somberness comes from, because if I look at for example, after the post tax credit drop off in April and May, pickup from July through September, and then really normal seasonality from there, pricing it seems as you know has not been great, but has been kind of stable.
Your gross margins, your September quarter was obviously after the post tax credit closings, and it was pretty strong considering especially with all the specs that you moved. So I mean, what am I missing here? I mean, does this really just boil down to a comp issue that last year you had two tax credits in it from a volume perspective, and this year you won’t? So what am I missing here in terms of what’s happening now that is driving this increased level of pessimism from you folks?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe you’re not watching as much Fox news as I watch, and maybe I’m watching too much of it, but to be quite candid with you, I don’t see much on the horizon that would give anybody a great degree of comfort on the financial condition of the countr
componenttext:
Maybe you’re not watching as much Fox news as I watch, and maybe I’m watching too much of it, but to be quite candid with you, I don’t see much on the horizon that would give anybody a great degree of comfort on the financial condition of the country. I see still high unemployment. I see very lackluster job growth or no job growth. We see continued high unemployment, and I see corporations sitting with over $1 trillion in cash.
So perhaps I am more somber than they, but they obviously are voting with their pocket book because we’re all keeping a lot of cash on our balance sheets until we have some future that’s been driven by the government that says hey, here’s what the rules are and you can go forward and play for the next three years to five years, and here’s what the rules are.
We don’t know what the rules are, and we’re by virtue of who we are and our experience of business is a little more adept at dealing with that, but if you’re a consumer out there and you’re working at Boeing, or you’re working at Microsoft, you are working in one of those companies and you see what’s going on in the economy, I don’t know how you can have any confidence that you are going to have a job tomorrow because people are still being laid off.
So our somber outlook is one that perhaps I’d call it realistic, it’s no job growth, high unemployment, and tremendous amount of debt in this country which is focusing on are we going to have issues going forward, which I think we will with our debt. So until those major factors are fixed in the economy, I don’t think any business can have any great assurance as to what’s going to happen in the future.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got it. Now that makes a lot of sense. So I guess to frame it in terms of what you are not saying, you are not saying that you saw a dramatic drop-off in demand which has driven you to be more pessimistic. You are not saying that you’ve seen pricing fal
componenttext: Got it. Now that makes a lot of sense. So I guess to frame it in terms of what you are not saying, you are not saying that you saw a dramatic drop-off in demand which has driven you to be more pessimistic. You are not saying that you’ve seen pricing fall apart. You’re basically saying that, as you look, in the past two years which benefited from some government stimulus and a lot of uncertainty going forward, it sounds more like a macro statement as opposed to those other things which you’re not saying?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely yes. This company is positioned today better than any company or industry to deal, whether it would be somber, realistic or optimistic come the spring selling season. I’m just dealing what the macro issues, and the macro issues I think have a
componenttext: Absolutely yes. This company is positioned today better than any company or industry to deal, whether it would be somber, realistic or optimistic come the spring selling season. I’m just dealing what the macro issues, and the macro issues I think have a bigger impact on our industry than any of the other factors that are involved.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks a lot.
componenttext: Okay, thanks a lot.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010

componenttext: Our next question comes from Stephen East with Ticonderoga. Please state your question.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. DT, thanks for that because that’s exactly what I was driving toward as well, whether you are seeing something in your order trends that made you change your mind. Are you seeing any shift among buyers? Are you seeing a shift from entry level to
componenttext: Thanks. DT, thanks for that because that’s exactly what I was driving toward as well, whether you are seeing something in your order trends that made you change your mind. Are you seeing any shift among buyers? Are you seeing a shift from entry level toward move up, anything like that that’s going on in the market?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Subsequent to that question of tax credit, we have seen our first time homebuyers now into the high 40% instead of in the 50% to 55% range. So, we have seen a little bit of that. We’re still seeing the strongest demand from the first time homebuyers sim
componenttext: Subsequent to that question of tax credit, we have seen our first time homebuyers now into the high 40% instead of in the 50% to 55% range. So, we have seen a little bit of that. We’re still seeing the strongest demand from the first time homebuyers simply because they don’t have some of the hurdles in terms of selling existing home before they can move into another home.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you just remind us when you would start seeing your first indications of the spring selling season?
componenttext: Could you just remind us when you would start seeing your first indications of the spring selling season?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, Super Bowl Sunday, but as Horton and I were talking the other day, it’s going to be end of February, most likely end of March before we can really ascertain whether there has been any spring selling season.
componenttext: Well, clearly, Super Bowl Sunday, but as Horton and I were talking the other day, it’s going to be end of February, most likely end of March before we can really ascertain whether there has been any spring selling season.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks.
componenttext: Okay, thanks.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Carl Reichardt with Wells Fargo Securities. Please state your question.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Carl Reichardt with Wells Fargo Securities. Please state your question.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, I have a legitimate business question. Stacey, last quarter we’ve talked about this quarter being a potentially profitable, but a challenge, and one of the issues was focused on backlog turnover, and your backlog turnover was close to 100% this qua
componenttext: Hey, I have a legitimate business question. Stacey, last quarter we’ve talked about this quarter being a potentially profitable, but a challenge, and one of the issues was focused on backlog turnover, and your backlog turnover was close to 100% this quarter and actually that way pretty much to the year. What you’re thinking about 2011, are we going to continue to see you turn your backlog at close 100% a quarter is that going to slow up?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: It’s hard to say that we achieved 100% in Q4, which is typically our highest backlog conversion, at other times we exceeded 100%, this fiscal year were typically quarters where we had tax credit expirations either in the quarter or eminent. So, it’s h
componenttext: It’s hard to say that we achieved 100% in Q4, which is typically our highest backlog conversion, at other times we exceeded 100%, this fiscal year were typically quarters where we had tax credit expirations either in the quarter or eminent. So, it’s hard to say that we will continue to see that. We have seen though continued high percentage of our home closings come from specs, which can be a shorter contract to close process, and we do continue to have those homes available to that can keep our conversion rate elevated, but in terms of giving you definite answer on what we can achieve going forward is difficult to do.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Don, going back to your thought process on market share gains are there some specific regions of the country or mature areas maybe two or three where you think the gain potential for you guys is most great. I know you’re going to say it’s pre
componenttext: And then Don, going back to your thought process on market share gains are there some specific regions of the country or mature areas maybe two or three where you think the gain potential for you guys is most great. I know you’re going to say it’s pretty much everywhere, but I would like you to focus, two or three that where you think the opportunity is the best?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly I think Florida has been really a great story for us over the course of the last 12 months to 18 months. I also look at Texas because of the fact that in Texas there are a lot of rolling option opportunities here more so than elsewhere and c
componenttext:
Well, clearly I think Florida has been really a great story for us over the course of the last 12 months to 18 months. I also look at Texas because of the fact that in Texas there are a lot of rolling option opportunities here more so than elsewhere and clearly Texas is our home and Texas continues to be a very profitable market for us and we have some very good operators here. We also have some very good operators in Florida.
Ironically, I look at our position in Las Vegas and Las Vegas is really a marginal market and we’ve got a Division President out there in Scott Stone has a great team and we continue to take market share in Las Vegas in really, really sad market. I think that also that we have opportunities in the Atlanta market and we have a good operator there, but those are really where I see some of our best market opportunities in big markets where we can continue to take market share.

componenttext: Appreciate it, thanks, guys.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, thanks for taking the question guys. Most of my questions have been answered, just two quick ones. Can you talk about, your subprime process in ‘06 and ‘07 and how that’s really changed for today and the sales mix in terms of the financing JC ve
componenttext: Hi, thanks for taking the question guys. Most of my questions have been answered, just two quick ones. Can you talk about, your subprime process in ‘06 and ‘07 and how that’s really changed for today and the sales mix in terms of the financing JC versus otherwise private label in that time period and then a follow-up?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Basically, subprime was available. There were investors who were interested in buying subprime product and so our mortgage company originated subprime in ‘05 and ‘06. The subprime and Alt-A combined essentially replaced the governmental lending in ter
componenttext: Basically, subprime was available. There were investors who were interested in buying subprime product and so our mortgage company originated subprime in ‘05 and ‘06. The subprime and Alt-A combined essentially replaced the governmental lending in terms of percentages. So, government had been 50% to 60% of our business prior to the availability of subprime and Alt-A, Alt-A and subprime grew while government shrank. And then there are no investors today buying either subprime or Alt-A. Most of the mortgage investors are looking for full documentation with the implicit guarantee of the U.S. Government behind it. So the government portion of our loans has grown again to 66% this quarter.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you say government, are you including FHA in that total?
componenttext: When you say government, are you including FHA in that total?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: FHA is in there. It’s usually in about the mid-40% range, and then the balance of that is going to be VA.
componenttext: FHA is in there. It’s usually in about the mid-40% range, and then the balance of that is going to be VA.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, good morning.
componenttext: Hey, good morning.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010

componenttext: ASPs for fiscal ‘11, I know, it’s been a little over the map this year because of mix shift, but the land that you’re buying now, what should we expect for ASPs in ‘11?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010

componenttext: I would expect our ASPs to be flat to slightly up.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I agree with your commentary about inflation being the looming problem in front of us, but how soon or what should we expect in terms of it showing up in your stick and brick cost. I mean, you said it was down 320 bps this year, but how long do y
componenttext: And then I agree with your commentary about inflation being the looming problem in front of us, but how soon or what should we expect in terms of it showing up in your stick and brick cost. I mean, you said it was down 320 bps this year, but how long do you think you’re going to be able to sustain that if we do see a sharp pickup in inflation?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Don has addressed a lot of that just in terms of, as long as the top line continues to be soft for us and we see continued margin pressure, we’re going to be back negotiating. We cannot accept price increases right now, so there has been a lot o
componenttext: I think Don has addressed a lot of that just in terms of, as long as the top line continues to be soft for us and we see continued margin pressure, we’re going to be back negotiating. We cannot accept price increases right now, so there has been a lot of talk about increases in commodities. I think we’ve had some talk around inflation in paint. But we have price protection in all of those categories in most of our markets, and so we’re going to negotiate very aggressively even in the markets where we don’t just based on our volume. So we’ve heard a lot about price increases over the last year, and in general, we’re able to hold the line on our pricing, and we’ll continue to do that until we can sell our end product for a greater price.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if we think that what happens in the marketplace where we have softer sales and softer closings for the industry on a go forward basis, I think a lot of these even if there are inflationary pressures from our vendors on commodities, I think it’s goi
componenttext: And if we think that what happens in the marketplace where we have softer sales and softer closings for the industry on a go forward basis, I think a lot of these even if there are inflationary pressures from our vendors on commodities, I think it’s going to be a difficult time for them to push those through based upon the slowing demand both on the sales and the closings.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Morning, guys. Most of my questions have been answered, but I definitely had to say go Giants before you get off the phone. No matter how long you made me wait. But real quick I do have one question which is I’ve heard from some other builders, and Don,
componenttext: Morning, guys. Most of my questions have been answered, but I definitely had to say go Giants before you get off the phone. No matter how long you made me wait. But real quick I do have one question which is I’ve heard from some other builders, and Don, you kind of mentioned it a little bit earlier, but just if you could give a little more color on it. This idea that pricing right now for consumers, because it’s much more of a confidence question than anything else and people just don’t feel comfortable going out and buying a house that pricing for homes is fairly inelastic, and I’m wondering if you can comment on whether or not you agree with that and how much that impacts your decisions going forward about pricing and incentives, and if that offers some measure of margin protection for you guys knowing that people are going to kind of come out of the woodwork when they’re going to come out of the woodwork and there’s not a whole lot on pricing that you can do to affect that or if you think that’s a wrong way to look at it?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think pricing is inelastic. We talk to our sales people, Horton and I do on a daily basis, and our sales managers, and there’s just not a lot that we can do to continue to sell homes, increase our sales base relative to the traffic that we’ve
componenttext:
Well, I think pricing is inelastic. We talk to our sales people, Horton and I do on a daily basis, and our sales managers, and there’s just not a lot that we can do to continue to sell homes, increase our sales base relative to the traffic that we’ve got. Now we’ve got a lot of plans for this year as we did for last year to increase our traffic vis-à-vis sales events that we had last year, and we’ve got plans for those in each one of our divisions, in our regions, in the country and also on a nationwide basis.
I think the way that we continue to handle the softness is by virtue of offering incentives so we can maintain our pricing structure in most all of our communities, because the last thing we really want to do is to enter into a decrease in our prices. Basically, we’d prefer to offer that on the incentive side.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, guys. Appreciate it, thank you.
componenttext: Great, guys. Appreciate it, thank you.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Leon with Standard & Poor’s. Please state your question.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Leon with Standard & Poor’s. Please state your question.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. There’s such a high concentration in the Southeast and South Central markets, and can you speak to those markets first in terms of the first time buyer and whether compared to past cycles, what’s going to give you more confidence than anyth
componenttext: Thank you. There’s such a high concentration in the Southeast and South Central markets, and can you speak to those markets first in terms of the first time buyer and whether compared to past cycles, what’s going to give you more confidence than anything more specific than just saying confidence or jobs, employment?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly as I was reading the other day, when you talk the about the South and the South Central and the Southeast, one of our strongest markets is Texas, and as I was reading the report, I think it was Perry’s report or something like that out of
componenttext:
Well, clearly as I was reading the other day, when you talk the about the South and the South Central and the Southeast, one of our strongest markets is Texas, and as I was reading the report, I think it was Perry’s report or something like that out of Waco, just talking about how the 380,000 jobs have been generated over the last decade or something like that, it’s all been in Texas.
So, clearly, we believe that Texas is a fantastic state. They have acquired a lot of corporations. We continue to get corporations moving in from California and other parts of the country. So, I think Texas will continue to be a very strong market for us both in terms of just relocations as well as job growth within the state.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just staying again on Southeast or South Central and you had positive comments, congratulations on building more communities in Florida at a lower cost and higher return, but foreclosures are substantial, and it’s an overhang that’s going to be there
componenttext: Just staying again on Southeast or South Central and you had positive comments, congratulations on building more communities in Florida at a lower cost and higher return, but foreclosures are substantial, and it’s an overhang that’s going to be there for a few years. So relative to other builders, national builders do you feel that you could be successful and still gain share?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I do and one of those reasons is that because we are penetrating our markets and we are tying up finished lots in almost all of those communities. So we have more flags in those communities than other builders.In terms of the foreclosures, we deal
componenttext:
Yes, I do and one of those reasons is that because we are penetrating our markets and we are tying up finished lots in almost all of those communities. So we have more flags in those communities than other builders.
In terms of the foreclosures, we deal with foreclosures in virtually every market every day. We believe we offer a very competitively priced product, a new product with a warranty on it vis-à-vis the foreclosures. In addition, to us, ours is a seamless process as opposed to very frustrating project trying to buy something from the government or from the bank. So as a result I think we can continue to effectively compete with those foreclosures and not only do I think I know we have to because they are going to be a problem for the industry probably for the next three to four, five years.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, great. Well, thanks so much.
componenttext: Yes, great. Well, thanks so much.

componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: Thanks, Ken.

componenttext: Thank you. Ladies and gentlemen unfortunately we have run out of time for questions. I will now turn the conference back over to management for closing remarks.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you and we appreciate all of you who joined us on our conference call. I want to be certain that everyone understands that we believe that we had a very successful fiscal year 2010 and most importantly, we are prepared to meet whatever the market co
componenttext:
Thank you and we appreciate all of you who joined us on our conference call. I want to be certain that everyone understands that we believe that we had a very successful fiscal year 2010 and most importantly, we are prepared to meet whatever the market conditions are in fiscal 2011.
I can’t thank all of our sales people enough and each one of our communities, because you’ve done a very successful job out there and to all of our construction people who continue to build houses faster, more efficiently and better than ever, thank you. Our vendors, who have continued to support us over the years and we need your support on a go-forward basis to meet the market, we thank you too. We clearly continue and will plan to continue to outperform everyone else in the industry.
D.R. Horton is the largest builder in America for the eighth consecutive year, and our goal clearly is to be largest builder for the ninth consecutive year all the while focusing on the most important aspect of our business and that is profitability. Donald Horton has said this many times, it all starts with the people and I frankly believe we have the best people in the industry and we appreciate the phenomenal job that you have done for us. Thank you very much.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010

componenttext: This concludes today’s conference. All parties may disconnect now.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the D.R. Horton America's Builder, the largest builder in the United States, 2010 fiscal Year-End Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Donald J. Tomnitz, Presi
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the D.R. Horton America's Builder, the largest builder in the United States, 2010 fiscal Year-End Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Donald J. Tomnitz, President and Chief Executive Officer for D.R. Horton. Thank you, Mr. Tomnitz. You may now begin.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Joining me this morning are Bill Wheat, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Stacey Dwyer, Executive Vice President and Treasurer. Before we get started, Stacey?
componenttext: Thank you, and good morning. Joining me this morning are Bill Wheat, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Stacey Dwyer, Executive Vice President and Treasurer. Before we get started, Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010

componenttext:
Some comments made on this call may constitute forward-looking statements as defined by the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Although D.R. Horton believes any such statements are based on reasonable assumptions, there's no assurance that actual outcomes will not be materially different. All forward-looking statements are based upon information available to D.R. Horton on the date of this conference call, and D.R. Horton does not undertake any obligation to publicly update or revise any forward-looking statement.
Additional information about issues that could lead to material changes in performance is contained in D.R. Horton's current report on Form 8-K dated February 8, 2010, which updated our annual report on Form 10-K and our most recent quarterly report on Form 10-Q, all of which are filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Fiscal 2010 was a year of the tax credit. This calls volatile sales and closings, but the year was consistent with our expectations and preparations. While the federal tax credit was in place, we experienced strong sales demand through the April 30 sales
componenttext:
Fiscal 2010 was a year of the tax credit. This calls volatile sales and closings, but the year was consistent with our expectations and preparations. While the federal tax credit was in place, we experienced strong sales demand through the April 30 sales contract deadline, especially from first-time homebuyers. Our closings were strong through the June 30 closing deadline for the tax credit. However, after the tax credit expired, sales demand dropped sharply in May. From June through August, our sales trend showed sequential improvement, and then we began experiencing a normal, seasonal slowdown in September and October. 
Overall, housing demand is weak. Even with significant fluctuations in the level of demand for our homes in fiscal 2010, our approach was very consistent. Manage our homes and inventory to current demand generate cash, reduce debt, position ourselves for profitability and maintain a strong balance sheet to be positioned to take advantage of opportunities.
As we look to fiscal 2011, we continue to be realistic in our expectations and will adjust our business to compete in the current market conditions. We expect another very challenging year for the homebuilding industry as a fundamental drivers of demand. The overall economy, job growth and consumer confidence are still very weak. In addition, we do not expect any stimulus in fiscal 2011 similar to the federal tax credits that were in effect last year. All of these factors make it likely that our sales and closing volumes will be below our volumes in fiscal 2010. 
However, we plan to continue to gain market share by opening new communities and adjusting our price points and product offerings due to demand we see in each of our individual markets. I want to congratulate each member of the D.R. Horton team for turning in a strong performance in fiscal 2010 despite continued difficult industry conditions. We appreciate very much your efforts. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our net loss for the quarter was $8.9 million or $0.03 per diluted share compared to a net loss of $234.9 million or $0.74 per diluted share in the prior year quarter. Homebuilding pretax loss were $6.5 million, which included $30.8 million of inventory i
componenttext: Our net loss for the quarter was $8.9 million or $0.03 per diluted share compared to a net loss of $234.9 million or $0.74 per diluted share in the prior year quarter. Homebuilding pretax loss were $6.5 million, which included $30.8 million of inventory impairments and lot option charges. Financial services pretax income was $4.8 million, which included $2.1 million of recourse expense. Our fourth quarter income tax provision was $7.2 million due primarily to an increase in our tax reserves. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our fourth quarter home sales revenue decreased 9% to $921 million on 4,281 homes closed from $1 billion on 4,810 homes closed in the year-ago quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was up 2% from the prior year and up 6% sequentially to $215,
componenttext: Our fourth quarter home sales revenue decreased 9% to $921 million on 4,281 homes closed from $1 billion on 4,810 homes closed in the year-ago quarter. Our average closing price for the quarter was up 2% from the prior year and up 6% sequentially to $215,200. The sequential increase was primarily due to a higher percentage of our closings coming from the West region in the fourth quarter versus the third quarter. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Net sales orders for the fourth quarter were down 21% from last year to 3,979 homes. The net sales orders in the prior year quarter included demand from the first-time homebuyer tax credit that was in effect last year. Based on current sales demand and th
componenttext:
Net sales orders for the fourth quarter were down 21% from last year to 3,979 homes. The net sales orders in the prior year quarter included demand from the first-time homebuyer tax credit that was in effect last year. Based on current sales demand and the fact that the tax credits were supporting sales demand last year, we expect sales in the next two quarters to be lower than last year. 
While we remain focused on opening new communities and gaining market share for us to see significant sustainable sales growth, we need to see improvements in the overall economy, the jobs landscape and consumer confidence. In the September quarter, our average sales price on net sales orders was essentially flat year-over-year at $205,500. 
Our cancellation rate was 31%. Our active selling communities were up 6% sequentially. 49% of our net sales came from communities opened in fiscal year 2009 or later. Our sales backlog decreased 27% from the prior year to 4,128 homes or $850.8 million. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the fourth quarter was 17%, up 450 basis points from our home sales margin in the year-ago period. A contributing factor to our margin improvement from last year was at 39% of fourth quarter closings or fro
componenttext:
Our gross profit margin on home sales revenue in the fourth quarter was 17%, up 450 basis points from our home sales margin in the year-ago period. A contributing factor to our margin improvement from last year was at 39% of fourth quarter closings or from new deals that were under contract in fiscal 2009 or later. 
Margins on closings in our new projects are approximately 200 to 300 basis points higher than on the remainder of our closings. Our margin decreased 20 basis points sequentially from the third to the fourth quarter, reflecting a weaker housing market we had experienced during the second half of this year. Although our gross margins have been in the 17% to 18% range each quarter this fiscal year, we expect to experience gross margin pressure over the next few quarters, as we continually adjust to the prevailing market in each of our communities. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: In our fourth quarter impairment analysis, we reviewed all projects in the company and determined that projects with a pre-impairment carrying value of $63.1 million were impaired, which resulted in $29.1 million of impairment charges, the majority of whi
componenttext:
In our fourth quarter impairment analysis, we reviewed all projects in the company and determined that projects with a pre-impairment carrying value of $63.1 million were impaired, which resulted in $29.1 million of impairment charges, the majority of which were in Texas, Florida and Illinois.
We refer to our projects, which have indicators of potential impairment but were not impaired as our watch list, which represents those projects deemed to be at the highest risk for future impairments. Our watch list is currently $346.7 million, similar to the amount at June 30, 2010, with the largest concentrations in California, Illinois and Arizona. Our inventory impairment process in future quarters will incorporate any changes in market conditions and any adjustments we make in our business. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our consistent focus on controlling SG&A has been a key to our return to profitability. We have leveraged our SG&A structure to focus on profitable opportunities in our existing markets with our current division operation. For fiscal 2010, we closed 25% m
componenttext:
Our consistent focus on controlling SG&A has been a key to our return to profitability. We have leveraged our SG&A structure to focus on profitable opportunities in our existing markets with our current division operation. For fiscal 2010, we closed 25% more homes on essentially flat SG&A dollars compared to fiscal 2009. 
Homebuilding SG&A expense for the quarter, which includes all corporate overhead, was $121.8 million or 13.2% of homebuilding revenues compared to 13.3% in the year-ago quarter. Fourth quarter homebuilding SG&A expense was lower than recent quarters due in part to the impact of the $7.9 million reduction in our executive compensation accrual. We will continue to actively manage our SG&A levels relative to our expected number of homes closings. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we are required to directly expense a portion of our interest incurred while our homebuilding debt level exceeds our active inventory, we recorded $17.1 million in homebuilding interest expense during the quarter. This was approximately 47% of the $36.
componenttext:
As we are required to directly expense a portion of our interest incurred while our homebuilding debt level exceeds our active inventory, we recorded $17.1 million in homebuilding interest expense during the quarter. This was approximately 47% of the $36.3 million of homebuilding interest we incurred. 
Our fourth quarter homebuilding interest incurred decreased 31% compared to the prior year, and our homebuilding interest incurred for the entire fiscal year decreased 16% as a result of the debt reductions we achieved this year. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Financial services pretax income for the quarter was $4.8 million compared to a loss of $2.9 million in the year-ago quarter. 83% of our mortgage company's business was captured during the quarter. Our company-wide capture rate was approximately 60%, and
componenttext:
Financial services pretax income for the quarter was $4.8 million compared to a loss of $2.9 million in the year-ago quarter. 83% of our mortgage company's business was captured during the quarter. Our company-wide capture rate was approximately 60%, and our average FICO score was 719 and our average combined loan to value was 90%. 
Our product mix in the quarter was essentially 100% agency eligible with government loans accounting for 63% of our volume. For fiscal 2007 through fiscal 2010, we have recognized recourse expense totaling $94.8 million. Our fiscal 2010 recourse expense was $13.7 million, which is down from $33.2 million in fiscal 2009. The majority of the recourse expense in 2007 and early 2008 related to early payment default provision. Since then, the more significant portion of the recourse expense relates to misrepresentations by the borrower in the loan origination process. Cumulatively through September 30, 2010, we have settled approximately 1,500 mortgage claims, and we are currently evaluating less than 300 additional claims. 
While mortgage claim activity can be volatile from month to month, mortgage claims in the second half of fiscal 2010 declined approximately 23% compared to the first half of the year. Each quarter, we analyze recent trends and claim activity to evaluate reserves for potential future claim exposure. Our reserve balance has currently totaled $39 million with $10.8 million reserves for owned mortgages and foreclosed real estate and $28.2 million for pending and projected claims. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
