componenttextpreview: Our total inventory decreased by approximately $87 million excluding non-cash impairment charges during the quarter. We reduced our homes in inventory by $129 million and increased our investment in residential land and lots and land held for development
componenttext:
Our total inventory decreased by approximately $87 million excluding non-cash impairment charges during the quarter. We reduced our homes in inventory by $129 million and increased our investment in residential land and lots and land held for development by $42 million. 
Our homes in inventory at the end of September totaled 9,500 homes, down 1,300 homes from June. 1,200 of our homes were models, 5,200 were speculative homes and 3,200 of these specs were completed. We continue to manage our total homes in inventory relative to our expectations of sales demand. We offer spec homes primarily to accommodate our first-time homebuyers and relocation homebuyers. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our land and lot purchases remain controlled, and we continue to evaluate our land development plans based on current sales trends. We have been actively contracting for finished lots to increase our active selling communities and increase our gross margi
componenttext:
Our land and lot purchases remain controlled, and we continue to evaluate our land development plans based on current sales trends. We have been actively contracting for finished lots to increase our active selling communities and increase our gross margins. 
In our fourth fiscal quarter, we invested approximately $188 million primarily in finished lots. Our spending on finished lots will remain largely dependent on our sales pace, while our spending on land and development cost will continue to be at relatively low levels. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our supply of owned land and lots at September 30, 2010, was approximately 90,000 lots, of which approximately 23,000 are finished. We control an additional 30,000 lots through option contracts, up 9% from June 30 with a net earnest money deposit balance
componenttext: Our supply of owned land and lots at September 30, 2010, was approximately 90,000 lots, of which approximately 23,000 are finished. We control an additional 30,000 lots through option contracts, up 9% from June 30 with a net earnest money deposit balance for these lots of only $13.3 million. We are focused on managing our supply of owned, finished lots in line with our sales demand in a low-risk capital efficient manner. Stacey?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Cash flow from operations for the September quarter totaled $122.3 million generated by the decrease in homes and inventory and mortgage loans held for sale, offset by our spending on finished lots and development and a decrease in our accounts payable. O
componenttext:
Cash flow from operations for the September quarter totaled $122.3 million generated by the decrease in homes and inventory and mortgage loans held for sale, offset by our spending on finished lots and development and a decrease in our accounts payable. Our fiscal year 2010 cash flow from operations totaled $709.4 million. 
We ended the fiscal year with $1.6 billion of homebuilding cash and marketable securities. The balance of our public notes outstanding at September 30, 2010, was $2.1 billion, and our note maturities in fiscal 2011 and 2012 are $189 million and $146.6 million, respectively. We retired over $1 billion of debt in fiscal 2010, and we have $483.8 million remaining on our debt repurchase authorization at September 30, 2010. Bill?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: At September 30, our homebuilding leverage ratio, net of cash and marketable securities, was 16.1%, a 16.4 percentage point improvement from year ago. Gross homebuilding leverage at September 30 was 44.3%, an 11.9 percentage point improvement from a year
componenttext: At September 30, our homebuilding leverage ratio, net of cash and marketable securities, was 16.1%, a 16.4 percentage point improvement from year ago. Gross homebuilding leverage at September 30 was 44.3%, an 11.9 percentage point improvement from a year ago. These leverage improvements compared to the prior year are due primarily to our cash generation and significant debt reductions. Don?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: In summary, our financial performance this fiscal year demonstrates the progress DHI has made toward achieving profitability, balance sheet strength and market share gains in this challenging and uncertain housing market. Some of our most important acco
componenttext:
In summary, our financial performance this fiscal year demonstrates the progress DHI has made toward achieving profitability, balance sheet strength and market share gains in this challenging and uncertain housing market. 
Some of our most important accomplishments this year include: pretax income totaled $99.5 million; home sales gross margins increased 420 basis points over the prior year, as we improve the cost and design of our products and open new communities on recently acquired lots at higher margins; fully loaded homebuilding SG&A, which includes all of corporate overhead as a percentage of revenues was 12.1%, essentially flat in dollars with fiscal 2009 on a 25% increase at homes closed; cash flow from operations of $709.4 million, bringing our total over the last 17 consecutive quarters to $5.9 billion; over $1 billion in homebuilding debt repurchases and redemptions this fiscal year, contributing to our net homebuilding leverage ratio of 16.1%. There are still challenges in the homebuilding industry: rising foreclosures, significant existing home inventory, high unemployment, tight mortgage lending standards and weak consumer confidence. However, new home inventory remains low, interest rates are favorable and housing affordability is near record highs. 
We, at Horton, will continue to focus on providing affordable homes, controlling our cost, contracting for new communities with attractively priced finished lots and maintaining our strong balance sheet. Again, we want to thank all of our DHI team members to continue to outsell and outperform everyone in the industry. Keep up the great work. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. Now we'll host any questions.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Michael Rehaut with JPMorgan.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question I just had was on community growth. If you could give us a sense of where it was year-over-year for the quarter. And as you look into fiscal '11, we appreciate the comments with regards to expectation for sales and closings to be down.
componenttext: The first question I just had was on community growth. If you could give us a sense of where it was year-over-year for the quarter. And as you look into fiscal '11, we appreciate the comments with regards to expectation for sales and closings to be down. And obviously, you're facing a tough first half comp to say the least. But how do you look at community growth going into next year as obviously offsetting some of that comp and also maybe limiting incremental downside on gross margins to the extent that you still have a positive mix shift into next year as well?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll start and I'm sure Don will jump in in a moment. Our community count year-over-year in terms of exit selling communities was up 17%. Since we look forward into next year, we are continuing to try to fit new communities under option contracts primaril
componenttext: I'll start and I'm sure Don will jump in in a moment. Our community count year-over-year in terms of exit selling communities was up 17%. Since we look forward into next year, we are continuing to try to fit new communities under option contracts primarily rolling option on finished lots. And we would certainly anticipate continuing to increase our exit selling communities that will be offset by some of our current communities rolling off, and our pace of increase in the communities will be dependent on the sales demand that we see.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we think most all of our growth next year, Mike, will come from penetrating our existing markets deeper and taking market share from the other builders who are less, I think, proactive in the markets and more undercapitalized than we. We continue on e
componenttext: And we think most all of our growth next year, Mike, will come from penetrating our existing markets deeper and taking market share from the other builders who are less, I think, proactive in the markets and more undercapitalized than we. We continue on each and every one of our markets to work with the banks and work with the developers to auction lots, which are already finished, which we can put into construction immediately. And those lots are obviously at more favorable prices than many of the lots that we've had over the course of 2005 to 2008.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I appreciate that. So just to follow up just to drill down a little bit. So are you willing to give us a sense of what you think community count might grow next year? Do you think you can still hit this double-digit mark? And secondly, the gross margin
componenttext: So I appreciate that. So just to follow up just to drill down a little bit. So are you willing to give us a sense of what you think community count might grow next year? Do you think you can still hit this double-digit mark? And secondly, the gross margin impact or benefit, does that kind of offset to the extent that you can increase even your percent of closings from new communities? Or do you think that that positive mix shift has largely occurred given you're near 40% right now?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think clearly that our community count will grow just as it did. And our goal, clearly, is to hit double-digit community growth. Whether we do that or not is going to be really dependent upon what deals become available in each of our markets. One
componenttext: Well, I think clearly that our community count will grow just as it did. And our goal, clearly, is to hit double-digit community growth. Whether we do that or not is going to be really dependent upon what deals become available in each of our markets. One of the things that we've realized is in certain of our markets, we saw no opportunities or very few opportunities a year ago. And all of a sudden, we're beginning to see more and more communities. And simply, that's a reflection of the banks and the developers dealing with the current market conditions and being honest with themselves about what the real market price of those lots are. As far as the gross margin, I believe that our gross margins have some potential to come under pressure come this spring, irrespective of the fact that we continue to bring on new communities with higher gross margins, simply because we're not right now projecting a huge spring bump. It's uncertain on what's going to happen on the spring, and certainly other builders have brought on what we think are additional specs late in the market post the tax credit. And we believe that to the extent that there's not a significant spring bump, there could be some gross margin deterioration come spring.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And clearly, part of our strategy and continuing to add new communities at today's prices is to help mitigate that margin pressure. We still continue to see higher margins in the range of 200 to 300 basis points on our new communities. The communities tha
componenttext: And clearly, part of our strategy and continuing to add new communities at today's prices is to help mitigate that margin pressure. We still continue to see higher margins in the range of 200 to 300 basis points on our new communities. The communities that we contracted since 2009 are now almost half of our business. So that's becoming really a core part of our business. And so we will continue to do that to help offset the margin pressure that we're seeing in the market. But on the whole, we will not be surprised to see some pressure on margins in a downward fashion in the coming quarters.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And really, on conclusion on that, I'd like to say is that to the extent that Horton has been proactive earlier than any other builder in terms of securing these option contracts, we've proven beyond any reasonable doubt amongst the sellers, the banks as
componenttext: And really, on conclusion on that, I'd like to say is that to the extent that Horton has been proactive earlier than any other builder in terms of securing these option contracts, we've proven beyond any reasonable doubt amongst the sellers, the banks as well as the lot owners that one, we are there; and two, we are performing; and three, we are putting specs on their lots and working their way through their lots at a faster pace. So I believe as I travel through all these markets, as D.R. does, we are definitely the pre-eminent desired buyer of lots in each and every market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Megan McGrath with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Megan McGrath with Barclays Capital.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on that last conversation a little bit more in terms of your expectation for the spring. Clearly, not a lot of visibility yet, but is there a desire to exit these old communities faster, and that's where you think some of this pri
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on that last conversation a little bit more in terms of your expectation for the spring. Clearly, not a lot of visibility yet, but is there a desire to exit these old communities faster, and that's where you think some of this pricing pressure will come from? Or generally, do you just think across the board, you're going to have to make up for lower volume with across-the-board price cut even in some of these new communities?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great job on CNBC this morning. I thought you did a great presentation. Would we like exit our older communities faster? Yes, we've been focusing on that for quite some time. And obviously, the basis in those older communities doesn't afford us the opport
componenttext: Great job on CNBC this morning. I thought you did a great presentation. Would we like exit our older communities faster? Yes, we've been focusing on that for quite some time. And obviously, the basis in those older communities doesn't afford us the opportunity to exit those clearly as possible. But clearly, we're focusing on adding the new communities. And as Stacey said, we're 200 to 300 basis points higher in our gross margin on newer communities. And to the extent that we can continue to add those, yes, I think it will offset what we anticipate to be some margin compression come the spring, unless there's a stronger spring market than what we're anticipating right now. And with the job growth, where it is; consumer confidence, where it is, I just don't see a lot of hopes for a great spring market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: A little depressing. But stepping back a little bit, Rutherford 2011, can you maybe just give us an idea of any sort of corporate goals that you're willing to share whether profitability or what you're telling your sales folks in terms of what they should
componenttext: A little depressing. But stepping back a little bit, Rutherford 2011, can you maybe just give us an idea of any sort of corporate goals that you're willing to share whether profitability or what you're telling your sales folks in terms of what they should focus on for next fiscal year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. As I tell our salespeople as I travel around the country, if they're warm and have a pulse, write them, and then we'll create about qualifying them. But I think that we need to clearly take the buyers out of the market. We have the best pricing in th
componenttext: Yes. As I tell our salespeople as I travel around the country, if they're warm and have a pulse, write them, and then we'll create about qualifying them. But I think that we need to clearly take the buyers out of the market. We have the best pricing in the industry, the most speculative inventory that's available for immediate move in in the industry. So our focus on our salespeople is you write them, and then we'll figure out whether or not we can get them qualified. But most importantly, what this company has always focused on, Megan, and we continue to focus on everyday that we get up and that is, how do we consistently turn a profit in this company. So the sales is working, says nothing happens until we sell something. But the reality of life is we have to sell these houses at a profit, and our focus is clearly how do we consistently be profitable in this corporation.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Josh Levin with Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Josh Levin with Citi.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Given your looking to be a fairly weak outlook for 2011, are you exploring more significant SG&A cuts in the quarters ahead? I'm not talking about just trimming fast but really trying to cut bone again.
componenttext: Given your looking to be a fairly weak outlook for 2011, are you exploring more significant SG&A cuts in the quarters ahead? I'm not talking about just trimming fast but really trying to cut bone again.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's get back to the bleak outlook. I think what we're telling you is what we see out there based upon the current economic conditions, but don't get confused. We have been, and we currently are, the best-positioned builder from an SG&A perspective, a le
componenttext: Let's get back to the bleak outlook. I think what we're telling you is what we see out there based upon the current economic conditions, but don't get confused. We have been, and we currently are, the best-positioned builder from an SG&A perspective, a leverage perspective, shareholders' equity perspective to continue to deal better with the existing market, whatever maybe relative to our competition. As far as SG&A cuts, yes, we have already identified with our regional presidents additional SG&A cuts to the extent that the sales do not materialize in accordance with our five-year plan for fiscal year '11. So, yes, I think those SG&A cuts will be more difficult than what they've been in the past, but we definitely have identified additional cuts that need to be made if the sales do not materialize.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're talking about sales being kind of flattish, not seeing a bump. You're talking about margin pressure, some margins compressing, but your impairment watch list didn't really go up. How do we reconcile all those facts? I mean...
componenttext: You're talking about sales being kind of flattish, not seeing a bump. You're talking about margin pressure, some margins compressing, but your impairment watch list didn't really go up. How do we reconcile all those facts? I mean...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it really comes down to -- what we're really dealing with is our current margins are still about 17%. And so we haven't seen a significant reduction in our margins yet. We do expect some pressure. And so we certainly did add some projects to the lis
componenttext: Well, it really comes down to -- what we're really dealing with is our current margins are still about 17%. And so we haven't seen a significant reduction in our margins yet. We do expect some pressure. And so we certainly did add some projects to the list this quarter. But at the same time, we did impair a number of projects this quarter as well. So on a net basis, the list did not increase this quarter, but that's something we will continue to evaluate each quarter as we move into fiscal 2011. And by the way, Josh, that's an important point. We're sitting with a 17% gross margin. Most of our competitors would be very happy to be facing what may be a bleak outlook in the spring with a 17% gross margin versus what they have.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from David Goldberg with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from David Goldberg with UBS.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question I have is, Don, I think you gave some great detail on some of the issues that are facing demand pool. But I'm wondering if you could talk about timing. I don't want to say rank them. What I'm trying to get to is the problem to market to
componenttext: The first question I have is, Don, I think you gave some great detail on some of the issues that are facing demand pool. But I'm wondering if you could talk about timing. I don't want to say rank them. What I'm trying to get to is the problem to market today is there's just a lot of buyers that might want to buy a house but can't qualify that they don't have a down payment or they don't have a FICO score? So how would you weigh the ability to qualify for a loan even with 1.25% 30-year fixed rate mortgages and only 3.5% down payments relative to selling my confidence in terms of what's inhibiting demand today?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say our biggest problem is not quantifying our buyers. The biggest problem right now is consumer confidence and the number of unemployed people out there. As we always say, it's hard to sell a home to an unemployed person. But the real key is that
componenttext: I would say our biggest problem is not quantifying our buyers. The biggest problem right now is consumer confidence and the number of unemployed people out there. As we always say, it's hard to sell a home to an unemployed person. But the real key is that the traffic count in our subdivisions is down, and I don't think there's a lot of pricing adjustment that we can do. It's just a function on the lack of traffic. So until there's some consumer confidence, until we start to grow jobs, I think we're going to continue to be faced with rather flat demand just simply because buyers don't feel confident about the future, and they're not going out there looking for a house and the numbers that they were certainly when the tax credits were there.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: But they're going to pull potential buyers. I mean, if people who can qualify could if they wanted to buy a home.
componenttext: But they're going to pull potential buyers. I mean, if people who can qualify could if they wanted to buy a home.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there's a huge pool of buyers out there. But again, and that pool, is less than what it was a year ago with unemployment where it is and the lack of job growth. But again, those people don't have the confidence a purchase today is going to be rewa
componenttext: I think there's a huge pool of buyers out there. But again, and that pool, is less than what it was a year ago with unemployment where it is and the lack of job growth. But again, those people don't have the confidence a purchase today is going to be rewarding. Although I will tell you that as I have keep telling people and I've been an example of this myself, I don't think there's ever been a better time in the history, my history in the homebuilding industry, with affordability and pricing where it is today to buy a home. And if you think that we're going to have inflation in this country, which I don't know how we cannot have with all the money we're printing, hard assets like a home are going to be the very best investment that you can make.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just for a follow up, Stacey, the comment that you made on claims, I'm wondering if we could focus, not on the mortgage-backed side, but just on the warranty side. Is it correct to say you haven't really seen the pickup pick up in claims on a war
componenttext: And then just for a follow up, Stacey, the comment that you made on claims, I'm wondering if we could focus, not on the mortgage-backed side, but just on the warranty side. Is it correct to say you haven't really seen the pickup pick up in claims on a warranty side that maybe some of your peers have talked about this quarter or over the last couple of quarters?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: That would be a fair statement. We have not seen anything and currently unusual in our warranty claims. We'll have full disclosure around our warranty reserves in our 10-K, but I think you'll see or count our typical role forward of our royalty claim.
componenttext: That would be a fair statement. We have not seen anything and currently unusual in our warranty claims. We'll have full disclosure around our warranty reserves in our 10-K, but I think you'll see or count our typical role forward of our royalty claim.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just overall, we do have a litigation reserve and have four for years. The gross estimated liability in terms of our actuarially determined litigation reserve is $571.3 million. Offset against that, we have an estimated interest receivable of $251.5 m
componenttext: And just overall, we do have a litigation reserve and have four for years. The gross estimated liability in terms of our actuarially determined litigation reserve is $571.3 million. Offset against that, we have an estimated interest receivable of $251.5 million. So our net reserve is $319.8 million. The year-over-year change in that net reserve has increased about $20 million, primarily just due to adding our estimates for the closings that occurred this year and then offset by anything that rolled off of the tale or any claims that were settled during the year. That's something we evaluate on a quarter-to-quarter basis and adjust as we need to, but we haven't seen any major changes in the activity. We've been very proactive on that in the history of the company. And again, I don't think we get credit for the conservative nature of our balance sheet, but we have been very conservative in all of our accruals, so I think we're well prepared for whatever the warranty claims are in a go-forward basis.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jade Rahmani with KBW.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jade Rahmani with KBW.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to ask on mortgage repurchase. Can you provide any insight on how you're looking at the risk efforts future purchase request? It sounds like you do. The risk gets fairly low especially given your recent provision experience. Why do you think y
componenttext: I just want to ask on mortgage repurchase. Can you provide any insight on how you're looking at the risk efforts future purchase request? It sounds like you do. The risk gets fairly low especially given your recent provision experience. Why do you think you haven't seen more of an increase in repurchase request given what the banks are seeing? Is it the nature of the new home product or because the mortgages originated were all purchase loans and didn't include refi activity? Or is it something else?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, there's probably several reasons. I think there actually has been a lower experience on new home mortgage originations, and there have been on existing homes. Part of it is because there's less refinance activity. So we haven't had people taking a lot
componenttext: No, there's probably several reasons. I think there actually has been a lower experience on new home mortgage originations, and there have been on existing homes. Part of it is because there's less refinance activity. So we haven't had people taking a lot of equity out based on large depreciation in home prices in certain markets where the home prices have adjusted back down as much. Beyond that, our provisions are based on a complete analysis of the loans that we have originated, the types of those that we have originated, the put back experience we've had on each type of loan and you're just -- well, I'm talking about in the comps post script with the decrease in mortgages put back to us a 23% in the second half of the year versus the first half of the year. That's indicating that we're seeing fewer requests in a time when this is a headline. And one thing I would point out's we've been recording recourse expense for four years. This isn't a new issue. I know it's kind of new in terms of the headline essentially, but we've been practically dealing with it through our mortgage company.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Joshua Pollard with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Joshua Pollard with Goldman Sachs.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is a pretty simple one. Do you guys expect to be profitable in 2011?
componenttext: My first question is a pretty simple one. Do you guys expect to be profitable in 2011?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do, and I will tell you that it's going to be a greater challenge than it was in 2010 simply because, as we mentioned to you, our sales and closing volumes will be -- we anticipate to be less, unless we have some significant spring sales bumps tha
componenttext: Yes, we do, and I will tell you that it's going to be a greater challenge than it was in 2010 simply because, as we mentioned to you, our sales and closing volumes will be -- we anticipate to be less, unless we have some significant spring sales bumps that we are having a hard time seeing today. So, yes, that's our goal. But again, it's going to be a larger challenge than it was last year in 2010.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if I understand everything that you're saying right, it will be fewer deliveries, lighter gross margin. You guys are looking to hold the line at least from a percentage basis on SG&A. Is there anywhere else that we should be expecting you guys to gene
componenttext: And if I understand everything that you're saying right, it will be fewer deliveries, lighter gross margin. You guys are looking to hold the line at least from a percentage basis on SG&A. Is there anywhere else that we should be expecting you guys to generate profits? Are you guys looking to do anything different in your business. You've had a number of your competitors getting to ancillary pieces about the rest of internal commercial market? I'm wondering if any of those things are interesting to you at this stage.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, frankly, we know one thing, we're a homebuilder, and what we're focusing on is the homebuilding operation and to the extent that financial services supplements that, the financial service side of the business. I don't see any significant opportuniti
componenttext: Well, frankly, we know one thing, we're a homebuilder, and what we're focusing on is the homebuilding operation and to the extent that financial services supplements that, the financial service side of the business. I don't see any significant opportunities out there that are going to enhance our performance other than continuing to execute on building, selling, closing homes and making money as I call it BSCM. That's our focus and really largely our sole focus at this point. And I think that our revenues and our closings, we do expect them to be down some based upon the tax credits not being with us. But I also believe that on the SG&A side; we're going to continue to look for opportunities to improve our SG&A. That's going to be more challenging, but this company has always come to the forefront in terms of dealing with whatever the market conditions are, and that's where we'll be.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And one other contributing factor, Josh, will be on our interest expense. We have continued to reduce our debt, dramatically reduced by about $1 billion this year. So our interest incurred has been coming down sharply. That will continue to flow through,
componenttext: And one other contributing factor, Josh, will be on our interest expense. We have continued to reduce our debt, dramatically reduced by about $1 billion this year. So our interest incurred has been coming down sharply. That will continue to flow through, and we'll see continued reductions in our direct interest expense. We see less interest capitalized in our inventory today than we did a year ago given our reduction in debt. So that is some offset, some mitigating factor to the margin pressure we expect to see in the marketplace. So both of those factors on the interest will contribute to some incremental improvement. And hopefully, it helps to offset the market conditions we expect to see.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I don't mean to be redundant, Josh. But once again, I think that a lot of companies would love to be in our position of having a 17% gross margin to deal with the future.
componenttext: And I don't mean to be redundant, Josh. But once again, I think that a lot of companies would love to be in our position of having a 17% gross margin to deal with the future.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as you the made that comment about your reversed gross margin, could you just talk very quickly about the difference between your margins on spec versus third sales? I mean, we're hearing a lot of different numbers across the industry. I would love
componenttext: Well, as you the made that comment about your reversed gross margin, could you just talk very quickly about the difference between your margins on spec versus third sales? I mean, we're hearing a lot of different numbers across the industry. I would love to hear where you guys stand now, and where do you think it could be if specs continue to make up a large portion of your sales.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our margins on our specs are typically lower than our margins on our build jobs. But, yes, at the same time, we know two things. One, by having specs, it satisfies the buyer who needs to be a relocation buyer or a first-time home buyer, who can all
componenttext: Well, our margins on our specs are typically lower than our margins on our build jobs. But, yes, at the same time, we know two things. One, by having specs, it satisfies the buyer who needs to be a relocation buyer or a first-time home buyer, who can all of a sudden qualify because they've gotten their credits right now or they're ready to move out of an apartment or out of their parents' home. The other thing we know about specs to own our focus in the company is that to the extent that a spec is 90 days older, it's 90 days past completion, we need to move that spec as quickly as possible because the profits on those specs have a tendency to decline the older they become.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's really a matter of focusing on managing them carefully, and that's something we've been doing for a long time. That's part of our business. And while there are lower margins on the spec versus build jobs, I think you can look at an overall margin and
componenttext: It's really a matter of focusing on managing them carefully, and that's something we've been doing for a long time. That's part of our business. And while there are lower margins on the spec versus build jobs, I think you can look at an overall margin and see that we are managing it reasonably well. There's always room for improvement, but that's something we're always focused on.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And to be specific, as we've always said, specs are a part of our business and is a part of our business model, and that's why we've been so affected by it over the years.
componenttext: And to be specific, as we've always said, specs are a part of our business and is a part of our business model, and that's why we've been so affected by it over the years.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Zener with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Zener with KeyBanc.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to get a little more granular. Obviously, you guys have been aggressive on the debt pay-down to lower your interest expense. If you were to look at simply the homebuilding operation, do you expect that business to be profitable, realizing ther
componenttext: I just want to get a little more granular. Obviously, you guys have been aggressive on the debt pay-down to lower your interest expense. If you were to look at simply the homebuilding operation, do you expect that business to be profitable, realizing there's a couple leverage that could affect the EPS relative to the interest expense and impairments?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, we expect the Homebuilding business to be profitable, and that's our focus, that's what our business plans call for. And then as we move to the fiscal year quarter-by-quarter, we'll see how successful we are at executing what our business plan
componenttext: Absolutely, we expect the Homebuilding business to be profitable, and that's our focus, that's what our business plans call for. And then as we move to the fiscal year quarter-by-quarter, we'll see how successful we are at executing what our business plan is. But, yes, we get up everyday, starting to shave and put our makeup on, and our goal is to be profitable in the homebuilding side of our business.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, I guess, related to the differential of new communities purchase post in '09 or later, that 200 to 300 basis points seems to be lower than what we might hear from other builders. Could you comment on, is that a function of where you initially un
componenttext: And then, I guess, related to the differential of new communities purchase post in '09 or later, that 200 to 300 basis points seems to be lower than what we might hear from other builders. Could you comment on, is that a function of where you initially underwrote it at a tighter range? Did it come in? And I guess kind of related to the first question on profitably, do you think your DTA could come back next year?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the new communities, we've been consistently saying 200 to 300 basis points for two years. And we started doing our new communities almost two years ago and have a significant history of closings on those communities and has become a significant portio
componenttext: On the new communities, we've been consistently saying 200 to 300 basis points for two years. And we started doing our new communities almost two years ago and have a significant history of closings on those communities and has become a significant portion of our business. So we're confident that that's a good level. Certainly, some do better than that. Some may be a little lower than that, but that's our average. And so I'm confident in our history, and I will see over time whether other builders' new communities contributed a similar level or better.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think that point is we do have a track record on our older communities, our new communities, I should say. And the other builders are just now beginning to enter into a lot of new deals or some new deals. So I think we certainly have a better t
componenttext: Yes, and I think that point is we do have a track record on our older communities, our new communities, I should say. And the other builders are just now beginning to enter into a lot of new deals or some new deals. So I think we certainly have a better track record in our 200 to 300 basis points is probably a lot more accurate than you're receiving from some.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And other thing I'd say on our existing communities is they're not static either, and we continue to renegotiate the costs, redesign the product, do everything we can to bring the costs down on those and improve the margins on those. At the same time, we'
componenttext: And other thing I'd say on our existing communities is they're not static either, and we continue to renegotiate the costs, redesign the product, do everything we can to bring the costs down on those and improve the margins on those. At the same time, we're layering in the higher margins from the options, and that's all reflected in our 17% to 18% margin that we've been running this year.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: So clearly, if our margins improved by 400 basis points versus last year, that did not come from new communities. Our existing communities improved their margins as well. So while the gap may be only 200 to 300, both levels are rising. I think you also as
componenttext: So clearly, if our margins improved by 400 basis points versus last year, that did not come from new communities. Our existing communities improved their margins as well. So while the gap may be only 200 to 300, both levels are rising. I think you also asked about the DTA for tax asset. It's a little over $900 million. Right now, the analysis of whether and when that might come on will be solely dependent, largely dependent on our profitability. The ability for us to have sustained substantial profitability and our expectations for forward profitability. So that will be dependent on our ability to execute on our goal and our plan to be profitable in fiscal 2011. And we'll be evaluating that as we move through the year. We can't say anything definitive about that right now until we show a consistent profitable record.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Oppenheim with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Oppenheim with Crédit Suisse.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you can just talk about your thoughts on community count. You've said that the community count will be dependent on the market and the sales, others trying to bring on new communities to effectively offset the tougher conditions. Is you
componenttext: I was wondering if you can just talk about your thoughts on community count. You've said that the community count will be dependent on the market and the sales, others trying to bring on new communities to effectively offset the tougher conditions. Is your thought that there's effectively too much supply out there as it is, and why deal with that? Can you just talk about your thoughts there?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not really, Dan. I'd tell you what it mainly surrounds is the willingness of the sellers, whether they be banks or developers, to write their lots down to current market conditions. And we've had a lot of institutions, who have been unwilling to park thei
componenttext: Not really, Dan. I'd tell you what it mainly surrounds is the willingness of the sellers, whether they be banks or developers, to write their lots down to current market conditions. And we've had a lot of institutions, who have been unwilling to park their lots to the price that really is the market price. So it's more of getting a log jam undone and many lenders relative to our ability to bring on those new communities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's already been a focus for us. It's up to 49% of our sales this quarter, and we'll continue to focus on it as far as incremental increase. But we're clearly just as focused on it because it's important to our business going forward.
componenttext: It's already been a focus for us. It's up to 49% of our sales this quarter, and we'll continue to focus on it as far as incremental increase. But we're clearly just as focused on it because it's important to our business going forward.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a function, too, in our division presence, in our regional presence and our land that people spend a lot of time with banks. And the first time you go in to discuss with the bank a foreclosed asset, they're typically in denial or they don't have the
componenttext: It's a function, too, in our division presence, in our regional presence and our land that people spend a lot of time with banks. And the first time you go in to discuss with the bank a foreclosed asset, they're typically in denial or they don't have the capital that they want to use to write down the loan to get the lots of the market price. So it takes a while, sometimes it takes a year before they are willing to deal with it. And at that point in time, as I said earlier, without a doubt, based upon our performance over the last couple of years in these foreclosed communities, we are the pre-imminent buyer in the marketplace today.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, just wondering, you're talking about the specs, and you've done a great job in the past in the terms of managing the specs and delivering the order growth of observing margin. Your comments in terms of the weaker demand, while still goi
componenttext: And then secondly, just wondering, you're talking about the specs, and you've done a great job in the past in the terms of managing the specs and delivering the order growth of observing margin. Your comments in terms of the weaker demand, while still going after buyers' pulse, is this especially you're not going after too much in terms of demand right now? I think there's too much worry in terms of having margins here. What's your thought there?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, we continually adjust our specs, as well as our inventory, relative to the demand that we see on a go-forward basis. So clearly, we have been reducing our unit inventory. We've been reducing our specs. Because as we said earlier, we expect our s
componenttext: Actually, we continually adjust our specs, as well as our inventory, relative to the demand that we see on a go-forward basis. So clearly, we have been reducing our unit inventory. We've been reducing our specs. Because as we said earlier, we expect our sales and closings to be less in 2011 than they were in 2010. So clearly, we're adjusting that inventory in accordance with what we think's going to happen is. As Don Horton said, one thing we can do is we can start them quickly, and we can get them built quickly. So to the extent that the demand exceeds where our current inventory level is, which is based upon what a lower number than perhaps what could be out there next year, we're well prepared to meet the demand because we can build them quickly.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you like our inventory levels, we're sufficient to meet our expectations right now.
componenttext: If you like our inventory levels, we're sufficient to meet our expectations right now.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jonathan Ellis with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jonathan Ellis with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: First question, just on what happened this quarter and then sort of looking forward with respect to pricing and use of incentives, I appreciate the commentary on the effect that mix benefited pricing this quarter. But I guess, as you think through the gro
componenttext: First question, just on what happened this quarter and then sort of looking forward with respect to pricing and use of incentives, I appreciate the commentary on the effect that mix benefited pricing this quarter. But I guess, as you think through the gross margin pressures to come and recognizing that pricing in your orders was fairly stable quarter-over-quarter, is it possible that more of the incentives could be coming below the price line in a form of closing costs or free options or upgrades that would impact margin with the price. So basically, the question is, could you see a scenario play out where pricing hold fairly stable over the next few quarters, where margins may come under pressure?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Certainly, that's our goal is to hold pricing stable in all of our communities. And to the extent that we need to incentivize our homes to be sold at a faster pace, we like to do that below the line as opposed to above the line.
componenttext: Certainly, that's our goal is to hold pricing stable in all of our communities. And to the extent that we need to incentivize our homes to be sold at a faster pace, we like to do that below the line as opposed to above the line.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: So you think, as of right now, you're feeling fairly comfortable you should be able to achieve that over the next few quarters?
componenttext: So you think, as of right now, you're feeling fairly comfortable you should be able to achieve that over the next few quarters?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that let's back up...
componenttext: Yes, I think that let's back up...

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: There are going to be two things that impact our average sales price. One would be just absolute pricing pressure, which, as Don said, our first response to that is going to be to offer additional incentives because we do want to try to hold on to our bas
componenttext: There are going to be two things that impact our average sales price. One would be just absolute pricing pressure, which, as Don said, our first response to that is going to be to offer additional incentives because we do want to try to hold on to our base pricing. The other thing that we're continuing to do then is we're opening new communities with lower cost. And that is letting us continue to offer new product and lower prices than in some of the current communities that we have open. So you could see some change in our pricing going forward as a combination of those two factors.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And also if you look at our stick-and-brick cost this quarter, we are down 320 bps on stick and brick. And one of the things that we've done over the last two years consistently is continue to drive down those stick-and-brick cost. I just came at Southeas
componenttext: And also if you look at our stick-and-brick cost this quarter, we are down 320 bps on stick and brick. And one of the things that we've done over the last two years consistently is continue to drive down those stick-and-brick cost. I just came at Southeast Florida, where we had a vendor meeting with our Southeast Florida division. And we had that Southwest Florida, we have a number of communities, and I will tell you we were frank with our vendors. We appreciated them having cooperated with us over the last couple of years. But to the extent of the market softer on a go-forward basis, we're going to be expecting better pricing and more concessions from our vendors because we're all in this together. We're trying to get to the point where we all can achieve profitability, but the only way we can do that is to continue to meet the market.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the second question, if you could offer up any guidance for what you think percentage of deliveries or closings next year will be from recently purchased lots. And then a related question, I've heard you talk about the 200 to 300 basis points mar
componenttext: And then the second question, if you could offer up any guidance for what you think percentage of deliveries or closings next year will be from recently purchased lots. And then a related question, I've heard you talk about the 200 to 300 basis points margin, right, for at least the last few quarters. I guess given your commentary about some of your competitors perhaps putting more spec inventory to the market and potential challenges in the spring selling season and next year, I guess, why are you still comfortable or confident that you can maintain that margin spread over your legacy communities? Why would you not see just as much pricing pressure perhaps or if more in newer communities that may narrow that spread?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, one thing that we're going to continue to do is to continue to add new communities at current market pricing. So to the extent that the market gets softer, we're going to be negotiating better finished lot prices. Also, we consistently renegotiate o
componenttext: Well, one thing that we're going to continue to do is to continue to add new communities at current market pricing. So to the extent that the market gets softer, we're going to be negotiating better finished lot prices. Also, we consistently renegotiate our existing rolling option contracts. And that's one of the beauties of a rolling option contract is we don't own the lots, someone else owns them. And to the extent our gross margins get compressed before we do the next take down, we're back renegotiating the lot price downward. And I'm personally approving all of the lot contract and all the renegotiations. So I can tell you, we see a lot of renegotiated contracts there. Additionally, I would say to you that we are going to put pressure on our vendors, and they've supported us throughout the years. And especially, since we're such a significant portion of every market, our vendors are very focused on additional business. And as we continue to aggregate market share in each one of our divisions, then we are going to be able to get price concessions from them. Just as an example, I just noticed the other day that we got something that' of a Las Vegas, where we are the largest builder in Las Vegas with 14.2% of the market share. I was in Southeast Florida, where a year ago, we had five communities. We're going to have 20 communities by the end of this calendar year and 25 communities by midyear next year. In Southwest Florida, we had seven two years ago and now, we have 34 communities. So if anyone has the opportunity to continue to put pricing pressure on the land sellers and the lot sellers and the vendors, someone is doing the volume in those markets to the extent that we are.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one distinction, the 200 to 300 basis points spread between newer communities and legacy communities is simply the spread in their margins. Competitive market pressures affect both new communities and legacy communities. So both of them, if they're u
componenttext: Just one distinction, the 200 to 300 basis points spread between newer communities and legacy communities is simply the spread in their margins. Competitive market pressures affect both new communities and legacy communities. So both of them, if they're under pressure, would move in the same direction, but we would still expect the spread to be better on our newer communities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And with option contracts, if we see significant price movement, we still have the opportunities to go back and renegotiate those lot costs.
componenttext: And with option contracts, if we see significant price movement, we still have the opportunities to go back and renegotiate those lot costs.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you have a guidance or percentage of deliveries or closings from recently purchased land for '11?
componenttext: Do you have a guidance or percentage of deliveries or closings from recently purchased land for '11?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our recent sales in the most recent quarter were up to 49% of our business. We expect that to continue to grow. It's now become a core part of our business, will continue to be a core part of our business, and so we expect that to continue to grow.
componenttext: Our recent sales in the most recent quarter were up to 49% of our business. We expect that to continue to grow. It's now become a core part of our business, will continue to be a core part of our business, and so we expect that to continue to grow.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Nishu Sood with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Nishu Sood with Deutsche Bank.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to come back to this somber outlook that is surprising a lot of people, I suppose. If I look at what you're reporting this quarter, I guess, I don't get it. I don't understand where this incremental somberness comes from. Because if I look at, fo
componenttext: I wanted to come back to this somber outlook that is surprising a lot of people, I suppose. If I look at what you're reporting this quarter, I guess, I don't get it. I don't understand where this incremental somberness comes from. Because if I look at, for example, what you said about demand, it's after the post-tax credit drop off in April and May, a pick up from July through September, and then really normal seasonality from there. Pricing, it seems, has not been great but has been kind of stable. Your gross margins, your September quarter was obviously after the post-tax credit closings. And that was pretty strong considering, especially with all the specs that you moved. So I mean, what am I missing here? I mean, is this really just boiled down to a comp issue that's the last year, you had two tax credits in it from a volume perspective and this year, you won't? So what am I missing here in terms of what's happening now that is driving this increased level of pessimism from you folks?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And maybe you're not watching as much Fox news as I watched, and maybe I'm watching too much of it. But to be quite candid with you, I don't see much on the horizon that would give anybody a great degree of comfort on the financial condition of the countr
componenttext: And maybe you're not watching as much Fox news as I watched, and maybe I'm watching too much of it. But to be quite candid with you, I don't see much on the horizon that would give anybody a great degree of comfort on the financial condition of the country. I see still high unemployment. I see very lack luster job growth or no job growth. We see continued high unemployment, and I see any corporations sitting with over $1 trillion in cash. So perhaps, I'm more somber than they, but they obviously are voting with their pocket book because we're all keeping a lot of cash on our balance sheets until we have some future that's being driven by the government that says, "Hey, here's what the rules are, and we can go forward and play for the next three to five years. And here's what the rules are." We don't know what the rules are, and we're by virtue of who we are and our experience in business a little more adept at dealing with that. But if you're a consumer out there and you're working at Boeing or working on Microsoft, you're working on one of those companies and you see what's going on in the economy, I don't know how you can have any confidence that you're going to have a job tomorrow because people are still being laid off. So our somber outlook is one that, perhaps, I'd call it realistic. It's no job growth, high unemployment and a tremendous amount of debt in this country, which is focusing on are we going to have issues going forward, which I think we will with our debt. So until those major factors are fixed in the economy, I don't think any business can have any great insurance as to what's going to happen in the future.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I guess to frame it in terms of what you're not saying, you are not saying that you saw a dramatic drop-off in demand, which has driven you to be more pessimistic. You are not saying that you've seen pricing fall apart. You're basically saying that as
componenttext: So I guess to frame it in terms of what you're not saying, you are not saying that you saw a dramatic drop-off in demand, which has driven you to be more pessimistic. You are not saying that you've seen pricing fall apart. You're basically saying that as you look in the past two year, which benefited from some government stimulus and a lot of uncertainty going forward, it sounds more like a macro statement as opposed with other things, which you're not saying.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, yes. This company is positioned today better than any company in our industry to deal whether will be somber, realistic or optimistic come the spring selling season. I'm just dealing with the macro issues, and the macro issues, I think, have a
componenttext: Absolutely, yes. This company is positioned today better than any company in our industry to deal whether will be somber, realistic or optimistic come the spring selling season. I'm just dealing with the macro issues, and the macro issues, I think, have a bigger impact on our industry than any of the other factors are involved.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Stephen East with Ticonderoga.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Stephen East with Ticonderoga.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Whether you're seeing something in your order trends that made you change your mind, are you seeing any shift among buyers? Are you seeing a shift from entry level toward move up, anything like that that's going on in the market?
componenttext: Whether you're seeing something in your order trends that made you change your mind, are you seeing any shift among buyers? Are you seeing a shift from entry level toward move up, anything like that that's going on in the market?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Subsequent to that tax credit, we have seen our first-time home buyers now into the high 40% instead of in the 50% to 55% range, so we have seen a little bit of that. But we're still seeing the strongest demand from the first-time homebuyers simply becaus
componenttext: Subsequent to that tax credit, we have seen our first-time home buyers now into the high 40% instead of in the 50% to 55% range, so we have seen a little bit of that. But we're still seeing the strongest demand from the first-time homebuyers simply because they don't have some of the hurdles in terms of selling the existing homes before they can move into another home.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And could you just remind us when you would start seeing your first indications of the spring selling season?
componenttext: And could you just remind us when you would start seeing your first indications of the spring selling season?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we think that -- well, clearly, Super Bowl Sunday. But as we're talking the other day, it's going to be end of February and most likely in the March before we can really ascertain whether there's been any spring selling season.
componenttext: Well, we think that -- well, clearly, Super Bowl Sunday. But as we're talking the other day, it's going to be end of February and most likely in the March before we can really ascertain whether there's been any spring selling season.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Carl Reichardt from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Carl Reichardt from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Stacey, last quarter, we talked about this quarter being potentially profitable by the challenge, and one of the issues was focused on backlog turnover. And your backlog turnover was close to 100% this quarter and actually that way pretty much through the
componenttext: Stacey, last quarter, we talked about this quarter being potentially profitable by the challenge, and one of the issues was focused on backlog turnover. And your backlog turnover was close to 100% this quarter and actually that way pretty much through the year. What are you thinking about 2011? Are we going to continue to see you turn your backlog close to 100% a quarter? Is that going to slow up?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's hard to say, but we achieved 100% in the Q4, which is typically our highest backlog conversion. The other times, we exceeded 100% this fiscal year were typically quarters where we have tax credit, expirations either in the quarter or imminent. So it'
componenttext: It's hard to say, but we achieved 100% in the Q4, which is typically our highest backlog conversion. The other times, we exceeded 100% this fiscal year were typically quarters where we have tax credit, expirations either in the quarter or imminent. So it's hard to say that we will continue to see that. We have seen, though, a continued higher percentage of our home closings coming from the specs, which can be a shorter contract to close process. And we do continue to have those homes available, so that can keep our conversion rate elevated. But in terms of giving you a definite answer on what we can achieve going forward is difficult to do.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Don, going back to your thought process on market share gains, are there some specific regions in the country or metro areas, maybe two or three, where you think the gain potential for you guys is most great? I know you're going to say it's pret
componenttext: And then, Don, going back to your thought process on market share gains, are there some specific regions in the country or metro areas, maybe two or three, where you think the gain potential for you guys is most great? I know you're going to say it's pretty much everywhere, but I'd like you to focus on two to three that where you think the opportunity is the best?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, I think Florida has been really a great story for us over the course of the last 12, 18 months. I also look at Texas because of the fact that in Texas, there are a lot of rolling option opportunities here more so than elsewhere. And clearly
componenttext: Well, clearly, I think Florida has been really a great story for us over the course of the last 12, 18 months. I also look at Texas because of the fact that in Texas, there are a lot of rolling option opportunities here more so than elsewhere. And clearly, Texas is our home, and Texas continues to be a very profitable market for us. And we have some very good operators here. We also have some very good operators in Florida. Ironically, I look at our position in Las Vegas, and Las Vegas is really a marginal market. And we've got a division President out there in Scotstone and has a great team, and we continue to take market share in Las Vegas in a really, really sad market. I think that also that we have opportunities in the Atlanta market, and we have a good operator there. But those are really where I see some of our best market opportunities and big markets where we can continue to take market share.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jack Micenko with FIG.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jack Micenko with FIG.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Most of the questions have been answered. Just two quick ones. Can you talk about your sub-prime process in '06 and '07 and how that's really changed for today? And what kind of sales mix in terms of financing versus GSC versus otherwise private label in
componenttext: Most of the questions have been answered. Just two quick ones. Can you talk about your sub-prime process in '06 and '07 and how that's really changed for today? And what kind of sales mix in terms of financing versus GSC versus otherwise private label in that time period? And then a follow up.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Basically, sub-prime was available. There were investors who were interested in buying sub-prime product. And so our mortgage company originated sub-prime in '05 and '06. The sub-prime and all pay combined essentially replaced the governmental lending in
componenttext: Basically, sub-prime was available. There were investors who were interested in buying sub-prime product. And so our mortgage company originated sub-prime in '05 and '06. The sub-prime and all pay combined essentially replaced the governmental lending in terms of percentages, so government had been 50% to 60% of our business prior to the availability of sub-prime in Alt-A. Alt-A and sub-prime grew, while government shrink. And then there are no investors today buying either sub-prime or Alt-A. Most of them, mortgage investors are looking for full documentation with the implicit guarantee of the U.S. government behind it. And so the government portion of our loans has grown again to 66% this quarter.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And when you say, government, are you breaking out or you're putting FHA in that total?
componenttext: And when you say, government, are you breaking out or you're putting FHA in that total?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: FHA is in there. it's usually in about a mid-40% range, and then the balance of that is going to be DA.
componenttext: FHA is in there. it's usually in about a mid-40% range, and then the balance of that is going to be DA.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the $350 million or so on the watch list, do you offer a state-by-state breakdown of that number?
componenttext: And then on the $350 million or so on the watch list, do you offer a state-by-state breakdown of that number?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I believe we gave our top three states, which account for more than 50%, and that is California, Illinois and Arizona. And this is a point I always like to mention that we're the only builder, I think, that gives you a watch list.
componenttext: I believe we gave our top three states, which account for more than 50%, and that is California, Illinois and Arizona. And this is a point I always like to mention that we're the only builder, I think, that gives you a watch list.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jay McCanless with Guggenheim.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jay McCanless with Guggenheim.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: ASPs for fiscal '11, I know it's been a little over the map this year because of mix shift. But the land that you're buying now, what should we expect for ASPs in '11?
componenttext: ASPs for fiscal '11, I know it's been a little over the map this year because of mix shift. But the land that you're buying now, what should we expect for ASPs in '11?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: We expect our ASPs to be flat to slightly up.
componenttext: We expect our ASPs to be flat to slightly up.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I agree with your commentary about inflation being the looming problem in front of us, but how soon or what should we expect in terms of it showing up in your stick-and-brick cost? I mean, you said it was down 320 bps this year, but how long do y
componenttext: And then I agree with your commentary about inflation being the looming problem in front of us, but how soon or what should we expect in terms of it showing up in your stick-and-brick cost? I mean, you said it was down 320 bps this year, but how long do you think you're going to be able to sustain that if we do see a sharp pickup in inflation?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Don has addressed a lot of that. Just in terms of as long as the top line continues to be soft for us and we see continued margin pressure, we're going to be back negotiating. We cannot accept price increases right now. And so there's been a lot o
componenttext: I think Don has addressed a lot of that. Just in terms of as long as the top line continues to be soft for us and we see continued margin pressure, we're going to be back negotiating. We cannot accept price increases right now. And so there's been a lot of talk about increases in commodities. I think we had some tough round inflation in paint, and we have price protection in all of those categories in most of our markets. And so we're going to negotiate very aggressively even in the markets where we don't, just based on our volume. And so we've heard a lot about price increases over the last year. And in general, we're able to hold the line in our pricing, and we'll continue to do that until we can sell our end product for a greater price.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if we think that what happens in the marketplace, where we have softer sales and softer closings for the industry on a go-forward basis, I think a lot of these, even if they are inflationary pressures from our vendors on commodities, I think is going
componenttext: And if we think that what happens in the marketplace, where we have softer sales and softer closings for the industry on a go-forward basis, I think a lot of these, even if they are inflationary pressures from our vendors on commodities, I think is going to be a difficult time for them to push those through based upon the slowing demand both on the sales and the closings.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Smith with JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Smith with JMP Securities.

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I've heard from some other builders and, Don, you kind of mentioned a little bit earlier, but just if you could give a little more color on it. This idea that pricing right now for consumers, because it's much more of a confidence question than anything e
componenttext: I've heard from some other builders and, Don, you kind of mentioned a little bit earlier, but just if you could give a little more color on it. This idea that pricing right now for consumers, because it's much more of a confidence question than anything else and people just don't feel comfortable going out in buying a house that pricing for homes is fairly inelastic. And I'm wondering if you can comment on whether or not you agree with that, and how much of that impacts your decisions going forward about pricing and incentives and if that offers some measure of margin protection for you guys knowing that people are going to kind of come out of the woodwork, when they're going to come out of the woodwork and there's not a whole lot on pricing that you can do affect that or if you think that's the wrong way to look at?

headline: DR Horton Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Nov 12, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think pricing is inelastic. We talked to our salespeople more than I do on a daily basis, our sales managers and it's just not a lot that we can do to continue to sell homes, increase our sales base relative to the traffic that we've got. Now we've got
componenttext: I think pricing is inelastic. We talked to our salespeople more than I do on a daily basis, our sales managers and it's just not a lot that we can do to continue to sell homes, increase our sales base relative to the traffic that we've got.
